CHAPTER 11
FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS
SECTION:
2-11-1: Creation
2-11-2: Duties
2-11-1: CREATION:
There shall be a Board of Fire and Police Commissioners as provided by law,
which shall consist of three (3) members to be appointed by the Mayor, whose
terms of office shall be three (3) years and until their respective successors
are appointed and have qualified, by and with the advice and consent of the
City Council. Not more than two (2) members of the Board shall belong to the
same political party. (Ord. 94-5, 3-21-1994)
2-11-2: DUTIES:
The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall have charge of all
appointments to the Fire and Police Departments and shall conduct and hold all
entrance and promotional examinations in the manner required by law. (M.C.
1962, sec. 9.902)
CHAPTER 12
FIREMEN'S PENSION BOARD
SECTION:
2-12-1: Creation
2-12-2: Duties
2-12-1: CREATION:
There is hereby created a Board of Trustees of the Fire Pension Fund which
shall consist of the Fire Chief, the Mayor, the City Treasurer, the City Clerk
or Deputy City Clerk and three (3) other persons who shall be chosen from the
active firefighters of the City, and one other person who shall be chosen from
the retired firefighters as provided by statute. The members of the Board
selected from the active and retired firefighters shall be elected at the time
and in the manner provided by statute. (Ord. 98-19, 5-4-1998)
2-12-2: DUTIES:
The Board of Trustees of the Firemen's Pension Fund shall have control of the
management of all funds belonging to or designated by law as part of the
Firemen's Pension Fund and of the administration of such funds, as provided by
statute. (M.C. 1962, sec. 9.1002)
CHAPTER 13
MUNICIPAL YOUTH COUNCIL
(Rep. by Ord. 98-19, 5-4-1998)
CHAPTER 14
PARK AND RECREATION BOARD
SECTION:
2-14-1: Board Membership
2-14-2: Organization
2-14-3: Control And Purposes
2-14-4: Receipts; Donations; Disposition
2-14-1: BOARD MEMBERSHIP:
The park and recreation board shall consist of nine (9) members. One member of
the nine (9) members shall be an alderman, with voting power. In addition,
there shall be an alternate alderman appointed, to have voting power only in
the absence of the primary aldermanic member. Both the primary and alternate
aldermanic members shall be appointed by the mayor, with the consent of the
city council. The board appointments shall be for a two (2) year term with the
terms staggered so that four (4) members are appointed one year and four (4)
members appointed the following year, with the aldermanic term being for one
year and being made annually. The appointments shall be made by the mayor on
the first regular council meeting in May of each year. (Ord. 95-14, 4-17-1995;
amd. Ord. 03-17, 5-19-2003)
2-14-2: ORGANIZATION:
The board shall elect one of its number as chairman, one as secretary, and one
as treasurer. The treasurer of the park and recreation board shall be
responsible for the compilation and reporting of the financial condition of the
park board, and shall not have authority to prepare or execute drafts for the
expenditures of funds. The board shall keep a correct record of its proceedings
and shall meet at such times as it may determine. (Ord. 00-24, 8-7-2000)
2-14-3: CONTROL AND PURPOSES:
   (A)   The park board shall have the responsibility for the establishment,
planning and coordination of all public parks and recreation programs involving
park property and shall direct the ornamenting, adorning, laying out and
improving of the grounds of said parks.
   (B)   The employment and day to day supervision of such workmen as may be
necessary to carry out such purposes, and as may be permitted under the budget
of the park board as submitted to the city council and approved each year,
shall be under the director of maintenance services. The director shall be
assisted by the park supervisor. The director of maintenance services shall be
responsible for budget recommendations to the park board regarding wages,
equipment and maintenance; the director shall further coordinate the use of
park employees with other municipal functions and services so as to make best
use of all municipal employees and equipment. All materials and equipment
purchased for park purposes shall be coordinated with material and equipment
purchases of the department of maintenance services and shall be authorized by
the director of maintenance services. In addition, the park board shall assume
the responsibility for the planning, establishing and maintaining of the
municipal recreation programs within the city, such programs to include
playgrounds, sports and recreation programs, and recreation centers.
   (C)   The board shall collect all receipts from park board activities and
properties and deposit them in the park fund in the city treasury. All funds
expended for the establishment and maintenance of public parks for the use and
benefit of the inhabitants of the city shall be budgeted and accounted for
separately so as to assure the proper expenditure of the taxes levied for park
purposes.
   (D)   In addition, all funds from the adult softball program and other
programs as agreed upon by the parties shall be deposited to a separate fund in
the city clerk's office, with authorized expenditures being made from said
segregated funds.
   (E)   The supervisor of parks shall be compensated at a rate to be
determined from time to time by the city council and shall be appointed by the
mayor with the approval and consent of the city council. (Ord. 88-29, 5-2-1988)
2-14-4: RECEIPTS; DONATIONS; DISPOSITION:
All receipts on account of the city parks, whether arising from rentals,
donation, sale of any part thereof, or of any lands so willed and devised by
any person to the city, shall be exclusively expended and applied under the
direction and control of the park board. (Ord. 88-29, 5-2-1988)
CHAPTER 15
PLAN COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-15-1: Purpose
2-15-2: Membership
2-15-3: Term Of Office
2-15-4: Procedure
2-15-5: Powers And Duties
2-15-6: Land Subdivision Or Resubdivision
2-15-1: PURPOSE:
In order that adequate provisions be made for the preparation of a
comprehensive plan for the guidance, direction and control of the growth and
development or redevelopment of the City and contiguous territory not more than
one and one-half (11/2) miles beyond the corporate limits and not included in
another municipality, a Plan Commission is hereby created as provided for by
State law. (Ord. 64-31, 9-8-1964)
2-15-2: MEMBERSHIP:
Said Plan Commission shall consist of nine (9) members, citizens of the City
appointed by the Mayor, on the basis of their particular fitness for their duty
on said Plan Commission and subject to the approval of the City Council. The
assistant Director of Planning and Development shall serve as secretary of the
Plan Commission. (Ord. 98-19, 5-4-1998)
2-15-3: TERM OF OFFICE:
Of the nine (9) members originally appointed, three (3) shall serve for a
period of three (3) years; three (3) for a period of two (2) years, and three
(3) for a period of one year. Thereafter, such members shall serve for a period
of three (3) years. Vacancies shall be filled by appointments for unexpired
terms only. All members of the Commission shall serve without compensation
except that they may be reimbursed for reasonable expenses. (Ord. 64-31, 9-8-
1964)
2-15-4: PROCEDURE:
Immediately following their appointment, the members of the Plan Commission
shall meet, organize, elect such officers as it may deem necessary, and adopt
rules and regulations of organization and procedure consistent with this Code
and State laws. The Commission shall keep written records of its proceedings,
which shall be open at all times to public inspection. The Commission shall
submit an annual report to the Mayor and City Council setting forth its
transactions and recommendations. (Ord. 64-31, 9-8-1964)
2-15-5: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The Plan Commission shall have the following powers and duties:
   (A)   To prepare and recommend to the City Council a comprehensive plan for
the present and future development or redevelopment of the City and contiguous
unincorporated territory not more than one and one-half (11/2) miles beyond the
corporate limits of the City and not included in any other municipality. Such
plan when adopted in whole or in separate geographical or functional parts,
shall be the Official Comprehensive Plan, or part thereof. Such plans shall be
advisory except as to such part thereof as has been implemented by ordinances.
The Comprehensive Plan shall not be adopted or amended except after notice and
public hearing as required by 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-12-7. The City
Clerk shall file notice of the adopted Comprehensive Plan and any amendments
thereto with the County Recorder of Deeds and report same to the chairman of
the Planning Commission.
   (B)   To provide for the health, safety, comfort and convenience of the
inhabitants of the City and contiguous territory, the Plan Commission shall
establish reasonable standards of design for subdivisions and resubdivisions,
reasonable requirements governing the location, width, course and surfacing of
public streets and highways, alleys, ways for public service facilities, curbs,
gutters, sidewalks, streetlights, parks, playgrounds, school grounds, size of
lots to be used for residential purposes, storm water drainage, water supply
and distribution, sanitary sewers, and sewage collection and treatment. The
requirements specified herein shall become regulatory when adopted by
ordinance.
   (C)   The Plan Commission shall receive for review, the plans for each
subdivision of land within the City and within one and one-half (11/2) miles of
the City and not part of another municipality. The Plan Commission shall
determine whether the subdivision conforms to the Comprehensive Plan and the
Official Map of the City and report by resolution to the Council and within the
time limits prescribed in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-12-8.
   (D)   To recommend to the City Council from time to time, such changes in
the Comprehensive Plan, or any part thereof, as may be deemed necessary.
   (E)   To prepare and recommend to the City Council, from time to time,
proposals and/or recommendations for specific improvements in pursuance of the
Comprehensive Plan.
   (F)   To give aid to the officials of the City charged with the direction of
projects for improvements embraced within the Official Plan, or parts thereof,
to further the making of such improvements and generally to promote the
realization of the Comprehensive Plan.
   (G)   To arrange and conduct any form of publicity in relation to its
activities for the general purpose of public understanding.
   (H)   To cooperate with regional planning commissions and other agencies or
groups to further the local planning program and to assure harmonious and
integrated planning for the area.
   (I)   To exercise such other powers germane to the powers granted by State
law, as may be conferred by the City Council.
   (J)   To designate land suitable for annexation to the Municipality and the
recommended zoning classification for such land upon annexation. (Ord. 64-31,
9-8-1964)
2-15-6: LAND SUBDIVISION OR RESUBDIVISION:
At any time or times, before or after the formal adoption of the Comprehensive
Plan by the corporate authorities, an official map may be designated by
ordinance, which map may consist of the whole area included within the Official
Comprehensive Plan, or one or more separate geographical or functional parts,
and may include all or any part of the contiguous unincorporated area within
one and one-half (11/2) miles of the corporate limits of the City. All
requirements for public hearing, filing of notice of adoption with the County
Recorder of Deeds, and filing of said Plan and ordinances, including the
Official Map, with the City Clerk shall be complied with as provided for by
law. No map or plat of any subdivision or resubdivision presented for record
affecting land within the corporate limits of the City or within contiguous
territory which is not more than one and one-half (11/2) miles beyond the
corporate limits shall be entitled to record or shall be valid unless the
subdivision shown thereon provides for standards of design and standards
governing streets, alleys, public ways, ways for public service facilities,
streetlights, public grounds, size of lots to be used for residential purposes,
storm and flood water runoff channels and basins, water supply and
distribution, sanitary sewers and sewage collection and treatment in conformity
with the applicable requirements of this Code, including the Official Map.
(Ord. 64-31, 9-8-1964)
CHAPTER 16
POLICE PENSION BOARD
SECTION:
2-16-1: Creation
2-16-2: Duties
2-16-1: CREATION:
There shall be a Police Pension Board consisting of five (5) members. Of these
members, two (2) shall be appointed by the Mayor, serving a term of two (2)
years each; two (2) shall be elected from the regular police force of the City,
and one shall be elected from the beneficiaries of the pension. Each member
shall serve for two (2) years and elected members shall be selected in the
manner provided by statute. Provided, that the terms of the members of the
Police Pension Fund first appointed shall commence on the second Tuesday of May
following the adoption of this Chapter. (M.C. 1962, sec. 9.1401)
2-16-2: DUTIES:
It shall be the duty of the members of the Police Pension Board to manage,
invest and control the Police Pension Fund and all monies pertaining thereto in
the manner provided by statute and to pay beneficiaries as provided by law.
(M.C. 1964, sec. 9.1402)
CHAPTER 17
RECREATION BOARD
(Rep. by Ord. 88-29, 5-2-1988)
CHAPTER 18
SAFETY COUNCIL
(Rep. by Ord. 98-19, 5-4-1998)
CHAPTER 19
ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-19-1: Creation And Members
2-19-2: Removal Of Members
2-19-3: Purpose
2-19-4: Meetings
2-19-5: Financing
2-19-6: Functions
2-19-7: Powers
2-19-8: Cooperation
2-19-1: CREATION AND MEMBERS:
There is hereby created the economic development commission of the city of East
Moline. This commission shall consist of nine (9) members, to be appointed by
the mayor and with the advice and consent of the city council.
Six (6) members shall be appointed so as to represent the following groups:
business, labor, industry, professional, development and citizens at large.
Three (3) members shall be appointed as follows:
   (A)   The city administrator, or his designee.
   (B)   Two (2) aidermen of different political parties, each to be appointed
for a two (2) year term.
All members appointed under the prior Ordinance shall continue to serve the
designated terms as appointed.
In the event no reappointment or replacement has been made by the Mayor and
Council at the end of the expiring term, the members whose terms are expiring
shall continue on said commission until such time as a reappointment or
replacement has been made by the Mayor, by and with the consent of the City
Council. Any such appointment shall be for the remainder of the (2) year term.
(Ord. 74-64, 12-9-1974; amd. Ord. 19-03; 2-19-2019)
2-19-2: REMOVAL OF MEMBERS:
Any member may be removed for missing three (3) consecutive meetings. Removal
shall be by majority vote of the remaining commissioners whom are in good
standing. The Mayor shall appoint a new member with City Council approval to
complete the remainder of the term of said removed member. (Ord. 19-03, 2-19-
2019)
2-19-3: PURPOSE:
The commission shall be charged with the responsibility of promoting and
ensuring sound commercial and industrial development and redevelopment within
the corporate limits of the city of East Moline. (Ord. 19-03; 2-19-2019)
2-19-4: MEETINGS:
After appointing the members, the mayor shall call the first meeting at which
time the commission shall elect a chairman, vice chairman and a secretary-
treasurer. The commission at said first meeting shall determine the time the
regular meeting shall be held. The chairman may recommend changing the regular
meeting time and meeting place as may become necessary from time to time. The
chairman may call special meetings to conduct the business of the commission.
The commission shall act by majority rule on all matters.
Minutes will be taken of proceedings of all meetings showing the actions of the
commission, and the vote of each member upon questions coming before it.
Members may attend and participate either in person or electronically. These
minutes will be made available to the City Council upon request. (Ord. 98-19,
5-4-1998; amd. Ord. 19-03, 2-19-2019)
2-19-5: FINANCING:
The City shall, at its discretion, fund the Commission for reasonable and
necessary operating expenses. (Ord. 74-64, 12-9-1974; amd. Ord. 19-03, 2-19-
2019)
2-19-6: FUNCTIONS:
   (A)   Industrial Park Development: The commission shall submit for city
council approval a plan for orderly development of the East Moline industrial
park and shall also submit for city council approval restrictive covenants
governing the development of the park. The commission may recommend to the city
council, from time to time, such changes in the development plan and
restrictive covenants as may be deemed necessary.
The commission shall obtain a current appraisal of the industrial park land in
order to aid in establishing a fair selling price competitive with the present
market.
The commission is authorized to actively seek out industrial prospects, to
negotiate a sale price for the sale of land located in the industrial park, and
to advertise for bids for the sale of said land. Subsequent recommendations and
details are to be submitted to the city council for final approval. The city
council may disapprove the recommendation of the commission only by a vote of
two- thirds (2/3) of those aldermen present.
Upon approval, the city council shall pass all ordinances necessary to
implement said approval.
The commission is authorized to recommend the issuance of industrial project
revenue bonds to the city council and to represent to prospective purchasers of
real estate or other developers that said recommendation would be made on their
behalf.
The commission will not sell any land for speculation. Any person, business or
corporation who purchases land must agree to begin construction within one
hundred eighty (180) days from date of sale. Exception to this rule will be
allowed for an existing industry in the industrial park to purchase adjacent
property for future expansion of existing facilities. The commission shall have
the authority to allow a real estate broker retained by the commission to
receive a commission for the sale of the land.
   (B)   Commercial Development And Redevelopment: The commission is to promote
and actively seek respectable businesses which will be an asset to the city of
East Moline. It shall actively participate in improving, developing or
redeveloping all commercial areas so designated by the plan commission of the
city of East Moline.
The commission shall study all requests by businesses that ask for city
participation financially. The commission shall submit to the city council for
consideration a final recommendation, including all supportive details, such as
percentage of city participation, tangible and intangible benefits, and
expected return on investment.
The commission is to enlist the support of existing businesses in preventing
the deterioration of these areas and ensuring a continual program of upgrading
and renovation.
   (C)   General: The City-Wide Economic Developmental Strategic Plan shall be
reviewed by the commission annually. The commissioner may recommend to the City
Council or city staff, from time to time, such changes in the development plan
and restrictive covenants as may be deemed necessary or advisable.
The commission shall be authorized to obtain current appraisals of developable/
Re-developable land/property in order to aid in land/property development or
redevelopment.
The commission is authorized to actively seek out industrial and business
prospects, to obtain bids and/or negotiate a sale price for the sale of land
and property owned by the City, or where the City has other financial interest
(s), including, but not limited to, TIF, Enterprise Zone, creation or retention
of jobs, and any evaluation, determination and assistance of financing gaps not
otherwise adequately addressed by other regional or local development entities.
All recommendations and details are to be submitted to the City Council for
final approval. The City Council shall approve or disapprove any recommendation
by majority vote. Upon approval, the City Council shall pass all ordinances or
resolutions necessary to implement such approval.
The commission is authorized to recommend the issuance of any type of financial
obligation to the City Council and to represent to prospective purchasers of
real estate or other developers that said recommendation would be made on their
behalf.
   (D)   Commercial Development and Redevelopment: The commission is to promote
and actively seek respectable businesses which will be an asset to the city of
East Moline. It shall actively participate in improving, developing or
redeveloping all commercial areas so designated by the plan commission of the
city of East Moline.
The commission shall study all requests by businesses that ask for city
participation financially. The commission shall submit to the city council for
consideration a final recommendation, including all supportive details, such as
percentage of city participation, tangible and intangible benefits, and
expected return on investment or value created. Project recommendation shall
include a definition and timeline for commencement of the project.
The commission is to enlist the support of existing businesses in preventing
the deterioration of these areas and ensuring a continual program of upgrading
and renovation. (Ord. 74-64, 12-9-1974; amd. Ord. 19-03, 2-19-2019)
2-19-7: POWERS:
The commission shall have any and all express and implied powers to carry out
the development enumerated in this ordinance, those powers shall include but
are not limited to, the power to allocate accumulate, authorize, reserve and
expand any sums as reasonably necessary. (Ord. 74-64, 12-9-1974; amd. Ord. 19-
03, 2-19-2019)
2-19-8: COOPERATION:
Under the direction of the City Administrator, the commission may call on city
departments for assistance in the performance of its duties, and it shall be
the duty of each city department to render such assistance to the commission as
may be reasonably required. (Ord. 74-64, 12-9-1974; amd. Ord. 19-03, 2-19-2019)
CHAPTER 20
HISTORIC PRESERVATION COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-20-1: Purpose
2-20-2: Composition Of Commission
2-20-3: Qualifications
2-20-4: Terms
2-20-5: Officers
2-20-6: Meetings; Quorum
2-20-7: Powers And Duties
2-20-8: Surveys And Research
2-20-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this Ordinance is to promote the protection, enhancement,
perpetuation, and use of improvement of special character or historical
interest or value in the interest of the health, prosperity, safety, and
welfare of the people of the City of East Moline by:
   (A)   Providing a mechanism to identify and preserve the historic and
architectural characteristics of East Moline which represent elements of the
City's cultural, social, economic, political, and architectural history;
   (B)   Promoting civic pride in the beauty and noble accomplishments of the
past as represented in East Moline's landmarks and historic districts;
   (C)   Stabilizing and improving the economic vitality and value of East
Moline's landmarks and historic areas;
   (D)   Protecting and enhancing the attractiveness of the City to have
buyers, visitors and shoppers and thereby supporting business, commerce,
industry, and providing economic benefit to the City;
   (E)   Fostering and encouraging preservation, restoration of structures,
areas, and neighborhoods and thereby preventing future urban blight. (Ord. 99-
52, 12-6-1999)
2-20-2: COMPOSITION OF COMMISSION:
The East Moline Historic Preservation Commission shall consist of seven (7)
voting members, who shall be residents of the City of East Moline, and to be
appointed by the Mayor and approved by the City Council. (Ord. 99-52, 12-6-
1999)
2-20-3: QUALIFICATIONS:
The members shall be appointed on the basis of expertise, experience or
interest in the area of architectural history, building construction or
engineering, finance, historical and architectural preservation, neighborhood
organizing or real estate. (Ord. 99-52, 12-6-1999)
2-20-4: TERMS:
Members of the Commission shall be appointed for terms of three (3) years. Of
those members first taking office, two (2) shall be appointed for one year,
three (3) for two (2) years, and two (2) for three (3) years. No members shall
serve more than two (2) successive three (3) year terms. Alternate members
shall be appointed to serve in the absence of or disqualification of the
regular members. Vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired term only. Members
shall serve without compensation. (Ord. 99-52, 12-6-1999)
2-20-5: OFFICERS:
Officers shall consist of a chairman, vice chairman, and a secretary elected by
the Preservation Commission who shall serve a term of one year and shall be
eligible for reelection, but no members shall serve as an officer for more than
two (2) consecutive years. The chairman shall preside over meetings. In the
absence of the chairman, the vice chairman shall perform the duties of the
chairman. If both are absent, a temporary chairman shall be elected by those
present. The secretary to the Preservation Commission shall have the following
duties:
   (A)   Take minutes of each Preservation Commission meeting;
   (B)   Be responsible for publication and distribution of copies of the
minutes, reports, and decisions of the Preservation Commission to the members
of the Preservation Commission;
   (C)   Give notice as provided herein or by law for all public hearings
conducted by the Preservation Commission;
   (D)   Advise the Mayor of vacancies on the Preservation Commission and
expiring terms of members; and
   (E)   Prepare and submit to the City Council a complete record of the
proceedings before the Preservation Commission on any matter requiring Council
consideration. (Ord. 99-52, 12-6-1999)
2-20-6: MEETINGS; QUORUM:
A quorum shall consist of a majority of the members. All decisions or actions
of the Historic Preservation Commission shall be made by a majority vote of
those members present and voting at any meeting where a quorum exists. Meetings
shall be held at regularly scheduled times to be established by resolution of
the Commission at the beginning of each calendar year or at any time upon the
call of the chairman. There shall be a minimum of four (4) meetings per year.
No member of the Historic Preservation Commission shall vote on any matter that
may materially or apparently affect the property, income or business interest
of that member. No action shall be taken by the Commission that could in any
manner deprive or restrict the owner of property in its use, modification,
maintenance disposition, or demolition until such owner shall first have had
the opportunity to be heard at a public meeting of the Preservation Commission,
as provided herein. The chairman, and in his absence the acting chairman, may
administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses. All meetings of the
Preservation Commission shall be open to the public. The Preservation
Commission keeps minutes of its proceedings, showing the vote, indicating such
fact, and shall keep records of its examinations and other official actions,
all of which shall be immediately filed in the office of the Preservation
Commission and shall be a public record. (Ord. 99-52, 12-6-1999)
2-20-7: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   (A)   To adopt its own procedural regulations;
   (B)   To conduct an ongoing survey to identify historically and
architecturally significant properties, structures and areas;
   (C)   To investigate and recommend to the City Council to adopt procedures
to protect properties or structures having special historic, community, or
architectural value;
   (D)   To determine an appropriate system of markers and make recommendations
for the design and implementation of specific markings of properties or
structures which have special historic, community, or architectural value;
   (E)   To advise property owners on physical and financial aspects of
preservation, renovation, rehabilitation, and reuse, and on procedures for
inclusion on the State or National Register of Historic Places;
   (F)   To inform and educate the citizens of East Moline concerning the
historic and architectural heritage of the City by publishing appropriate maps,
newsletters, brochures, and pamphlets, and by holding programs and seminars;
   (G)   To accept and administer on behalf of the City of East Moline, upon
designation by the City Council, such gifts, grants and money as may be
appropriate for the purpose of this Ordinance;
   (H)   To call upon available City staff members, as well as other experts
for technical advice;
   (I)   To testify before all boards and commissions, including the City
Planning Commission and the Zoning Board of Appeals, on any matter affecting
historically and architecturally significant properties;
   (J)   To periodically review the East Moline Zoning Ordinance and to
recommend to the City Planning Commission and the City Council any amendments
appropriate for the protection and continued use of historically or
architecturally significant properties. (Ord. 99-52, 12-6-1999)
2-20-8: SURVEYS AND RESEARCH:
The Historic Preservation Commission shall undertake an ongoing survey and
research effort in the City of East Moline to identify neighborhoods, areas,
sites, structures, and objects that have historic, community, architectural, or
aesthetic importance, interest, or value. As part of the survey, the Historic
Preservation Commission shall review and evaluate any prior surveys and studies
by any unit of government or private organization and compile appropriate
descriptions, facts, and photographs. The Historic Preservation Commission
shall identify significant structures based upon the following criteria:
   (A)   Architecturally or historically significant properties in one
identifiable neighborhood or district geographical area of the City of East
Moline;
   (B)   Association with a particular person, event, or historical period;
   (C)   Representation of a particular architectural style or school, or of a
particular architect, engineer, builder, designer or craftsman;
   (D)   Such other criteria as may be adopted by the Preservation Commission
to assure systematic survey of all significant properties within the City of
East Moline. (Ord. 99-52, 12-6-1999)
CHAPTER 21
PATHWAY PRIORITIES PROJECT COMMITTEE
SECTION:
2-21-1: Creation And Membership
2-21-2: Term Of Office
2-21-3: Meetings
2-21-4: Purpose, Powers And Duties
2-21-1: CREATION AND MEMBERSHIP:
There is hereby established a committee to be known as the pathway priorities
project committee, consisting of nine (9) members, to be appointed by the
mayor, with the advice and consent of the city council. The members should be
appointed from any of the following groups:
City of East Moline residents.
Employees or officers of school district 37.
Employees or officers of school district 34.
Employees or officers of school district 30 (UTHS).
Bistate regional commission.
Community Not For Profit Health And Wellness Organization.
East Moline business owner or representative.
One member of the committee shall be appointed from the city of East Moline
engineering department.
The members shall be selected and appointed on the basis of interest in the
area of pedestrian sidewalk and trail projects, transportation planning,
education, public safety, engineering and architectural principles.
The members shall serve without compensation, but may be reimbursed for any
personal expense incurred in the performance of their duties, subject to prior
approval of the city council.
The chairman of the committee shall be elected annually by a majority vote of
the committee. The chairman shall annually appoint a recording secretary. (Ord.
11-01, 1-18-2011)
2-21-2: TERM OF OFFICE:
Each member shall serve a term of three (3) years, with the initial
appointments being for staggered terms of one, two (2) and three (3) years
each. In the event no reappointment or replacement has been made by the mayor
and city council at the end of the expiring terms, members shall continue on
said committee until such time as a reappointment or replacement has been made
by the mayor, by and with the consent of the city council. (Ord. 11-01, 1-18-
2011)
2-21-3: MEETINGS:
The committee shall meet monthly at city hall or at a place designated by the
chairman. All meetings shall be open to the public and held in accordance with
the Illinois open meetings act. (Ord. 11-01, 1-18-2011)
2-21-4: PURPOSE, POWERS AND DUTIES:
The purpose of the committee is to create a healthier and safer East Moline
through promotion of multimodel transportation.
The committee will plan and implement concepts and projects which promote, but
are not limited to:
Bicycle networks and routes.
"Complete streets".
Interconnection of pedestrian, bicycle, transit and vehicle routes as part of
the intermodal and "multimodel" transportation system.
Interconnection of trails and networks to other cities and counties.
Pedestrian and bicycle bridges.
Pedestrian pathways.
Promote plans and concepts to interconnect with other forms of transportation
including, but not limited to, school and public bus routes, water taxi
facilities, rail terminals and airport terminals.
Safe routes to schools.
Shared use trails.
Sidewalks.
The committee shall cooperate and interact with:
Activate quad cities.
Bistate regional commission/Bistate trails committee.
Illinois department of transportation.
Illinois safe routes to school programs.
League Of American Bicyclists.
League Of Illinois Bicyclists.
Quad Cities Bicycle Club.
Quad cities transportation advocacy group.
River Action, Inc.
and other appropriate organizations. (Ord. 11-01, 1-18-2011)
CHAPTER 22
ADMINISTRATIVE HEARINGS FOR PSEBA
SECTION:
2-22-1: Purpose
2-22-2: Administrative Composition
2-22-3: Procedure
2-22-4: Administrative Hearing
2-22-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to provide a fair and efficient method of
determining the eligibility of an employee for the benefits enumerated under
the Public Safety Employee Benefits Act (820 ILCS 320/1 et seq.) through the
process of an administrative hearing. All benefits provided employees pursuant
to the Public Safety Employees Benefits Act will be consistent with the Act.
(Ord. 18-19, 11-19-2018)
2-22-2: ADMINISTRATIVE COMPOSITION:
The system of the administrative hearing shall be comprised of a hearing
officer whose power, authority and limitations are as follows:
   (A)   Power of the Hearing Officer: The hearing officer shall have all of
the powers granted to them under common law relative to the conduct of an
administrative hearing including the power to:
      1.   Preside over all City hearings involving the Public Safety Employee
Benefits Act (820ILCS 320/1 et seq.).
      2.   Administer oaths.
      3.   Hear testimony and accept evidence that is relevant to the issue of
eligibility under the Public Safety Employee Benefits Act (820 ILCS 320/1 et
seq.).
      4.   Issue subpoenas to secure attendance of witnesses and the production
or relevant papers or documents upon the request of the parties or their
representatives.
      5.   Rule upon the objections in the admissibility of evidence.
      6.   Preserve and authenticate the record of the hearing and all exhibits
in evidence introduced at the hearing.
      7.   Issue a determination based on the evidence presented at the
hearing, the determination of which shall be in writing and shall include a
written finding of fact, decision and order.
   (B)   Hearing Officer The Mayor with the consent of the City Council, is
hereby authorized to appoint a person to hold the position of a hearing officer
for each and every individual hearing that shall come before this village. In
making said selection, the Mayor shall consider all pertinent information
including, at a minimum:
      1.   The candidate’s ability to comply with the job description as set
forth herein.
      2.   Background and performance data made available to the Mayor on file
with the City or otherwise obtained by the City.
      3.   The candidate must be an attorney licensed to practice in the State
of Illinois for at least three (3) years and have a knowledge of and experience
in employment and labor law, general civil procedure, the rule of evidence and
administrative practice. (Ord. 18-19, 11-19-2018)
2-22-3: PROCEDURE:
The system of administrative hearing for determination of eligibility for
benefits tinder the Public Safety Employee Benefits Act (820ILCS 320/1 et seq.)
shall be initiated by the serving of a written notice on the City Clerk by any
public safety employee stating in foil detail the nature of the employee’s
claim giving foil particulars thereof, i.e. date, time, place, nature of injury
and any other factual circumstances surrounding said incident giving rise to
said claim; requesting the benefits enumerated under the Public Safety Employee
Benefits Act (820 ILCS 320/1 et seq.) and requesting the setting of a hearing
for the eligibility to receive said benefits. (Ord. 18-19, 11-19-2018)
2-22-4: ADMINISTRATIVE HEARING:
An administrative hearing shall be held to adjudicate and determine whether the
subject public safety employee is eligible for benefits under the Public Safety
Employee Benefits Act (820 ILCS 320/1 et seq.). If the employee is found
eligible, the employee benefits shall be consistent with the Act.
   (A)   Time and Date: Hearings shall be held on the date, time and place and
established by the City with appropriate notice served up the public safety
employee.
   (B)   Record: All hearings shall be attended by a certified court reporter
and a transcript of all proceedings shall be made by said certified court
reporter.
   (C)   Procedures: The City and foe petitioning public safety employee shall
be entitled to representation by counsel at said hearing and may present
witnesses, may present testimony and documents, may cross-examine opposing
witnesses and may request foe issuance of subpoenas to compel the appearance of
relevant witnesses or foe production of relevant documents.
   (D)   Evidence: The rules of evidence as set forth in the Illinois Code of
Evidence shall apply.
   (E)   Final Determination: The determination by foe hearing officer of
whether foe petitioning public safety employee is eligible for the benefits
under the Public Safety Employee Benefits Act (820 ILCS 320/1 et seq.) shall
constitute a final determination for foe purpose of judicial review under foe
common law writ of certiorari. (Ord. 18-19, 11-19-2018)
TITLE 3
BUSINESS REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
LICENSES AND PERMITS
SECTION:
3-1-1: Applications
3-1-2: Subject To License
3-1-3: License Year
3-1-4: Forms
3-1-5: Signatures
3-1-6: Investigation
3-1-7: Fees
3-1-8: Termination Of Licenses
3-1-9: Building And Premises
3-1-10: Change Of Location
3-1-11: Nuisances
3-1-12: Revocation
3-1-13: Posting License
3-1-14: Vehicle Tag
3-1-15: Penalty For Late Payment
3-1-1: APPLICATIONS:
Applications for all licenses and permits required by this code shall be made,
in writing, to the city clerk in the absence of provision to the contrary. Each
application shall state the name of the applicant, the permit or license
desired, the location to be used, if any, the time covered and the fee to be
paid; and each application shall contain such additional information as may be
needed for the proper guidance of the city officials in the issuing of the
permit or license applied for. (1962 Code § 21.001)
3-1-2: SUBJECT TO LICENSE:
Whenever in this code a license is required for the maintenance, operation or
conduct of any business or establishment, or for doing business or engaging in
any activity or occupation, any person shall be subject to the requirement if
by himself or through an agent, employee or partner, he holds himself forth as
being engaged in the business or occupation; or solicits patronage therefor,
actively or passively; or performs or attempts to perform any part of such
business or occupation in the city. (1962 Code § 21.002)
3-1-3: LICENSE YEAR:
The license year for the city shall begin on May 1 and end on April 30 of each
year, except as otherwise set forth. (1962 Code § 21.003; amd. 1974 Code)
3-1-4: FORMS:
Forms for all licenses and permits, and applications therefor, shall be
prepared and kept on file by the city clerk. (1962 Code § 21.004)
3-1-5: SIGNATURES:
Each license or permit issued shall bear the signatures of the mayor and the
city clerk in the absence of any provision to the contrary. (1962 Code §
21.005)
3-1-6: INVESTIGATION:
Upon the receipt of an application for a license or permit, where provisions of
this code necessitate an inspection or investigation before the issuance of
such permit or license, the city clerk shall refer such application to the
proper officer for making such investigation within forty eight (48) hours of
the time of such receipt. The officer charged with the duty of making the
investigation or inspection shall make a report thereon, favorable or
otherwise, within ten (10) days after receiving the applications or a copy
thereof. The health inspector shall make or cause to be made an inspection in
regard to such license in the connection of the care and handling of food and
the preventing of nuisances and the spread of disease, for the protection of
health; the building inspector shall make or cause to be made any such
inspections relative to the construction of buildings or other structures. All
other investigations except where otherwise provided, shall be made by the
chief of police or by some other officer designated by the mayor and council.
(1962 Code § 21.006)
3-1-7: FEES:
In the absence of provision to the contrary, all fees and charges for licenses
or permits shall be paid in advance at the time application therefor is made to
the city clerk. Except as otherwise provided, all license fees shall become a
part of the corporate fund.
There will be a ten dollar ($10.00) fee for each duplicate copy of the license
requested.
There will be a fifty dollar ($50.00) fee for each license that must be
reprocessed due to incorrect business information submitted to the city on the
initial application. (Ord. 15-03, 8-17-2015)
3-1-8: TERMINATION OF LICENSES:
All annual licenses shall terminate on December 31, where no provision to the
contrary is made.
The City Clerk shall mail to all licensees of the City a statement of the time
of expiration of the license held by the licensees, if an annual, three (3)
weeks prior to the date of such expiration. Provided, that a failure to send
out such notice, or the failure of the licensee to receive it shall not excuse
the licensee from a failure to obtain a new license, or a renewal thereof, nor
shall it be a defense in an action for operation without a license. (1962 Code
§ 21.008; amd. Ord. 20-13, 7-20-2020)
3-1-9: BUILDING AND PREMISES:
No license shall be issued for the conduct of any business, and no permit shall
be issued for any thing, or act, if the premises and building to be used for
the purpose do not fully comply with the requirements of this code. No such
license or permit shall be issued for the conduct of any business or
performance of any act which would involve a violation of the zoning title
(title 10 of this code). (1962 Code § 21.009)
3-1-10: CHANGE OF LOCATION:
The location of any licensed business or occupation, or of any permitted act,
may be changed, provided ten (10) days' notice thereof is given to the city
clerk, in the absence of any provision to the contrary; provided, that the
building and zoning requirements of this code are complied with. (1962 Code §
21.010)
3-1-11: NUISANCES:
No business, licensed or not, shall be so used for or in connection with the
operation of another licensed business or occupation unless provided for or
required by ordinance when said business is detrimental and a nuisance to the
general public. It shall be the duty of the licensee, or the person in charge
of the premises to be inspected, to admit thereto for the purpose of making the
inspection any officer or employee of the city who is authorized or directed to
make such inspection at any reasonable time that admission is requested.
Whenever an analysis of any commodity or material is reasonably necessary to
secure conformance with any code provision or to detect violations thereof, it
shall be the duty of the licensee of the municipality whose business is
governed by such provision to give to any authorized officer or employee of the
city requesting the same sufficient samples of such material or commodity for
such analysis upon request.
In addition to any other penalty which may be provided, the mayor may revoke
the license of any licensed proprietor of any licensed business in the city who
refuses to permit any such officer or employee who is authorized to make such
inspection or take such samples to make the inspection, or take an adequate
sample of the said commodity, or who interferes with such officer or employee
while in the performance of his duty in making such inspection. Provided, that
no license shall be revoked for such cause unless written demand is made upon
the licensee or person in charge of the premises, in the name of the city,
stating that such inspection or sample is desired at the time it is sought to
make the inspection or obtain the sample. (1962 Code § 21.011)
3-1-12: REVOCATION:
Any license or permit for a limited time may be revoked by the city council at
any time during the life of such license or permit for any violation by the
licensee or permittee of the code provisions relating to the license or permit,
the subject matter of the license or permit, or to the premises occupied; such
revocation may be in addition to any fine imposed. (1962 Code § 21.012)
3-1-13: POSTING LICENSE:
It shall be the duty of any person conducting a licensed business in the city
to keep his license posted in a prominent place on the premises used for such
business at all times. (1962 Code § 21.013)
3-1-14: VEHICLE TAG:
Whenever the number of vehicles used in the basis of a license fee, the city
clerk shall furnish each licensee with a license for each vehicle covered by
the license fee, and such license shall be posted in a conspicuous place on
each such vehicle while it is in use. (1962 Code § 21.014; amd. 1974 Code)
3-1-15: PENALTY FOR LATE PAYMENT:
In the event that any payment for any type of license or permit to be issued by
the city of East Moline is made after the date for payment, the following
penalties shall be added to the amount of the license or permit fee:
   (A)   Any payment in excess of fifteen (15) days past the due date shall
bear a penalty of twelve percent (12%).
   (B)   Any payment in excess of forty five (45) days past the due date shall
bear a penalty of twenty five percent (25%). (Ord. 75-59, 12-15-1975)
CHAPTER 2
AMBULANCES
SECTION:
3-2-1: License Required
3-2-2: Definition
3-2-3: Requirements Of Applicant
3-2-4: Fee
3-2-5: Vehicles
3-2-6: Register
3-2-7: Drivers
3-2-8: Insurance
3-2-9: Traffic Rules
3-2-10: Unlawful Use
3-2-11: Destinations
3-2-12: Driver's License Required
3-2-13: Driver's License Fee
3-2-14: Qualifications
3-2-15: Penalty
3-2-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to engage in the business of operating an ambulance in the
City without having first secured a license therefor. Application for such
licenses shall be made in writing to the Clerk, and shall state thereon the
name of the applicant, the intended place of business and the number of
ambulances to be operated. If the applicant is a corporation, the names and
addresses of the president and secretary thereof shall be given. (Ord. 73-39,
10-15-1973)
3-2-2: DEFINITION:
The term "ambulance" as used in this Chapter shall mean and include an
especially equipped motor vehicle to be used as an emergency unit for carrying
the sick and injured. (Ord. 73-39, 10-15-1973)
3-2-3: REQUIREMENTS OF APPLICANT:
No such license shall be issued to or held by any person or corporation who has
less than two (2) ambulances, and no more than six (6) firms shall be so
licensed. (Ord. 73-39, 10-15-1973)
3-2-4: FEE:
The annual fee for such license shall be ten dollars ($10.00) per ambulance.
Whenever the number of ambulances so operated shall be increased during the
license year, the licensee shall notify the Clerk of such change and shall pay
the additional fee.
Such fee shall be in lieu of any other vehicle fee required by ordinance and
the Clerk shall issue suitable tags or stickers for the number of ambulances
covered by each license. Such tag or sticker shall be displayed in a prominent
place on each ambulance while it is in use, and may be transferred to any
ambulance put into service to replace one withdrawn from service.
The licensee shall notify the Clerk of the motor number and State license
number of each ambulance operated and of the corresponding Municipal tag or
sticker number. (Ord. 73-39, 10-15-1973)
3-2-5: VEHICLES:
No ambulance shall be operated unless it bears a State license duly issued; and
no such ambulance shall be operated unless it is equipped with a siren
producing an audible signal of an intensity of one hundred (100) decibels at a
distance of fifty feet (50') from said siren, and with a lamp emitting an
oscillating, rotating or flashing red beam directed in part toward the front of
the vehicle and containing a power rating of at least one hundred (100) amps,
with the aforesaid siren and lamp in full operation at all times during such
trip or journey. It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to inspect every
ambulance so often as may be necessary to see to the enforcement of the
provisions of this Section. Each ambulance, while operated, shall have on each
side in letters readable from a distance of twenty feet (20') the name of the
licensee operating it. If more than one ambulance is operated by the licensee,
each ambulance shall be designated by a different number, and such number shall
also appear on each side of the ambulance. (Ord. 73-39, 10-15-1973)
3-2-6: REGISTER:
It shall be the duty of the City Clerk to keep a register of the names of
persons to whom such license is granted or transferred, the date when issued or
transferred, the number of the license and the description of the vehicle or
vehicles licensed. (Ord. 73-39, 10-15-1973)
3-2-7: DRIVERS:
No person shall drive an ambulance or be hired or permitted to do so unless he
has passed the qualifications established by statute. (Ord. 73-39, 10-15-1973)
3-2-8: INSURANCE:
No ambulance shall be operated unless it is covered by a bond or public
liability policy as required by statute. (Ord. 73-39, 10-15-1973)
3-2-9: TRAFFIC RULES:
It shall be the duty of every driver of an ambulance to obey all traffic rules
established by statute or ordinance with the following exceptions: when the
ambulance is being used in response to an emergency situation, and the same is
operated at a speed in excess of forty (40) miles per hour and directed to
disregard traffic laws for the purpose of a specific trip, the ambulance shall
be operated in complete conformance with every other motor vehicle law and
regulation by statute or ordinance in which ambulances are operated, relating
to the operation of motor vehicles, as such provision applies to motor vehicles
in general, except laws and regulations pertaining to compliance with official
traffic-control devices or to vehicular operation upon the right half of the
roadway. (Ord. 73-39, 10-15-1973)
3-2-10: UNLAWFUL USE:
It shall be unlawful to knowingly permit any ambulance to be used in the
perpetuation of a crime or misdemeanor. (Ord. 73-39, 10-15-1973)
3-2-11: DESTINATIONS:
Ambulance operators shall deliver the sick or injured to any hospital in the
County of Rock Island, State of Illinois. (Ord. 73-39, 10-15-1973)
3-2-12: DRIVER'S LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall drive an ambulance unless he shall have secured a license
therefor as herein provided. (Ord. 73-39, 10-15-1973)
3-2-13: DRIVER'S LICENSE FEE:
The fee for an ambulance driver's license shall be five dollars ($5.00) per
year. (Ord. 73-39, 10-15-1973)
3-2-14: QUALIFICATIONS:
No such license shall be issued to any person who is not competent to operate a
motor vehicle or who is not familiar with the traffic laws and ordinances. The
Chief of Police shall examine each applicant for an ambulance driver's license
to determine the competency of the applicant, and no such license shall be
issued excepting on certificate of the Chief that the applicant has
demonstrated his ability to operate a motor vehicle as required herein. (Ord.
73-39, 10-15-1973)
3-2-15: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this Chapter shall
be fined not less than one dollar ($1.00) nor more than one hundred dollars
($100.00) for each offense; and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on
each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 73-39, 10-
15-1973)
CHAPTER 3
PLACES FOR AMUSEMENT
SECTION:
3-3-1: Definitions
3-3-2: License Required
3-3-3: Application
3-3-4: Inspection
3-3-5: License Fees
3-3-6: Display Of License
3-3-7: Prohibitions And Restrictions
3-3-8: Revocation Of License
3-3-9: Seizure And Destruction Of Machine
3-3-10: Penalty
3-3-11: Separability Of Provisions
3-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context otherwise requires, the following terms as used in this
Chapter shall be construed according to the definitions given below:
MECHANICAL AMUSEMENT DEVICE: Any machine, which, upon the insertion of a coin,
slug, token, plat or disc or by any other means of consideration, may be
operated by the public generally for use as a game, entertainment or amusement,
whether or not registering a score. It shall include such devices as foosball
machines, electronic game machines, marble machines, pinball machines, skill
ball, mechanical grab machines and all games, operations or transactions
similar thereto under whatever name they may be indicated.
PERSON, FIRM, CORPORATION, OR ASSOCIATION: Any person, firm, corporation or
association which owns any such machine; the person, firm, corporation or
association in whose place of business any such machine is placed for use by
the public; and the person, firm, corporation or association having control
over such machine; provided, however, that the payment of such fee by any
person, firm, corporation or association enumerated herein shall be deemed a
compliance with this Section of the Ordinance.
PLACES FOR AMUSEMENT: Any public place kept, used, maintained, advertised and
held out to the public to be a place primarily for the offering of games of
amusement, or amusement devices, including the following: billiard, pool or
bagatelle or pigeon hole table; any mechanical amusement device. (Ord. 92-27,
7-6-1992)
3-3-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
Any person, firm, corporation or association operating a place of amusement as
herein defined by Section
3-3-1 of this Chapter, shall be required to obtain a license from the City of
East Moline, upon payment of a license fee. Application for such license shall
be made to the City Clerk upon a form to be supplied by the City Clerk for that
purpose by January 1 of each year. The license year shall be from January 1 to
December 31.
Any person, firm, corporation or association, not constituting a place for
amusement as defined herein, and operating a non-coin operated mechanical
amusement device, shall be required to obtain a license from the City of East
Moline, upon payment of a license fee. Application for such license shall be
made to the City Clerk for the purpose by January 1 of each year. The license
year shall be from January 1 to December 31. (Ord. 92-27, 7-6-1992; amd. Ord.
20-13, 7-20-2020)
3-3-3: APPLICATION:
The application for such license shall contain the following information:
   (A)   Name and address of applicant, age, date and place of birth;
   (B)   Prior convictions of applicant, if any;
   (C)   Location where place of amusement is to be operated; and
   (D)   Number and description of tables, machines or devices for which the
licensee is requesting authorization for the operation of, including mechanical
features, name of manufacturer and serial number.
No license shall be issued to any individual applicant unless he shall be over
twenty one (21) years of age and a citizen of the United States. (Ord. 76-15,
4-19-1976)
3-3-4: INSPECTION:
Application for license shall be made out in duplicate, one copy being referred
to the Chief of Police and the other copy to the City Electrical Inspector.
   (A)   The Chief of Police shall investigate the location wherein it is
proposed to operate such place of amusement, ascertain if the applicant is a
person of good moral character, and either approve or disapprove the
application.
   (B)   The Electrical Inspector shall inspect all wiring required for
amusement, determine if the same complies with the Electrical Code of the City
of East Moline, and shall either approve or disapprove the application.
   (C)   No license shall be issued to any applicant unless approved by the
Chief of Police and the Electrical Inspector. (Ord. 76-15, 4-19-1976)
3-3-5: LICENSE FEES:
Every applicant, before being granted a license shall pay an annual license fee
in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the privilege of operating
or maintaining for operation the place of amusement. (Ord. 81-73, 12-21-1981)
3-3-6: DISPLAY OF LICENSE:
   (A)   The license herein provided for shall be posted permanently and
conspicuously at the location of the premises.
   (B)   If the licensee shall move his place of business to another location
within the City of East Moline, the license may be transferred to such new
location upon application to the City Clerk, giving the street and number of
the new location. The new location shall be approved by the Chief of Police and
City Electrical Inspector in the same manner as provided in Section
3-3-4 of this Chapter. (Ord. 76-15, 4-19-1976)
3-3-7: PROHIBITIONS AND RESTRICTIONS:
   (A)   No person, firm, corporation or association holding a license under
this Ordinance shall permit persons under sixteen (16) years of age to
frequent, loiter, go or remain in any place of amusement licensed hereunder at
any time, unless accompanied by a parent or legal guardian.
      No person under the age of sixteen (16) years of age shall frequent,
loiter, go or remain in any place of amusement at any time, unless accompanied
by a parent or legal guardian. (Ord. 81-39, 5-4-1981)
   (B)   No person, firm, corporation or association holding a license under
this Ordinance shall permit any patron to bring onto the licensed premises or
possess any firearms or weapons on the premises, any alcohol or any beverage
containing alcohol, or any cannabis or controlled substance, as defined in the
Cannabis Control Act 1 . (Ord. 93-3, 2-1-1993)
   (C)   No person, firm, corporation or association holding a license under
this Ordinance shall permit patrons of such establishment to loiter outside of
the establishment so as to: 1) create a danger of a breach of the peace, 2)
create a disturbance or annoyance to the comfort and repose of any person, 3)
obstruct the free passage of pedestrians or vehicles, or 4) obstruct, molest or
interfere with any person lawfully in any public place. It shall be the burden
of the licensee to advise his patrons that any person loitering will not be
readmitted to such establishment.
   (D)   No person, firm, corporation or association shall permit any patrons
of such licensed establishment to remain on the premises if said patron has
caused a disturbance or engaged in disorderly conduct.
   (E)   It shall be unlawful to keep open for business any place for amusement
licensed hereunder between: 1) the hours of ten thirty o'clock (10:30) P.M.,
Sunday through Thursday, and nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. the following day; 2) the
hours of eleven thirty o'clock (11:30) P.M., Friday and Saturday and nine
o'clock (9:00) A.M., Saturday and twelve o'clock (12:00) noon on Sunday. (Ord.
76-15, 4-19-1976)
 
Notes
1 1. 720 ILCS 550/1 et seq.
3-3-8: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
Every license issued under this Ordinance is subject to the right, which is
hereby expressly reserved, to revoke the same should the licensee, directly or
indirectly, operate its place for amusement contrary to the provisions of this
Ordinance, the ordinances of the City of East Moline, or the law of the State
of Illinois. Said license may be revoked by the Mayor for written notice to the
licensee which notice shall specify the ordinance or law violations with which
the licensee is charged, if after a hearing the licensee is found to be guilty
of such violations. Ten (10) days' notice of the hearing shall be given the
licensee. At such hearing the licensee and his attorney may present and submit
evidence of witnesses in his defense. (Ord. 76-15, 4-19-1976)
3-3-9: SEIZURE AND DESTRUCTION OF MACHINE:
If the Chief of Police shall have reason to believe any mechanical amusement
device is a gambling device, per se, such machine may be seized by the police
and impounded and if upon trial of the exhibitor for allowing it to be used as
a gambling device said exhibitor be found guilty, such machine shall be
destroyed by the police. (Ord. 76-15, 4-19-1976)
3-3-10: PENALTY:
Any person, firm, corporation or association violating any of the provisions of
this Ordinance, in addition to the revocation of his or its license, shall be
liable to a fine or penalty of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more
than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. (Ord. 81-39, 5-4-1981)
3-3-11: SEPARABILITY OF PROVISIONS:
It is the intention of the City Council that each separate provision of this
Ordinance shall be deemed independent of all other provisions herein, and it is
further the intention of the City Council that if any provision of this
Ordinance be declared invalid, all other provisions thereof shall remain valid
and enforceable. (Ord. 76-15, 4-19-1976)
CHAPTER 4
COIN OPERATED DEVICES
SECTION:
3-4-1: Amusement Devices
3-4-2: Music Devices
3-4-3: Video Gaming Terminals
3-4-1: AMUSEMENT DEVICES:
   (A)   License Required: No person shall place or install, or maintain or
operate in any building or place within the city any mechanical or electrical
amusement devices, including amusement devices for use by the public and for
which a fee is charged, without first having obtained a license for each place
or location where such mechanical or electrical amusement device shall be
installed, maintained or operated. (Ord. 78-27, 6-19-1978)
   (B)   Application: Any person desiring the license required in and by this
section shall make application for that purpose to the city clerk, which
application shall set forth the full name of the applicant and his address, the
location and character of the building or place where such mechanical coin
controlled amusement devices are to be located, maintained and operated, the
number of such devices to be located, maintained and operated in such building
or place, and the charge to be made to the customer for operating each of such
devices. (1962 Code § 22.302)
   (C)   License Fee: The annual license fee for the privilege of placing,
installing, or maintaining mechanical or electrical amusement devices in any
building or place within the city for use by the public and for which a fee is
charged shall be forty dollars ($40.00), and shall be paid by the operator of
the building or public place.
   (D)   License Year: The license year for the city shall begin on January 1
and end on December 31 of each year, except as otherwise set forth.
   (E)   Minors: It shall be unlawful to permit any person under sixteen (16)
years of age to play or operate any coin operated pinball machine.
(1962 Code § 22.302; amd. Ord. 78-27, 6-19-1978; Ord. 81-72, 12-21-1981; Ord.
92-26, 7-6-1992; Ord. 20-13, 7-20-2020)
3-4-2: MUSIC DEVICES:
   (A)   Definition: The term "coin operated music device" shall mean any
phonograph, piano player, music box, "jukebox" or other instrument or device
capable of producing or reproducing any vocal or instrumental sounds, other
than a motion picture sound machine, which is governed or controlled by the
deposit of a coin or token. (1962 Code § 22.401)
   (B)   License Required: No person shall keep, or permit to be kept, for gain
or profit from operation within the city, any coin operated musical device
without first having obtained a license as herein provided. (1962 Code §
22.402)
   (C)   Application: Application for said license shall be made to the city
clerk, in conformity with chapter 1 of this title, except as otherwise herein
provided. In addition, the applicant shall set forth the description of the
coin operated musical device or devices intended to be kept for use on his
premises. (1962 Code § 22.403)
   (D)   Issuance: No such license shall be issued to any person unless such
person is the owner or proprietor of the premises in which such coin operated
musical device is to be installed. (1962 Code § 22.404)
   (E)   License Fee; Terms Of License: The annual license fee for the
privilege of keeping, or permitting to be kept, for gain or profit from
operation, any "coin operated music device" within the city, shall be forty
dollars ($40.00), and shall be paid by the applicant. (Ord. 81-72, 12-21-1981)
   (F)   Transfer Of License: No license issued to any person shall be
transferable. (1962 Code § 22.406)
   (G)   Regulations: No license issued hereunder shall permit the operation of
any coin operated musical instrument at any place or in any manner which will
disturb the peace and quiet of persons outside the licensed premises. (1962
Code § 22.407; amd. 1974 Code)
3-4-3: VIDEO GAMING TERMINALS:
   (A)   License Required: No person shall place or install, or maintain or
operate in any building or place within the city any coin operated video gaming
terminal, as authorized by the Illinois state legislature by adoption of the
video gaming act, 230 Illinois Compiled Statutes 40/1 through 85, for use by
the public and for which a fee is charged, without first having obtained a
license for each place or location where such video gaming terminal shall be
installed, maintained or operated.
   (B)   Application: Any person desiring the license required in and by this
section shall make application for that purpose to the city clerk, which
application shall set forth the full name and address of the applicant, the
location and character of the building or place where such coin operated video
gaming terminals are to be located, maintained and operated, the number of such
video gaming terminals to be located, maintained and operated in such building
or place, and the charge to be made to the customer for operating each of such
video gaming terminals.
   (C)   License Fee: The annual license fee for the privilege of placing,
installing or maintaining each coin operated video gaming terminal, as
authorized and licensed by the Illinois gaming board, in any building or place
within the city for use by the public and for which an operational fee is
charged for such use shall be one-hundred twenty five dollars ($125.00) per
terminal for the 2024 calendar year and two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per
terminal annually thereafter, and shall be paid to the city by the operator of
the building or public place. The annual license fee for each coin operated
video gaming terminal shall be prorated for any proportional period of the
license year term, as said term is set forth in subsection (D) of this section.
   (D)   License Year: Due to the global health emergency in 2020 and the
restrictions on restaurants and taverns, the majority of video gaming license
holders have been significantly affected by the Governor’s Executive Order.
Consequently, existing licenses set to expire April 30, 2020 are extended to
June 30, 2020. For 2020 video gaming license renewals only, video gaming
licenses are reduced to a half-year (six month) license with a revised fee of
50% of the annual fee. The six-month license fee will be due by July 31, 2020.
Renewals of video gaining licenses for 2020 will be valid from July 1 to
December 31. New video gaming licenses will be paid on a pro-rata basis
according to the time left in the remainder of the calendar year. This six-
month license will expire on December 31, 2020 at which time the regular annual
fee will be due for the license valid for year 2021. License renewals in 2021
and thereafter will follow the calendar year. License holders that have already
paid their 12-month video gaming license renewal fee will be provided a credit
for the amount paid in excess of the six-month fees for 2020 which shall be
applied to the 2021 renewal.
   The license year for the City shall begin on January 1 and end on December
31 of each year, except as otherwise set forth.
   (E)   Minor: It shall be unlawful to permit any person less than twenty one
(21) years of age to play or operate any coin operated video gaming terminal.
   (F)   1.   Video Gaming Terminals located in gas stations within the City
shall be permitted.
      2.   The number of licenses issued shall be limited to twenty (30) store
fronts not including gas stations. (Ord. 13-01, 1-22-2013; amd. Ord. 18-07, 9-
4-2018; Ord. 18-12, 10-1-2018; Ord. 20-13, 7-20-2020; Ord. 23-19, 12-4-2023)
CHAPTER 5
COMMERCIAL AND RESIDENTIAL SCAVENGERS
SECTION:
3-5-1: Definition
3-5-2: License And Bond
3-5-3: Application
3-5-4: Vehicles
3-5-5: Limitation Of Licenses To Be Issued
3-5-6: Disposal
3-5-1: DEFINITION:
The term "commercial and residential scavenger" shall mean any person or firm
engaged in the collection, removal, transportation and disposal of the contents
of any vault, tank or container, whether above or below grade, which consists
of residential garbage or rubbish or commercial garbage or rubbish. (Ord. 69-
25, 5-19-1969)
3-5-2: LICENSE AND BOND:
It shall be unlawful to perform the services of a commercial or residential
scavenger unless duly bonded and licensed. Each commercial and residential
scavenger shall annually give a bond for the sum of one thousand dollars
($1,000.00) to be approved by the Council conditioned to the faithful
performance of services.
License fees and bonds shall be due on May 1 of each year.
The license fee shall be twenty five dollars ($25.00) per year for the first
vehicle and ten dollars ($10.00) per year for each vehicle thereafter. (Ord.
69-25, 5-19-1969)
3-5-3: APPLICATION:
Each application for a license shall be obtained from the City Clerk for each
vehicle utilized, subject to the approval of the applicant therefor by the
Director of Maintenance Services, and in accordance with the provisions of this
Code. Prior to a license being issued, the applicant shall supply the City with
a current list of all his customers in the City. (Ord. 69-25, 5-19-1969; amd.
Ord. 88-1, 1-4-1988)
3-5-4: VEHICLES:
Prior to a license being issued, all vehicles must have been inspected and
certified by the Health Inspector of the City.
Any vehicles used by such commercial and residential scavenger in his business
must be constructed so that garbage and refuse will not be spilled from them;
they shall be watertight and equipped with permanent tops for such portions as
are used for the transportation of refuse and excluding the use of a canvas
top.
Any vehicles used by such commercial and residential scavenger in his business
must be maintained in a clean manner so as to prevent offensive odors or be
classed as a nuisance and drivers and assistants must be neat and clean in
appearance.
Any vehicles used by such commercial and residential scavenger in his business
must be marked with the name of the person owning the vehicle, together with
the number of his license in letters and figures not less than six inches (6")
in height and such lettering shall be placed on a conspicuous portion of the
vehicle so that it can be seen at all times while in use and operation. (Ord.
69-25, 5-19-1969)
3-5-5: LIMITATION OF LICENSES TO BE ISSUED:
There shall be no more than ten (10) commercial and residential scavenger
licenses issued by the City for any one year.
Any license which has not been used for a period of thirty (30) days, without a
just and reasonable cause, shall be subject to repeal by the City Council.
(Ord. 71-25, 5-17-1971)
3-5-6: DISPOSAL:
It shall be unlawful for any commercial and residential scavenger to deposit or
to store any refuse in any place within the City limits or within one mile
thereof, excepting with the permission of the City Council.
All commercial and residential scavengers will be required to comply with
applicable provisions of this Code covering their operation. (Ord. 69-25, 5-19-
1969)
CHAPTER 6
INDUSTRIAL SCAVENGERS
SECTION:
3-6-1: Definition
3-6-2: License And Bond
3-6-3: Application
3-6-4: Vehicles
3-6-5: Limitation Of Licenses; Repeal
3-6-6: Disposal
3-6-1: DEFINITION:
The term "industrial scavenger" shall mean any person or firm engaged in the
collection, removal, transportation and disposal of the contents of any vault,
tank or container, whether above or below grade, which consists of industrial
garbage or industrial rubbish. (Ord. 69-26, 5-19-1969)
3-6-2: LICENSE AND BOND:
It shall be unlawful to perform the services of an industrial scavenger unless
duly bonded and licensed. Each industrial scavenger shall annually give a bond
for the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) to be approved by the City
Council, conditioned to the faithful performance of services. License fees and
bonds shall be due on May 1 of each year.
The license fee shall be twenty five dollars ($25.00) per year for the first
vehicle and ten dollars ($10.00) per year for each vehicle thereafter. (Ord.
69-26, 5-19-1969)
3-6-3: APPLICATION:
Each application for a license shall be obtained from the City Clerk for each
vehicle utilized, subject to the approval of the applicant therefor by the
Director of Maintenance Services, and in accordance with the provisions of this
Code. Prior to a license being issued, the applicant shall supply the City with
a current list of all his customers in the City. (Ord. 69-26, 5-19-1969; amd.
Ord. 88-1, 1-4-1988)
3-6-4: VEHICLES:
Prior to a license being issued, all vehicles must have been inspected and
certified by the Health Inspector of the City.
Any vehicles used by such industrial scavenger in his business must be
constructed so that garbage and refuse will not be spilled from them; they
shall be watertight and equipped with permanent tops for such portions as are
used for the transportation of refuse and excluding the use of a canvas top.
Any vehicles used by such industrial scavenger in his business must be
maintained in a clean manner so as to prevent offensive odors or be classed as
a nuisance and all drivers and assistants must be neat and clean in appearance.
Any vehicles used by such industrial scavenger in his business must be marked
with the name of the person owning the vehicle together with the number of his
license in letters and figures not less than six inches (6") in height, and
such lettering shall be placed on a conspicuous portion of the vehicle so that
it can be seen at all times while in use and operation. (Ord. 69-26, 5-19-1969)
3-6-5: LIMITATION OF LICENSES; REPEAL:
   (A)   There shall be no more than ten (10) industrial scavenger licenses
issued by the City for any one year.
   (B)   Any license which has not been used for a period of thirty (30) days
without just and reasonable cause shall be subject to repeal by the City
Council. (Ord. 71-26, 5-17-1971)
3-6-6: DISPOSAL:
It shall be unlawful for any industrial scavenger to deposit or to store any
refuse in any place within the City limits or within one mile thereof,
excepting with the permission of the City Council.
All industrial scavengers will be required to comply with applicable sections
of this Code covering their operation. (Ord. 69-26, 5-19-1969)
CHAPTER 7
LIQUOR DEALERS
SECTION:
3-7-1: Definitions

3-7-21: Sale To Intoxicated Persons, Habitual Drunkards
3-7-22: Gambling
