                               United States Food and Drug Administration as a
                               non-tobacco product for sale as a tobacco
                               cessation product, as a tobacco dependence
                               product, or for other medical purposes, and is
                               being marketed and sold solely for the approved
                               purpose.
                               Any substance containing tobacco leaf,
TOBACCO PRODUCTS:              including, but not limited to, cigarettes,
                               cigars, pipe tobacco, snuff, chewing tobacco or
                               dipping tobacco.
                               Any mechanical, electric or electronic, self-
                               service device, which, upon insertion of money,
VENDING MACHINE:               tokens or any other form of payment dispenses
                               tobacco products. (Ord. 03-13, 4-21-2003; amd.
                               Ord. 17-09, 4-17-2017)
 
3-21-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale at retail to give away, deliver
or to keep with the intention of selling at retail, giving away or delivering
tobacco products, or alternative nicotine products within the city without
having first obtained a tobacco dealer's license required by this chapter.
(Ord. 03-13, 4-21-2003; amd. Ord. 17-09, 4-17-2017)
3-21-3: LICENSE APPLICATION:
Application for a license hereunder shall be made in writing to the city
clerk's office on forms provided. (Ord. 03-13, 4-21-2003)
3-21-4: LICENSE FEE:
The fee for a tobacco dealer's license will be one hundred dollars ($100.00)
per year, which will be due on May 1 of each year. Every holder of a license
issued pursuant to this chapter shall immediately post and keep posted while in
force, in a conspicuous location on the premises, the license so issued. (Ord.
03-13, 4-21-2003; amd. Ord. 17-09, 4-17-2017)
3-21-5: SIGNS:
Signs informing the public of the age restrictions provided for herein shall be
posted by every licensee at or near every display of tobacco products, or
alternative tobacco products or upon every vending machine, which offers
tobacco products for sale. Each sign shall be plainly visible. (Ord. 03-13, 4-
21-2003; amd. Ord. 17-09, 4-17-2017)
3-21-6: PROHIBITED SALES, DELIVERY AND POSSESSION:
It shall be unlawful for any person, including any licensee, to sell, offer for
sale, give away or deliver tobacco products, or alternative nicotine products
to any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years.
It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years to
purchase tobacco products, or alternative nicotine products, or to misrepresent
his or her identity or age, or to use any false or altered identification for
the purpose of purchasing tobacco products.
It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years to
possess any tobacco products, or alternative nicotine products; unless the
possession by the person under the age of twenty-one (21) years is under the
direct supervision of a parent or guardian of such person and is in the privacy
of the parent's or guardian's home.
No person under sixteen (16) years of age may sell any tobacco products, or
alternative nicotine products at a retail establishment selling tobacco
products, or alternative nicotine products. This does not apply to a sales
clerk in a family-owned business which can prove that the sales clerk is in
fact a son or daughter of the owner.
It shall be unlawful to sell, offer for sale, give away, or display tobacco
products, or alternative nicotine products for sale at any location where the
consumer can acquire those products through self-service. The licensee will
display all products from behind a sales/service counter so that no consumer
can access tobacco products, alternative nicotine products without the
assistance from an employee of the licensee. This restriction shall not apply
to customer self-service from vending machines as described in section 6-3- 49
of this code.
(Ord. 03-13, 4-21-2003; amd. Ord. 17-09, 4-17-2017; Ord. 22-12, 7-18-2022)
3-21-7: FINES, SUSPENSION, REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
The mayor may suspend or revoke any license issued under the provisions of this
chapter, if he determines that the licensee has violated any of the provisions
of this chapter, and may levy a fine on the licensee. The fine imposed shall
not exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each violation. Each day on which
a violation continues shall constitute a separate violation.
However, no such license shall be suspended or revoked and no licensee shall be
fined except after a hearing before the mayor, with not less than ten (10) days
written notice to the licensee affording the licensee an opportunity to appear
before the mayor and defend against the charges contained in such notice.
Every act of omission of whatsoever nature, constituting a violation of any of
the provisions of this chapter by any officer, director, manager or other agent
or employee of any licensee shall be deemed and held to be the act of such
licensee.
Any licensee determined by the mayor to have violated any of the provisions of
this chapter shall in addition to any fine imposed, pay to the city the cost of
the hearing before the mayor on such violation. The mayor shall determine the
cost incurred by the city for said hearing, including, but not limited to:
court reporter fees, the cost of transcripts or records, attorney fees, the
cost of preparing and mailing notices and orders and all other miscellaneous
expenses incurred by the city or such lesser sum as the mayor may allow.
The licensee shall pay said cost to the city within thirty (30) days of
notification of the cost by the mayor. Failure to pay said cost within thirty
(30) days is a violation of this chapter and may be the cause for license
suspension or revocation. (Ord. 03-13, 4-21-2003)
CHAPTER 22
PAWNBROKERS
SECTION:
3-22-1: Definition
3-22-2: License Duration, Fee
3-22-3: Hours Of Business, Location
3-22-4: Register
3-22-5: Time Of Redemption Or Removal Of Pledge
3-22-6: Dealings With Minors
3-22-7: Transactions With Intoxicated Persons Or Thieves
3-22-8: Penalties
3-22-1: DEFINITION:
Any person who lends money on deposit or pledge of personal property, bonds,
notes or other valuable things or securities, or who deals in the purchasing of
personal property on condition of selling the same back again at a stipulated
price, is, for the purposes of this chapter, a "pawnbroker". (Ord. 04-01, 2-2-
2004)
3-22-2: LICENSE DURATION, FEE:
   (A)   No person shall exercise or carry on the business of pawnbroker within
the city of East Moline without being duly licensed, by the city.
   (B)   The city clerk shall grant a pawnbroker's license to any person not
convicted of a felony who may apply, and by paying to the city clerk the sum
required for said license. Said license shall be issued for a period of one
year, from May 1 through April 30. The applicant shall pay, one hundred dollars
($100.00) per year as a license fee. (Ord. 04-01, 2-2-2004)
3-22-3: HOURS OF BUSINESS, LOCATION:
   (A)   No person licensed under this chapter shall receive on deposit or
pledge any personal property or other valuable thing before eight o'clock (8:
00) A.M., or after ten o'clock (10:00) P.M.
   (B)   All pawnbroker business activities shall be conducted only in a
business or industrial zoning district. (Ord. 04-01, 2-2-2004)
3-22-4: REGISTER:
   (A)   Each pawnbroker shall maintain in the English language, a book, or
register in which an accurate account and description shall be made of every
transaction at the time of the transaction, and shall contain the date of pawn,
time of pawn, amount pawned for and article pawned (including serial numbers
where applicable), the name and address and driver's license or state ID card
number of the person pledging or pawning each article, complete description and
thumbprints of the person pledging or pawning each article. No entry made in
such register shall be erased, obliterated, or defaced.
   (B)   The register as well as each article or thing of value pawned or
pledged, shall at all reasonable times, be open to inspection by the East
Moline police department.
   (C)   In addition to being subject to inspection as provided above, each
pawnbroker will deliver to the East Moline police department, by twelve o'clock
(12:00) noon of each day, a copy of the register of the prior day's business,
if applicable. Any failure to deliver the register could be cause for
suspension or revocation of the pawnbroker's license. (Ord. 04-01, 2-2-2004)
3-22-5: TIME OF REDEMPTION OR REMOVAL OF PLEDGE:
No personal property received in deposit or pledge by any person licensed under
this chapter, shall be sold or permitted to be redeemed or removed from the
place of business of such licensed person, for a period of twenty four (24)
hours, after a report as required to be delivered to the chief of police shall
have been so delivered. (Ord. 04-01, 2-2-2004)
3-22-6: DEALINGS WITH MINORS:
   (A)   No person licensed under this chapter shall take or receive in pawn or
purchase any article, property or effects from any minor, or claimed by any
minor.
   (B)   A "minor" shall be defined as a person under eighteen (18) years of
age. (Ord. 04-01, 2-2-2004)
3-22-7: TRANSACTIONS WITH INTOXICATED PERSONS OR THIEVES:
No licensee or person employed by the licensee shall take any article from any
person intoxicated, or from any person known to be convicted of theft, or to
have been convicted of larceny or burglary. (Ord. 04-01, 2-2-2004)
3-22-8: PENALTIES:
   (A)   Any violations of the above sections shall subject the licensee to a
fine of not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) or more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00).
   (B)   After conducting a hearing on said violations, the mayor may revoke or
suspend the license of any pawnbroker.
   (C)   Every act or omission of whatsoever nature, constituting a violation
of any of the provisions of this chapter by any officer, director, manager or
other agent or employee of any licensee shall be deemed and held to be the act
of such licensee. (Ord. 04-01, 2-2-2004)
CHAPTER 23
WASTE HAULERS
SECTION:
3-23-1: Registration And Fees
3-23-1: REGISTRATION AND FEES:
   (A)   Any septic waste hauler wanting to obtain dumping privileges at the
East Moline Regional Wastewater Treatment Plant will be required to register
and provide the following information:
      1.   Billing information (W-9 form requires as part of billing
information);
      2.   Emergency contact information;
      3.   Proof of liability insurance (Min. $100,000.00 property /
$300,000.00 personal injury);
      4.   Proof of worker’s compensation insurance (or sworn statement
applicant has no employees);
      5.   List of trucks with tank volumes;
      6.   List of drivers with relevant information;
      7.   List of other disposal sites used by waste hauler.
   (B)   All septic waste haulers are required to abide by the City of East
Moline’s Sewer Use Ordinance, East Moline’s Dumper Policy, US EPA and IEPA
requirements pertaining to septic waste haulers.
   (C)   All septic waste haulers will be required to pay a $50.00 non-
refundable application fee that will accompany the registration application.
   (D)   If approved, the registration will be valid until January 31 of the
following calendar year at which time the registration must be renewed. (Ord.
18-13, 10-15-2018)
TITLE 4
BUILDING REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
BUILDING CODE

4-1-10: Safeguards
4-1-1: BUILDING CODES ADOPTED BY REFERENCE; PERMIT FEES:
   (A)   Adoption: The provisions of the International Building Code, 2018
edition, International Residential Code, 2018 edition, International Existing
Building Code, 2018 edition, International Fuel Gas Code, 2018 edition,
International Mechanical Code, 2018 edition, International Energy Conservation
Code, 2018 edition, International Property Maintenance Code, 2018 edition, and
International Swimming Pool and Spa Code, 2018 edition, which are freely
viewable online at http://publicecodes.citation.com/icod/index.htm, and, the
NFPA 70: 2017 National Electrical Code prepared and published by the National
Fire Protection Association are hereby adopted by reference and shall serve as
the Building Code of the City, subject to certain amendments, which are marked
exhibits A through H, as attached to the respective codes, which amendments are
on file in the Office of the Inspection Department. Where a conflict between
any referenced code appears, the more restrictive, as determined by the
Building or Code official, shall apply. (Ord. 18-10, 9-17-2018)

   (C)   Waiver Of Building Permit Fees: No building permit fees shall be

of those building permit fees as exempted under the Enterprise Zone Ordinance 1
. (Ord. 07-05, 3-5-2007)

4-1-2: PERMIT AND COMPLIANCE BOND REQUIREMENTS:
   (A)   Permit Required: It shall be unlawful to erect or construct any
building or structure other than a fence where the cost of such construction
exceeds one hundred dollars ($100.00) or where such building or structure
exceeds one hundred twenty (120) square feet in roof area, or to alter or
remodel any building or structure so as to change the bearing walls, beams,
supports, roof, or expand or diminish the existing floor area, without having
first secured the required permit or permits therefor from the building
inspector.
   (B)   Permit Duration And Extension: The building permit shall be valid for
six (6) months and may be extended for an additional six (6) months without fee
by the building inspector.
   (C)   Permit And Compliance Bond Requirements: Any person, firm or
corporation desiring to engage in the business of any form of building
construction or reconstruction including, but not limited to, concrete and
masonry contracting, demolition contracting, electrical contracting, fire
sprinkler contracting, fire suppression contracting, fire alarm contracting,
general contracting, heating, ventilation and air conditioning contracting,
lawn sprinkler contracting, swimming pool contractors and installers, private
sewage disposal contracting, roofing contracting, sign contracting, siding and
window contracting, and radon mitigation contracting, in the City of East
Moline shall register with the Inspection Department effective June 1 of each
year, and shall file with the Inspection Department a compliance bond, with the
form thereof to be furnished by the building inspector, in the amount of ten
thousand dollars ($10,000.00), conditioned upon the faithful performance of all
the provisions of this Code. This bond is a continuous bond and shall remain in
full force and effect until canceled by notice. The surety shall have the right
to cancel this bond for future liability upon thirty (30) days' written notice
to the City of East Moline.
Plumbing contractors shall provide copy of current State of Illinois contractor
registration and license of plumber of record.
   (D)   Proof Of Insurance Required: General contractors, upon registration,
shall provide the following:
      1.   Proof of liability insurance acceptable to the Finance Department in
the type and amount listed below:
Each applicant shall obtain and maintain for the duration of such registration,
public liability and property damage insurance in the minimum amount and for as
hereby specified: one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for each
occurrence of property damage; and three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00)
for each occurrence of personal injury or bodily harm. Such policy shall
provide that it cannot be canceled except upon written notification to the
Office of the Finance Department at least thirty (30) days prior to the date of
cancellation. Proof shall be a certificate of insurance.
      2.   Proof that the applicant has obtained workers' compensation
insurance or that the applicant is an approved self-insurer of workers'
compensation. Proof shall either be the certificate of insurance from the
insurance provider or the certificate of approval as a self-insurer issued by
the Illinois Industrial Commission. If an applicant is a sole proprietorship or
partnership then the applicant shall not be required to provide proof of
workers' compensation insurance. Such applicant's application shall include a
sworn statement that the applicant has no employees. (Ord. 07-05, 3-5-2007)
      3.   Effective May 1, 2011, the fee for registration shall be sixty
dollars ($60.00) and shall be valid for one year, and the filing fee for
plumbing contractors shall be sixty dollars ($60.00) and shall be valid for one
year. (Ord. 11-15, 4-4-2011)
      4.   A "general contractor" shall be taken to be any person, firm,
partnership, or corporation employed directly by any person, firm, partnership,
or corporation, who erects or reconstructs any building or parts thereof. (Ord.
07-05, 3-5-2007)
4-1-3: INTERPRETATION:
Whenever in the building regulations it is provided that anything must be done
subject to the approval of or discretion of the building official of the City,
this shall be construed to give such officer only the discretion of determining
whether the rules and standards established by ordinance have been complied
with; and no such building official shall have the power to change or alter
such rules or standards in any arbitrary or discriminatory manner.
Provided further, that whenever reference is made, in the Building Code herein
adopted, to the "building official" such term shall mean the building inspector
or other officers of the City designated by the Mayor and City Council as
having the duty to enforce the building regulations of the City. (1962 Code §
14.103)
4-1-4: APPLICATION:
Applications for such permits shall be made to the building inspector and shall
be accompanied by plans and specifications in duplicate showing the work to be
done; such plans shall be verified by the signature either of the owner of the
premises or by the architect or contractor in charge of operations. (1962 Code
§ 14.104)
4-1-5: APPROVAL OF PLANS:
The application, plans and specifications filed by an applicant for a permit
shall be reviewed by the building inspector. Such plans may be reviewed by
other departments of the City to check compliance with the laws and ordinances
under their jurisdiction. If the building inspector is satisfied that the work
described in an application for permit and the plans filed therewith conform to
the requirements of the Building Code as adopted and other pertinent laws and
ordinances, and that the fee specified has been paid, he shall issue a permit
therefor to the applicant. (Ord. 85-36, 10-21-1985)
4-1-6: VARIATIONS AND APPEALS:
   (A)   Variations: It shall be unlawful to vary materially from the submitted
plans and specifications unless such variations are submitted on an amended
plan to the Inspections Department and approved by the building official or
Code official.
   (B)   Appeals: Any owner or agent not in accord with a decision made by the
building official, Code official, or designated person, shall have the right to
appeal from such order or ruling to the Board of Standards and Appeals, as
granted and prescribed in title 2, chapter 4 of this Code. (Ord. 18-10, 9-17-
2018)
4-1-7: WRECKING AND DEMOLITION:
   (A)   Permit: It shall be unlawful to wreck or demolish any building or
structure that is larger than four hundred (400) square feet in floor area or
that is connected to electric, gas, water or sewer service without first
obtaining a permit from the building inspector. The applicant must prove that
all utilities have been disconnected before a permit shall be issued.
   (B)   Fee Schedule:
 
Frame garage or accessory building         $ 25.00
Residential 1 story house                  50.00
Residential greater than 1 story           75.00
Commercial building - 1 story              100.00
Commercial building - greater than 1 story 150.00
Industrial building - 1 story              200.00
Industrial building - greater than 1 story 250.00
 
   (C)   Compliance Bond: Before said demolition permit is granted by the
building inspector, the party applying therefor shall file with the City Clerk
a compliance bond, with the form thereof to be furnished by the building
inspector, in the amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) conditioned upon
the faithful performance of the provisions of this Building Code.
   (D)   Disposition Of Materials: The applicant shall certify to the building
inspector that all materials removed from the site shall either be salvaged,
destroyed or deposited in a landfill site approved by the Illinois
Environmental Protection Agency.
   (E)   Transportation Of Materials: The transport of all materials removed
from the site of any nonframe building must be on a route approved by the City.
   (F)   Safety Precautions: All parts of a building or structure shall be
wrecked and removed from the site so that no unsafe conditions nor hazardous
materials remain. All cellars, basements, cisterns, septic tanks or other below
grade cavities shall be completely removed and filled with sand or solid fill
within one foot (1') of finished grade.
   (G)   Site Restoration: The site shall be restored to original grade with
suitable topsoil material, graded to match existing terrain and drainage and
seeded with grass.
Exception: In the event a structure is to be constructed upon the site within
sixty (60) days after the date the demolition permit is issued, then the above
requirements for site restoration need not apply. (Ord. 01-11, 4-16-2001)
4-1-8: HOURS OF OPERATION:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in construction or demolition
activities in any Residential Zoning District at any time other than between
the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. (Ord. 85-
36, 10-21-1985)
4-1-9: OBSTRUCTION OF RIGHTS-OF-WAY:
No street, alley, nor sidewalk shall be obstructed to vehicle or pedestrian
traffic during the time of building construction or demolition without a permit
from the City Engineer. (Ord. 85-36, 10-21-1985)
4-1-10: SAFEGUARDS:
It shall be the duty of the persons engaged in construction or demolition to
take precautions to assure the safety of pedestrians and property. Warnings,
barricades, lights, temporary roofs over sidewalks, and flagmen shall be used
and maintained whenever necessary to assure public safety. (Ord. 85-36, 10-21-
1985)
CHAPTER 2
HOUSING CODE
SECTION:
4-2-1: Housing Code Adopted By Reference
4-2-2: Housing Inspector
4-2-3: Housing Advisory And Appeals Board
4-2-4: Powers Of Board
4-2-5: Vacant And Foreclosed Property Ordinance Purpose
4-2-6: Definitions
4-2-7: VFPO Guidelines
4-2-8: Registration And Appeals Process
4-2-9: Appeal Process
4-2-10: Remedial Building Plan
4-2-11:    Change Of Ownership
4-2-12:    Enforcement And Penalties
4-2-13:    Exemption
4-2-1: HOUSING CODE ADOPTED BY REFERENCE:
   The International Code Council, international property maintenance code as
adopted in section
4-1-1 of this title, copy of which is on file in the inspection department
office, is hereby adopted by reference and shall serve as the housing code of
the city, subject to certain amendments, which were recommended by the East
Moline board of appeals, and which are marked exhibit A as attached to the
ordinance codified herein and made a part hereof by reference, which amendments
are on file in the office of the inspection department.
(Ord. 06-13, 6-5-2006; amd. Ord. 10-13, 5-3-2010)
4-2-2: HOUSING INSPECTOR:
   (A)   The position of a "housing inspector" is hereby created, together with
such staff that shall be necessary to enforce the provisions of this code and
the enforcing officer shall be classified as the "housing inspector" of the
city.
   (B)   This office shall be directly responsible to the city engineer and the
housing and advisory appeal board of said city for the duties as defined in
this code by the housing and advisory appeal board and the housing inspector's
service shall be terminated after just cause is shown as determined by his
supervisors aforementioned.
   (C)   All permits or certificates issued pursuant to inspections of this
office shall be signed and approved by the housing inspector, building
inspector, electrical inspector, heating and air conditioning inspector, health
inspector, and the fire chief or his agent, certifying that the premises meet
the requirements of this code. (Ord. 69-15, 4-7-1969)
4-2-3: HOUSING ADVISORY AND APPEALS BOARD:
A board is hereby created to be known as the housing advisory and appeals board
and it shall consist of five (5) citizen members and the city engineer as an ex
officio member. The five (5) citizen members shall be appointed by the mayor by
and with the advice and consent of the city council and they shall include an
engineer, a building contractor, a journeyman trade or craftsman, a
businessman, and a minority group representative. This board shall elect a
chairman from the five (5) citizen members. The terms of the five (5) citizen
members shall be for three (3) years each and shall be staggered terms as
specified by the mayor. The references to the building official in section H-
203 of the uniform building code referring to the housing advisory and appeals
board are hereby deleted and the city engineer shall herewith be inserted in
the place of the building official referred to therein.
(Ord. 69-15, 4-7-1969)
4-2-4: POWERS OF BOARD:
   (A)   The board referred to above shall have the power to hear and decide
appeals from the housing code when a written petition appealing an order or
requirement of the building inspector or his duly authorized representative,
pursuant to regulations of the housing code of the city, is filed by a property
owner or his agent, with the secretary of the housing advisory and appeals
board, specifically, the city engineer.
   (B)   The board shall hold a public hearing on the appeal of the appellant
not more than fifteen (15) days after the date of filing the appeal and said
appeal shall be subject to a twenty five dollar ($25.00) filing fee which shall
cover the cost of publication of the public notice in a newspaper of general
circulation throughout the community.
   (C)   The board shall render all decisions and findings in writing to the
building inspector with a duplicate copy to the appellant and may recommend to
the city council such new legislation as is consistent therewith.
   (D)   The board shall also have the power to establish schedules whereby the
owner, or his agent, of a property or holding shall appeal to the board for an
order or requirement issued by the building inspector or his duly authorized
representative based upon findings of fact according to the individual
circumstances or financial ability of the appellant which can be reasonably and
properly completed to meet the provisions or requirements of this code.
   (E)   An appeal shall stay all proceedings in furtherance of the action
appealed from, unless the building inspector or his duly authorized
representative certifies to the board that by reason of facts stated in the
certificate a stay would, in his opinion, cause imminent peril to life or
property; in such case, proceedings shall not be stayed otherwise than by order
which may, on due cause shown, be granted by the board on applications, after
notice to the building inspector by a court of record.
   (F)   The board is hereby empowered to take sworn testimony and all final
administrative decisions of the aforesaid board shall be subject to judicial
review pursuant to the provisions of the administrative review act, approved
May 8, 1945, and all amendments and modifications thereof, and the rules
adopted pursuant thereto.
(Ord. 69-15, 4-7-1969)
4-2-5: VACANT AND FORECLOSED PROPERTY ORDINANCE PURPOSE:
   The purpose of the vacant and foreclosed property ordinance (VFPO) is for
the integrity of the area, general nuisance prevention, property value
retention, health and public safety of the East Moline community. The VFPO
assists staff with assigning responsibility to property owners, financial
institutions, investors, and all interested parties regarding vacant properties
under their care. All parties with an interest in vacant properties shall be
required to register all vacant properties with the City of East Moline
community development department. Six (6) month registration allows staff to
contact property owners in the event of an emergency, safety issues, nuisance
violations, and more importantly direct communication regarding the condition
of the property.
   The VFPO Ordinance shall not be construed to prevent the enforcement of
other applicable ordinances, codes, legislation, and regulations which
prescribe standards other than are provided herein, and in the event of
conflict, the most restrictive shall apply.
(Ord. 24-07, 9-3-2024)
4-2-6: DEFINITIONS:
ABANDON: Any residential or commercial real estate which has been continuously
unoccupied by persons legally in possession for the preceding one (1) year.
Failure to establish or maintain public utilities within the one (1) year shall
be considered abandonment.
APPEAL: Property owners directly affected by the decision of the director, or
his/her designee shall have the right to an appeal. The property owner shall
notify the director in writing within twenty (20) days that he /she is seeking
an appeal to the vacant and foreclosed property ordinance or determination for
modification or denial. The director shall set the date, time, and location of
the meeting. The board of zoning appeals shall hear the appeal.
BUILDING CODES: ICC code standards adopted by the City of East Moline.
BUILDING/STRUCTURE: Anything constructed or erected with a fixed location on
the ground or attached to something having a fixed location on the ground used
or intended for shelter or occupancy. Structures include, but not limited to:
commercial and residential buildings, walls, swimming pools, signs, and fences.
CHANGE OF OWNERSHIP: The transfer of ownership of property from the current
owner(s) to the new owner(s). The new owner(s) shall be required to submit a
vacant building application, action plan and subject to all fees associated
with the VFPO ordinance/application.
COMPLAINT OF FORECLOSURE: Legal procedure lenders file regarding during the
foreclosure process. Information provided regarding the physical address, legal
description, deed or trust, promissory note, the default, amount due, and list
of defendants and describe their interest in the property.
CONTACT INFORMATION: Name, address, emergency phone contact and alternate
contact. The point of contact shall be locally or within the quad city region
that can respond within a twenty-four (24) hour period.
CREDITOR: A federal or state-chartered bank, savings bank, savings and loan
association, credit union, mortgagee and any entity acting on behalf of the
creditor named in the debt obligation including, but not limited to servicers.
DANGEROUS BUILDING: A building defined as a "dangerous building" in the city
building code, as it may be amended. Such buildings are public nuisances.
DWELLING: One family, two family, multiple family, and townhouse intended for
the purpose of habitation.
EXTERIOR PROPERTY AREAS: The open space on the premises and on adjoining
property under the control of owners or operators of such premises.
LOT: A tract of land intended as a unit for the purpose (whether immediate or
future) of development or transfer of ownership. A lot may or may not coincide
with a "lot of records."
MAINTENANCE: Acts of repair and other acts to prevent a decline in the
condition of grounds, structures, and equipment; such that the condition does
not fall below the standards established by this.
OCCUPANT: Any person (including domestic service employees) living and/or
sleeping in a dwelling unit or having possession of a space within a building.
OCCUPIED BUILDING/STRUCTURE: A commercial or residential building/structure
used for the purposes of habitation, storage, or conducting business. Occupied
buildings/structures shall maintain the proper utility services required for
habitation or conducting business which includes electric, heat, sewer, and
water.
PROPERTY OWNER: Any individual, group of individuals, association, corporation,
joint stock association, joint venture, or any other entity in whose name the
legal title to the real estate is recorded.
PUBLIC NUISANCE: A public nuisance will shall be considered either of the
following:
   1.   The physical condition, or uses of any premises regarded as a public
nuisance at common law, under the Illinois compiled statutes, or under this
code; or
   2.   Any physical condition, use or occupancy of any premises or its
appurtenances considered an attractive nuisance to children, including, but not
limited to, abandoned wells, shafts, basements, excavations, and unsafe fences
or structures; or
   3.   Any premises which has unsanitary sewerage or plumbing facilities; or
   4.   Any premises designated by the community development director, or his
or her designee, as unsafe for human habitation or use; or
   5.   Any premises which is manifestly capable of being a fire hazard, or
manifestly unsafe or insecure as to endanger life, limb or property; or
   6.   Any premises which is unsanitary, or which is littered with rubbish or
garbage, or which has an uncontrolled growth of weeds; or
   7.   Any building that is dangerous, in a state of dilapidation,
deterioration or decay; faulty construction; open or vacant and the doors,
windows, or other openings are boarded up or secured, by any means other than
conventional methods used in the design of the building or permitted for new
construction of similar type; damaged by fire to the extent as not to provide
shelter, in danger of collapse or failure and dangerous to anyone on or near
the premises; or
   8.   Any building defined as a "dangerous building" by this section, as it
may be amended.
VACANT: A building, structure, or lot that has been unoccupied for more than
thirty (30) days. To include but not limited to the absence of utilities
provided by the City of East Moline or any other private utility company
supplying electric, heat, sewer, and water.
VFPO APPLICANT: Person or registered agent responsible for applying to the City
of East Moline when a property is vacant for more than thirty (30) days, at any
given time.
VFPO REGISTRATION: The City of East Moline by ordinance number requires all
vacant properties to be registered with the city for the purpose of maintaining
the integrity of the area, general nuisance prevention, property value
retention, health and public safety of the East Moline community. The applicant
shall provide the city with the appropriate contact information of the person
or company responsible for nuisance violation, regular maintenance, and
emergency events.
VFPO REGULATIONS: All vacant properties are subject to the enforcement of the
adopted international code council (ICC) codes adopted by the City of East
Moline and all necessary city codes pertaining to the subject property in
direct violation. All codes shall include the adopted building, electrical,
mechanical, plumbing, property maintenance, fire, storm water, ordinances, city
codes, and zoning codes.
WORKMANLIKE: Whenever the words "workmanlike state of maintenance and repair"
are used in this code, they shall mean that such maintenance and repair shall
be made in a reasonably skillful manner, and by licensed professionals where
required by law and work shall comply with all applicable codes and laws.
(Ord. 24-07, 9-3-2024)
4-2-7: VFPO GUIDELINES:
   (A)   Application: Applicant to submit application to the community
development department if the property is vacant more than (30) days. Vacant
registration includes commercial and residential buildings/structures, vacant
commercial and residential lots, and parcels with no building/structure. A
separate application shall be required for each building/structure, lot or
parcel identified with a separate address or separate property identification
number (PIN).
   (B)   Application Fee: Applicants shall pay to the City of East Moline a
registration fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150) per residential lot every
six (6) months. Applicants shall pay to the City of East Moline a registration
fee of two hundred dollars ($200) per commercial lot every six (6) months.
   (C)   Application Review: Staff shall review all applications to ensure all
contact information is current and correct.
   (D)   Remedial Plan: The applicant shall submit a detailed plan for regular
maintenance, future construction, and detailed timeline for completion, at the
time of application submittal.
   (E)   Inspections: Staff will conduct random inspections for compliance.
   (F)   Failure To Comply: Failure to comply with the VFPO Ordinance shall
result in fines, abatement orders, liens placed on the property, and any other
legal actions permitted by law.
(Ord. 24-07, 9-3-2024)
4-2-8: REGISTRATION AND APPEALS PROCESS:
   (A)   The City of East Moline vacant and foreclosed property registration
shall be valid for a period of six (6) months. Property owners and/or creditor
are required to register any building, lot, or parcel of land that is vacant
for more than thirty (30) days, at any given time. Each building/structure,
lot, or parcel of land with a separate address or property identification
number (PIN) shall be required to register separately. In addition to
registration, property owners shall submit a plan of action regarding regular
maintenance plan, future construction, and detailed timeline for completion
during the vacancy.
   (B)   Creditors filing a complaint of foreclosure or executing a deed in
lieu of foreclosure on any building, lot, or parcel of land shall be required
to register within thirty (30) days. The creditor shall notify the City of East
Moline of any change of ownership, action plan, maintenance plan schedule, and
any other changes affecting the property.
   (C)   Property owners shall provide the following:
      1.   Name, address and telephone number of owner.
      2.   Name, address and telephone number of any local agent or
representative.
      3.   Name, address and telephone number of all persons with any legal
interest in the property, building and premises.
      4.   Legal description and tax parcel identification number of the
premises on which the building is situated.
      5.   The common address of the building.
      6.   Date on which building became vacant or unoccupied.
      7.   Remedial building plan.
   (D)   At the time of application submittal, property owners and/or creditors
shall pay the required application fee. The fee schedule shall be as follows:
      1.   Vacant Residential Property Registration one hundred fifty ($150)
every six (6) months
      2.   Vacant Commercial Property Registration two hundred dollars ($200)
every six (6) months
   Failure to comply with the City of East Moline vacant and foreclosed
property ordinance (VFPO) shall result in fines, abatement orders, liens placed
on the property, and any other legal actions permitted by law.
(Ord. 24-07, 9-3-2024)
4-2-9: APPEAL PROCESS:
   The director of community development or his/her designee shall have the
authority to review, modify, deny, or approve the proposed vacant building plan
in accordance with the City of East Moline VFPO. If the owner or agent of the
building objects to the modifications or denial made by the director, such
owner or agent shall have the right of appeal to the board of zoning appeals
(BZA) for a final determination. Such an appeal shall be filed with the
director within twenty (20) days of receipt of the director's notice of
modification or denial.
(Ord. 24-07, 9-3-2024)
4-2-10: REMEDIAL BUILDING PLAN:
   (A)   When a building is registered as required herein, the owner or agent
shall submit a remedial building plan. The city, via its community development
director, or his or her designee, may determine the remedial building plan if
the owner or agent fails to file a plan or such plan does not conform with this
chapter. The plan shall contain the following:
      1.   A plan of action to repair any doors, windows or other openings
which are boarded up or otherwise secured by any means other than conventional
methods used in the design of the building or permitted for new construction of
similar type. The proposed repair shall result in openings secured by
conventional methods used in the design of the building or by methods permitted
for new construction of a similar type.
      2.   For buildings and premises thereof, which are identified as being or
containing public nuisances, then the remedial building plan shall contain a
plan of action to remedy such public nuisances.
      3.   For buildings and premises thereof, which are identified as being
code deficient, then the remedial building plan shall contain a plan of action
to remedy such deficiencies.
      4.   For each required plan a time schedule shall be submitted
identifying a date of commencement of repair and date of completion of repair
for each improperly secured opening, identified nuisance and identified code
deficiency.
      5.   When the owner proposes to demolish the building, then the owner
shall submit a plan and time schedule for such demolition.
      6.   A plan of action to maintain the building and premises thereof in
conformance with applicable law.
      7.   A plan of action with a time schedule identifying the date the
building will be habitable and occupied or offered for occupancy or sale. The
time schedule shall include dates of commencement and completion of all actions
required to achieve habitability. No plan which does not provide for compliance
with this chapter, or which will not, as determined by the community
development director, or his or her designee, achieve such compliance within
six (6) months, will be approved.
      8.   All premises upon which unoccupied or vacant buildings are located
and all exteriors shall, at all times, be maintained in compliance with this
code.
      9.   Exterior lighting according to standards established by the
community development director, or his or her designee, and available from the
city.
      10.   A plan shall additionally provide evidence of liability insurance
for the property in a minimum amount of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000).
(Ord. 24-07, 9-3-2024)
4-2-11: CHANGE OF OWNERSHIP:
   The remedial building plan shall remain in effect, notwithstanding a change
in ownership. The new owner is required to file a new registration with the
community development director or his/her designee and supply the name, address
and telephone number of the new owners.
(Ord. 24-07, 9-3-2024)
4-2-12: ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTIES:
   (A)   Any person found to have violated any provision of this chapter shall
be subject to a minimum fine of one hundred dollars ($100) per day per
violation to a maximum of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750) per day per
violation, in addition to any other legal or equitable remedies available to
the city. Each day shall constitute a new violation. Such other remedies
include, but are not limited to, injunctive relief, application to a court of
competent jurisdiction for a receiver, demolition, or condemnation, contracting
for the repair or purchase of the premises, or foreclosure of any lien the city
may have thereon.
   (B)   A separate and distinct offense shall be committed each day on which
such person or persons shall violate the provisions of this chapter.
   (C)   Nothing herein contained shall prohibit the city from immediately
condemning as provided for in this code a building or taking other immediate
action upon a determination that the building is a public nuisance or poses an
imminent danger to the occupants of the building, or the public, health, safety
and welfare.
(Ord. 24-07, 9-3-2024)
4-2-13: EXEMPTION:
   (A)   The following circumstances may warrant an exemption from registration
and/or payment of fee:
      1.   If the property is habitable wherein ail building systems are in
sound working order which is evidenced by the issuance of a certificate of
occupancy, and the building and grounds are maintained in good order, and the
building is being actively marketed for sale or rental and actively maintained.
Evidence of the property following the City of East Moline, housing code while
marketing for sale or rent shall include but not limited to, retaining a
licensed real estate agent or broker to list the property for sale or rent,
taking out advertisements in various media forms such as, newspapers and online
services, and need to be provided to the community development director or his
or her designee. The director may request additional information, for example
any available photos, price, and agent information.
      2.   An owner submits plans to the director demonstrating that the
property will be completely rehabilitated and restored to productive use and
occupancy within twelve (12) months following the initial property registration
along with a certified letter from a licensed contractor or architect stating
that the property is capable of being completely rehabilitated and restored to
productive use and occupancy within the twelve (12) months following the
initial property registration. In the interim the property is actively
maintained. The director may request additional information, for example any
available photos, plot plan, layout plan etc. Failure to make reasonable
progress within one hundred eighty (180) days of permit issuance will result in
the permit being revoked and subjected to section
4-2-12, Enforcement and Penalties.
      3.   The owner certifies to the designated municipal official that the
vacancy is a result of damage from a natural disaster in the past six (6)
months and the owner is actively seeking insurance proceeds or federal/state
assistance to rehabilitate. The owner is required to update the director
monthly until the property is rehabilitated.
      4.   The owner certifies the vacancy is a result of a fire in the past
thirty (30) days and the owner is actively seeking insurance proceeds to
rehabilitate. The owner is required to update the director monthly until the
property is rehabilitated.
      5.   The owner certifies to the director that the vacancy is not an
abandonment and is utilized as a vacation home, or conversely the property is
vacant while the owner resides at a vacation home and the subject property is
actively maintained.
      6.   The owner is on active duty with any branch of the U.S. Armed
Services. In determining whether a request for exemption should be granted, the
director shall consider the following:
         a.   The applicant's prior record as it pertains to the city's housing
code, building code, or property maintenance code violations;
         b.   The amount of vacant property the applicant currently has within
the city; and the length of time that the building for which the exception is
sought has been vacant.
         c.   The proximity of the vacant property to a school, which requires
additional safety considerations.
(Ord. 24-07, 9-3-2024)
CHAPTER 3
PLUMBING
SECTION:
4-3-1: Adoption Of Plumbing Code
4-3-2: Permit Required
4-3-3: Enforcing Officer
4-3-4: New Plumbing, Exposure For Inspection
4-3-5: Individual Connection To Sewer And/Or Water Required
4-3-6: Standards
4-3-7: Fee Schedules
4-3-8: Prohibition Of Wells For Potable Water Supply
4-3-1: ADOPTION OF PLUMBING CODE:
The most recent edition of the Illinois Plumbing Code shall apply to the
installation, alteration, repair, relocation, addition, replacement, and
maintenance of plumbing systems regulated by the Illinois Plumbing Code within
the City of East Moline. The Uniform Plumbing Code, 2018 edition, which is
freely viewable on line at http://epubs.iapmo.org/2018/UPC/, shall apply to any
and all plumbing and piping systems not regulated by the Illinois Plumbing
Code. In addition, any structure in which a building drain is installed shall
have at least one vent stack carried through the roof and increased to a
minimum size of four inches (4") at a point one foot (1') below the roof line.
It shall be unlawful to install any plumbing fixtures within the City which do
not comply with the above regulations. The plumbing inspector shall keep on
file in his office and make available for inspection by the public, the most
recent copy of Illinois Plumbing Code and amendments as adopted by the City.
(Ord. 18-10, 9-17-2018)
4-3-2: PERMIT REQUIRED:
   (A)   No person shall engage in or perform plumbing in the City without
first obtaining a permit from the plumbing inspector. Permits shall be granted
to those persons eligible under the provisions of "an act in relation to the
licensing and regulation of plumbers, to repeal a certain act therein named and
to prescribe penalties for the violation thereof", approved July 13, 1953, of
the State of Illinois, and to those persons engaged in the sewer cleaning
business. The term "plumbing" is used herein as defined in said Act, as
amended.
   (B)   In order to be eligible to obtain a permit, any person engaging in, or
performing plumbing as a licensed plumber shall be on file in the office of the
plumbing inspector, and furnish satisfactory proof that such person is duly
licensed and registered with the State. All sewer cleaning businesses engaged
to work on a sewer shall be registered with the City. Such person shall file
with his registration a surety bond to be approved by the City Attorney in the
sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), conditioned to indemnify and save
harmless the City from the results of any acts of the registry engaging in or
performing plumbing and/or sewer cleaning in the City. Such bonds shall be a
continuous bond. All contractors who work on the interior of a City sewer shall
file with the plumbing inspector of said City a written report setting forth
the location, nature of work and cause, if known, within twenty four (24) hours
of completion of said work. (Ord. 07-05, 3-5-2007)
4-3-3: ENFORCING OFFICER:
The plumbing inspector shall enforce the provisions of the Illinois Plumbing
Code in the City. (Ord. 18-10, 9-17-2018)
4-3-4: NEW PLUMBING, EXPOSURE FOR INSPECTION:
In all buildings hereafter erected, both public and private, and in all
buildings already built or erected wherein any plumbing is hereafter installed
or wherein any sewer connection pipe shall be hereafter repaired or changed,
except for minor repairs, on the sewer side of the trap, the drain, soil
rainwater and other pipe or pipes connected directly or indirectly into any
drain, soil or waste pipe, and all traps shall be exposed for view for
inspection and test by the plumbing inspector, and shall not be covered until
such test is made. (Ord. 97-20, 4-7-1997)
4-3-5: INDIVIDUAL CONNECTION TO SEWER AND/OR WATER REQUIRED:
Every building having plumbing fixtures installed and intended for human
habitation, occupancy, or use on premises abutting on a street, alley or
easement in which there is a public sewer and/or water available within two
hundred feet (200') of the property line, shall have an individual connection
made with the sewer and/or water main within ninety (90) days after the owner
thereof has received notice of availability of sewer and/or water services.
The entire plumbing and drainage system of every building shall be entirely
separate and independent from that of any other building, except in the
situation where there are two (2) buildings on one lot, one in the rear of the
other building. In that situation, if there is no sewer in the alley to which
the rear building can be connected, the sewer, in front, serving the front
building may be extended to serve the rear building. (Ord. 97-20, 4-7-1997)
4-3-6: STANDARDS:
All work done on any plumbing system shall be performed in an efficient and
workmanlike manner, and in accordance with the Illinois Plumbing Code as
adopted by the City. (Ord. 97-20, 4-7-1997; amd. Ord. 18-10, 9-17-2018)
4-3-7: FEE SCHEDULES:
   (A)   Residential Plumbing Fee Schedule:
      1.   In dwelling structures or portions of structures used exclusively
for dwelling purposes, the fee for the first two (2) fixtures shall be twenty
five dollars ($25.00), and shall be an additional ten dollars ($10.00) for each
fixture thereafter.
      2.   The fee for the installation or replacement or relocation of all
domestic water heaters, domestic hot water storage tanks, range boilers, and
all domestic water heating appliances pertaining to plumbing shall be twenty
five dollars ($25.00) for each such fixture.
      3.   The fee for the installation of roof drains shall be twenty five
dollars ($25.00) when piping to such drain is run inside of buildings and
wasted into a storm drain system, including natural storm drain runoff areas
for each location.
      4.   A special fee for the performance of service and maintenance work
shall be five dollars ($5.00) to cover the cost of permit issuance and
inspection of work at each location.
   (B)   Commercial Plumbing Valuation Fee Schedule: In commercial, industrial
and institutional structures, the permit fee shall be based on the valuation of
the entire plumbing installation, which is to be declared on the permit
application. The following fee schedule shall apply:
$1.00 - $1,000.00                     $ 25.00
$1,001.00 - $2,000.00                 30.00
$2,001.00 - $3,000.00                 40.00
$3,001.00 - $4,000.00                 50.00
$4,001.00 - $5,000.00                 60.00
$5,001.00 - $6,000.00                 70.00
$6,001.00 - $7,000.00                 80.00
$7,001.00 - $8,000.00                 90.00
$8,001.00 - $9,000.00                 100.00
$9,001.00 - $10,000.00                110.00
$10,001.00 - $11,000.00               120.00
$11,001.00 - $12,000.00               130.00
$12,001.00 - $13,000.00               140.00
$13,001.00 - $14,000.00               150.00
$14,001.00 - $15,000.00               160.00
$15,001.00 and over add, per thousand 20.00
 
Plus sewer and water at twenty five dollars ($25.00) for each connection and/or
tap.
   (C)   Sanitary Sewer Connections:
      1.   Tap-In Permit Fee: All structures shall be connected to the sanitary
sewer main at the time of completion of construction. There shall be a fee of
twenty five dollars ($25.00) for a permit to cover each tap-in to the City
sanitary sewer mains, or for each connection to an existing stub extension from
the main, to serve the building sewerage system.
      2.   Backflow Prevention Devices: All backflow prevention devices shall
be inspected at the time of installation and shall be certified annually. The
fee for each inspection or certification for this shall be thirty dollars
($30.00).
      3.   Connections To City Water Mains: With respect to all structures,
building lots, subdivisions, etc., there is established a fee of twenty five
dollars ($25.00) for a permit fee to cover each individual tap to the City
water mains, whether for immediate or future use. When taps are made for water
extension to serve individual lots at the time of installation of the water
main system, such taps shall be made by Illinois licensed plumbers who are
bonded to act as contractors by the City of East Moline, Illinois, and proper
permits shall be procured and paid for at that time.
      4.   Extra Trip Charge: All extra trips that are made other than those
required for regulation inspections will be charged at the rate of forty two
dollars fifty cents ($42.50) per trip. This charge shall apply to any trip
occasioned by wrong construction, the use of defective or improper material, or
any call to make inspection before the work to be inspected is ready. (Ord. 07-
05, 3-5-2007)
4-3-8: PROHIBITION OF WELLS FOR POTABLE WATER SUPPLY:
   (A)   Use Of Ground Water As A Potable Water Supply Prohibited: The use, or
attempt to use as a potable water supply, of ground water from within the
corporate limits of the City of East Moline by the installation or drilling of
wells or by any other method is hereby prohibited, including at points of
withdrawal by the City of East Moline.
   (B)   Penalties: Any person violating the provisions of this section shall
be subject to a fine of up to five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each
violation.
   (C)   Definitions:
      PERSON: Any individual, partnership, copartnership, firm, company,
limited liability company, corporation, association, joint stock company,
trust, estate, political subdivision, or any other legal entity, or their legal
representatives, agents or assigns.
      POTABLE WATER: Any water used for human or domestic consumption,
including, but not limited to, water used for drinking, bathing, washing
dishes, preparing foods, watering lawns, or watering gardens in which produce
intended for human consumption is grown.
   (D)   Sump Pump Discharge Excepted: The prohibition as set forth in
subsection (A) of this section shall not prohibit the discharge of water from a
sump pump upon lawns or gardens.
   (E)   Severability: If any provision of this section or its application to
any person or under any circumstances is adjudged invalid, such adjudication
shall not affect the validity of the section as a whole or of any portion not
adjudged invalid. (Ord. 99-9, 3-1-1999)
CHAPTER 4
ELECTRICAL CODE
SECTION:
4-4-1: Electrical Codes Adopted By Reference
4-4-2: Permit And Compliance Bond Requirements
4-4-3: Administration
4-4-4: Procedure
4-4-5: Appeals
4-4-6: Adoption Of Fee Schedule
4-4-7: Electrical Contractor License
4-4-1: ELECTRICAL CODES ADOPTED BY REFERENCE:
The International Code Council, International Code Council Electrical Code
administrative provisions, 2018 edition, and the National Fire Protection
Association, National Electrical Code as adopted in section
4-1-1 of this title, copies of which are on file in the Office of the
Inspection Department, are hereby adopted by reference and shall serve as the
Electrical Code of the City subject to certain amendments, which were
recommended by the East Moline Board of Standards and Appeals and which are
marked exhibit F attached to the ordinance codified herein and made a part
hereof by reference, which amendments are on file in the Office of the
Inspection Department. (Ord. 18-10, 9-17-2018)
4-4-2: PERMIT AND COMPLIANCE BOND REQUIREMENTS:
It shall be unlawful to install electrical wiring and to connect electrical
fixtures, apparatus, or appliances for furnishing light, heat, or power without
having secured a permit from the building inspector.
Any person, firm or corporation desiring to engage in the business of
electrical contracting in the City of East Moline shall file with the City
Clerk a compliance bond, with the form thereof to be furnished by the building
inspector, in the amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), conditioned upon
the faithful performance of all the provisions of the National Electrical Code,
as most recently adopted. (Ord. 01-10, 4-16-2001)
4-4-3: ADMINISTRATION:
The building inspector shall have the power and responsibility to administer
the Electrical Code. This includes, but is not limited to, reviewing plans,
issuing permits, inspecting for compliance, interpreting rules and regulations
of the code, requiring compliance with the code, and approving electrical work.
(Ord. 85-40, 11-18-1985)
4-4-4: PROCEDURE:
Application for permits shall be made to the building inspector and shall be
accompanied by necessary plans, information and specifications of the work to
be done as determined by the building inspector. Upon approval of the plans and
payment of the fee, an electrical permit shall be issued. (Ord. 85-40, 11-18-
1985)
4-4-5: APPEALS:
Any owner or his agent not in accord with a decision made in the enforcement of
this code shall have the right to appeal from such order or ruling to the Board
of Standards and Appeals, as granted and prescribed in title 2, chapter 4 of
this City Code. (Ord. 18-10, 9-17-2018)
4-4-6: ADOPTION OF FEE SCHEDULE:
The following fee schedule is hereby adopted for the issuance of all electrical
permits in the City:
