an infectious waste generator or contributor that may cause punctures or cuts.
Such waste includes, but is not limited to, needles, syringes, lancets, scalpel
blades, contaminated broken or sharp laboratory glassware including slides,
coverslips, and pasteur pipettes.
      Non-Infectious Waste Sharps: Waste sharps not originating from the
diagnosis, care or treatment of humans or animals.
   (C)   Fluid Blood, Blood Products And Body Fluids: Human blood and blood
products include serum, plasma and other blood components. The term body fluid
should include semen, vaginal secretions, cerebrospinal fluid, synovial fluid,
pleural fluid, peritoneal fluid, pericardial fluid, amniotic fluid and any
other body fluid visibly contaminated with blood.
   (D)   Animal Waste: Animal waste derived from animals afflicted with
zoonotic disease or purposely infected with agents communicable to humans.
Infectious animal waste should include blood and body fluids, carcasses, body
parts, excrement, and bedding of these animals.
   (E)   Other Wastes: Other wastes as reasonably determined by the infectious
waste generator, that have come into contact with human body substances or
other sources which may contain pathogenic microbial agents or other
biologically active materials in sufficient concentrations that exposure to the
waste directly or indirectly creates a significant risk of disease.
INFECTIOUS WASTE GENERATOR: Any producer of infectious waste, to include
without limitation the following categories: skilled nursing facility or
convalescent hospitals, intermediate care facilities, inpatient care facilities
for the developmentally disabled, chronic dialysis clinics, community clinics,
health maintenance organizations, surgical clinics, urgent care clinics, acute
psychiatric hospitals, laboratories, medical buildings, physician's offices and
clinics, veterinary offices, dental offices and clinics, funeral homes, or
other similar facilities.
INFECTIOUS WASTE GENERATOR - PRIVATE: Any producer of infectious waste and
dependent upon self-injection; to include without limitation, persons with
insulin dependent diabetes, persons with hemophilia using clotting factor, and
persons receiving other injections or intravenous treatments.
INFECTIOUS WASTE TRANSPORTER: A person who transports infectious waste.
INFECTIOUS WASTE TREATMENT: Infectious waste treatment is defined as any
method, technique or process designed to change the biological character or
composition of waste, and as described herein. (Ord. 90-31, 8-20-1990)
7-12-2: AUTHORITY; ADMINISTRATION, INSPECTION AND ENFORCEMENT:
The Health Officer of the East Moline Public Health Department is authorized to
administer and enforce all the provisions of this Chapter relating to the
generation, storage, treatment, transportation, and disposal of infectious
wastes in the City. (Ord. 90-31, 8-20-1990)
7-12-3: INFECTIOUS WASTE INVENTORY PLAN:
The Health Officer shall prepare an infectious waste inventory plan of all
infectious waste generators. Such infectious waste inventory plan shall be
limited to general identification of types of infectious waste generated (e.g.,
laboratory waste, infectious waste sharps, non-infectious waste sharps, fluid
blood/blood products and body fluids, animal waste, other) and, name, address,
and phone number of infectious waste generator. (Ord. 90-31, 8-20-1990)
7-12-4: STORAGE AND CONTAINMENT OF INFECTIOUS WASTE:
   (A)   Outdoor storage of infectious waste shall be in a manner and location
which affords protection from animals, rain and wind; does not provide a
breeding place or a food source for insects or rodents; and is accessible only
to authorized personnel.
   (B)   Infectious waste, except for sharps, shall be contained in disposable
leakproof plastic bags or containers that have a strength to preclude ripping,
tearing or bursting under normal conditions of use. The bags shall be labeled
as containing infectious waste (i.e., BIOHAZARD symbol). The bags shall be
secured to prevent leakage or expulsion of solid or liquid waste during
storage, handling or transport. These gags shall be placed in containers which
will lend rigidity to the plastic bags such as disposable or reusable pails,
cartons, boxes, drums or portable bins. These containers shall be labeled with
the standard BIOHAZARD symbol or as infectious waste.
   (C)   Infectious sharps waste shall be contained in leakproof, rigid,
puncture resistant, containers, and shall be tightly lidded before being placed
in approved plastic bags for storage, handling and transport. These containers
shall be labeled with the standard BIOHAZARD symbol or as infectious waste.
      1.   Non-infectious sharps waste shall be contained in leakproof, rigid,
puncture resistant containers, and shall be tightly lidded before being placed
in approved plastic bags for handling and storage.
   (D)   Reusable containers for infectious waste storage shall be rigid,
durable, corrosion resistant, non-absorbent, and water tight, insect and rodent
proof, and equipped with tight fitting lids or covers. Reusable containers
shall be cleaned and sanitized as needed to preclude the possibility of
nuisance conditions.
   (E)   Non-reusable containers, such as cardboard, styrofoam or other
materials intended for single-use only shall not be re-used for any purpose.
(Ord. 90-31, 8-20-1990)
7-12-5: INFECTIOUS WASTE TREATMENT:
   (A)   Infectious waste generator shall not cause or allow any infectious
waste to be deposited in any landfill unless same has been rendered innocuous
by incineration, steam sterilization, or other treatment method approved in
writing by the Health Officer. Proper monitoring of treatment processes should
be followed to insure sterilization of the waste is achieved. Blood, blood
products and body fluids may be poured via a utility sink drain or toilet into
an approved sewage disposal system. Following proper grinding and screening,
animal excrement and bedding material should be disposed of in an approved
sewage disposal system provided the waste strength is acceptable. Once
infectious waste is properly treated, it is non-infectious and can enter the
general waste stream.
   (B)   Infectious waste generator-private shall be exempted from those
requirements concerning infectious waste treatment as described in subsection
(A) of this Section. However, all other requirements herein stated shall be
considered applicable. (Ord. 90-31, 8-20-1990)
7-12-6: INFECTIOUS WASTE DISPOSAL:
   (A)   Infectious waste generators which do not utilize facilities to render
waste innocuous shall:
      1.   Contract with a special waste hauler permitted by the Illinois
Environmental Protection Agency to dispose of all infectious waste materials
or;
      2.   Personally transport infectious waste to an approved infectious
waste treatment or storage facility, provided that all infectious waste is
properly contained, and identified while in transport; and provided that such
infectious waste treatment or storage facility notifies the Health Officer in
writing of such agreement with individual infectious waste generator. (Ord. 90-
31, 8-20-1990)
7-12-7: INFECTIOUS WASTE TRANSPORTER:
   (A)   Any person desiring to operate as a commercial infectious waste
transporter shall submit written application to the Health Officer.
Such application form shall be prepared by the Health Department and shall
include the applicant's full name, post office address, and the signature of an
authorized representative of the applicant; shall disclose whether such
applicant is an individual, firm, corporation, and description of the site(s)
that the applicant is planning to use to treat or dispose of infectious waste.
   (B)   Infectious waste collection/transportation vehicles used by permitted
infectious waste transporters shall have a leakproof, fully enclosed non-
compacting container compartment of a durable and easily cleanable
construction, and shall be identified on each side of the vehicle with the name
or trademark of the infectious waste transporter and with the standard
BIOHAZARD symbol or otherwise to indicate containment of infectious waste.
   (C)   All persons collecting or transporting infectious waste shall avoid
littering, the creation of other nuisances or hazards at the loading point,
during transport and upon unloading of the waste.
   (D)   The Health Officer may require disinfection of any vehicle. Vehicles
shall be cleaned frequently to prevent rodent/vector nuisances. All waste-water
from vehicle cleaning shall be disposed of in a sanitary sewer system unless
otherwise authorized by the Health Officer.
   (E)   Infectious waste transporter shall have available at all times a
containment kit/equipment so as to control accidental leakage, or spill, of
infectious waste from transport container. All spills shall be reported to the
Health Department. (Ord. 90-31, 8-20-1990)
7-12-8: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Violation of any of the provisions of this Chapter shall constitute a violation
subject to the provisions of Section
1-4-1 of this Code and any person convicted thereof may be punished for each
separate offense. Each day's violation shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 90-31, 8-20-1990)
CHAPTER 13
TATTOOING ESTABLISHMENTS
SECTION:
7-13-1: Definitions
7-13-2: Tattooing Establishments And Tattoo Artists To Be Licensed; Fees
7-13-3: Display Of License
7-13-4: Exceptions To Provisions Of Chapter
7-13-5: Application And Fee
7-13-6: Contents Of Application
7-13-7: Hours Of Operation
7-13-8: Personnel
7-13-9: Equipment
7-13-10: Cleaning And Storage Of Equipment
7-13-11: Tattooing Procedures
7-13-12: Sanitary Facilities
7-13-13: Physical Facilities
7-13-14: Inspections
7-13-15: Tattooing
7-13-16: No Guarantee Or Warranty
7-13-17: Hearing Prerequisite To Revocation Of License; Notice
7-13-18: Grounds For Revocation
7-13-19: Tattooing Establishments Practicing When Provisions Of Chapter Became
Effective
7-13-20: Federal, State And Local Regulation
7-13-21: Penalty
7-13-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this Chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this Section:
CERTIFICATE OF INSPECTION: Written approval from the health authority that said
tattooing has been inspected and meets all of the terms of this Ordinance
relating to physical facilities, equipment and layout for operation of such
business. Said writing shall be on a form designated by the health authority
for such purposes.
CITY: The City of East Moline, Illinois.
HEALTH AUTHORITY: The Health Inspector or authorized representative.
OPERATOR: Any individual, firm, partnership, company, corporation or
association that owns or operates an establishment where tattooing is
performed.
TATTOO ARTIST: Any individual who performs or practices the art of tattooing,
on the person of another.
TATTOO, TATTOOED, TATTOOING: To insert pigment under the surface of the skin of
a human being, by pricking with a needle or otherwise, so as to produce an
indelible mark or figure visible through the skin. (Ord. 95-1, 2-6-1995)
7-13-2: TATTOOING ESTABLISHMENTS AND TATTOO ARTISTS TO BE LICENSED; FEES:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of
operating a tattooing establishment within the City without first paying an
annual license fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) and payable to City Clerk's
office upon written approval from the health authority and to engage in such
business in accordance with the provisions hereof.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or conduct any tattoo
establishment within the City without a tattoo license, respectively, which
shall be issued pursuant to the provisions of this Chapter, or to employ any
person as a tattooer, who has not paid for such tattoo artists annual license
fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each artist, and payable to City Clerk's
office, upon written approval from the health authority. (Ord. 95-1, 2-6-1995)
7-13-3: DISPLAY OF LICENSE:
Every person to whom a license shall have been granted shall display said
license in a conspicuous place. Failure to display said license shall be
grounds for revocation. (Ord. 95-1, 2-6-1995)
7-13-4: EXCEPTIONS TO PROVISIONS OF CHAPTER:
The requirements of this Chapter shall have no application and no effect upon
and shall not be construed as applying to any person, firm or corporation
licensed by the State to practice medicine or licensed by the State to practice
any of the healing arts. (Ord. 95-1, 2-6-1995)
7-13-5: APPLICATION AND FEE:
Any person desiring to obtain a license to operate a tattooing establishment
shall make application to the City Clerk who shall refer all such applications
to the Chief of Police and Health Inspector for an appropriate investigation.
(Ord. 95-1, 2-6-1995)
7-13-6: CONTENTS OF APPLICATION:
   (A)   The application for a tattooing license required by this Chapter shall
contain the following information:
      1.   Full name and current address;
      2.   The two (2) previous addresses of the applicant immediately prior to
the current address;
      3.   Written proof that the applicant is over the age of eighteen (18)
years;
      4.   Applicant's height, weight and color of eyes and hair;
      5.   Two (2) current photographs at least two inches by two inches (2" x
2") in size;
      6.   The business, occupation or employment of the applicant for the
three (3) years immediately preceding the date of the application;
      7.   The tattooing license history of the applicant, including whether
such person in previous operation in this or another area has had his license
revoked or suspended, the reason therefore, and any business activity or
occupation subsequent to the action of suspension or revocation;
      8.   All convictions (excluding traffic convictions), and the grounds
therefore;
      9.   The names of all employees of the establishment (and there shall be
a continuous obligation to notify the City Clerk within 10 days after any
employee is terminated or hired);
      10.   A certificate from a medical doctor designating that the applicant
has recently been examined and is free of any contagious or communicable
disease. (Ord. 95-1, 2-6-1995)
7-13-7: HOURS OF OPERATION:
The hour of operation of a tattoo, electrolysis and/or body piercing
establishment within the City shall be between the hours of seven o'clock (7:
00) A.M. and ten o'clock (10:00) P.M., Monday through Saturday and shall not be
open for business on Sunday. (Ord. 95-1, 2-6-1995)
7-13-8: PERSONNEL:
   (A)   No employee, while infected with a disease in a communicable form, or
who is a carrier of a disease; and no employee while affected with a boil,
infected wound or acute respiratory infection shall provide tattooing to a
client.
   (B)   No employee shall provide tattooing to any skin surface that shows
evidence of any rash, boils, infections or other unhealthy conditions or
disease.
   (C)   Employees shall thoroughly wash their hands and the exposed portions
of their arms with soap and warm water before starting work, during work as
often as is necessary to keep them clean, and after smoking, eating, drinking
or using the toilet. Employees shall keep their fingernails clean and trimmed.
   (D)   Employees providing tattooing shall, in addition to thoroughly
washing, shall use single-use latex or vinyl examination gloves, as a barrier
to potentially infective blood.
   (E)   Employees shall not use tobacco in any form, or eat or drink while
tattooing a client.
   (F)   No employee shall provide tattooing without first obtaining a
tattooing artist permit. (Ord. 95-1, 2-6-1995)
7-13-9: EQUIPMENT:
   (A)   All service table surfaces shall be constructed of easily cleanable
material.
   (B)   Sterile single service or sterile individual containers of dye or ink
shall be used for each patron.
   (C)   Ink cups shall be for single patron use.
   (D)   All tubes, needle bars and instruments used in the tattoo procedure
that are not sterile single patron use and disposable shall be thoroughly
cleaned and steam sterilized or dry-heat sterilized between patrons.
   (E)   Tattoo machines shall be stored in a manner that will maintain
sterility.
   (F)   Needles shall be disposable, sterile, single patron use or shall be
reusable needles and shall be thoroughly cleaned and steam sterilized or dry-
heat sterilized between patrons.
   (G)   Razors shall be single patron use and disposable, or shall be
sterilized razors with a new blade used for each patron. Alum or other material
used to stop the flow of blood shall be used only in liquid or powder form.
   (H)   Topical ointments or medications shall be packaged for single patron
use.
   (I)   All bandages and dressings shall be sterile and single use.
   (J)   All instruments, equipment and facilities shall be maintained in a
clean and sanitary condition. (Ord. 95-1, 2-6-1995)
7-13-10: CLEANING AND STORAGE OF EQUIPMENT:
   (A)   All clean and ready-to-use needles and instruments shall be kept in a
locked storage cabinet maintained in a clean and sanitary condition.
   (B)   A steam sterilizer (autoclave) shall be provided for sterilizing all
needles and similar instruments before use on any customer, person or patron.
Sterilization of equipment will be accomplished by exposure to live steam for
at least thirty (30) minutes at a minimum pressure of fifteen (15) pounds per
square inch, and temperature of two hundred forty degrees Fahrenheit (240°F),
or one hundred sixteen degrees Celsius (116°C).
   (C)   Dry-heat sterilization shall be at three hundred fifty degrees
Fahrenheit (350°F) (170° C) for one hour. The needles and instruments required
to be sterilized shall be so used, handled and temporarily placed during
tattooing and/or body piercing so that they will not be contaminated. (Ord. 95-
1, 2-6-1995)
7-13-11: TATTOOING PROCEDURES:
   (A)   The area of skin to be worked on shall first be thoroughly washed and
scrubbed for a period of two (2) minutes with warm water to which has been
added an antiseptic liquid soap. A sterile single-use sponge shall be used to
scrub the area. After shaving and before the tattooing, electrolysis and/or
piercing is begun, a solution of seventy percent (70%) alcohol shall be applied
to the area with a single-use sponge used and applied with a sterile
instrument;
   (B)   For tattooing, single-service or individual containers of dye or ink
shall be used for each patron, and the container therefore shall be discarded
immediately after completing work on a patron; any dye in which the needles
were dipped shall not be used on another person;
   (C)   Whenever a new sterile tube is used that contains a different color of
dye or ink, a separate or new sterile needle shall also be used. Excess dye or
ink shall be removed from the skin with an individual, single-use sterile
sponge or a disposable paper tissue which shall be used only on one person and
then immediately discarded. After completing work on any person, the tattooed
area shall be washed with sterile gauze saturated with an antiseptic soap
solution approved by the health officer, or a seventy percent (70%) alcohol
solution. The tattooed area shall be allowed to dry and petroleum jelly from a
collapsible or plastic tube shall be applied, using sterile gauze. A sterile
gauze dressing shall then be fastened to the tattooed area with adhesive; and
   (D)   Persons tattooed shall be provided with printed instructions regarding
tattoo care during the healing process and shall be instructed to consult a
physician if signs and symptoms of an infection develop.
   (E)   Single-use needles, razors or other sharps materials must be disposed
of immediately upon completion of tattooing within approved sharps disposal
containers. (Ord. 95-1, 2-6-1995)
7-13-12: SANITARY FACILITIES:
   (A)   Enough potable water under pressure, and at the right temperature
shall be provided to all fixtures and equipment that use water.
   (B)   The potable water system shall be installed so as to preclude the
possibility of backflow.
   (C)   All water-carried sewage shall be disposed of by means of a Municipal
sewage system, or a private sewage system or a private sewage disposal system.
   (D)   All plumbing shall be sized, installed and maintained in accordance
with applicable provisions of the plumbing code.
   (E)   At least one toilet and no fewer than the number of toilets required
by the plumbing code shall be provided, and shall be accessible to the public
clientele.
   (F)   Toilet rooms shall be completely enclosed and shall have tight
fitting, self-closing doors.
   (G)   Toilet rooms shall be mechanically and effectively ventilated to the
outside atmosphere.
   (H)   Toilet rooms shall be kept clean, in good repair and free of
objectionable odors. A supply of toilet tissue shall be provided at each toilet
at all times. Easily cleanable, covered receptacles shall be provided for waste
materials.
   (I)   Lavatories shall be located in, or immediately adjacent to toilet
rooms.
   (J)   Lavatories shall be located in the immediate vicinity, and easily
accessible to the tattooing artist while providing tattooing to a client.
   (K)   Each lavatory shall be provided with hot and cold water tempered by
means of a mixing valve or combination-faucet.
   (L)   A supply of hand-cleansing soap or detergent shall be available at
each lavatory. A supply of sanitary towels or a hand-drying device providing
heated air shall be conveniently located near each lavatory. Common towels
shall be prohibited. If disposable towels are used, easily cleanable waste
receptacles shall be conveniently located.
   (M)   Lavatories, soap dispensers, hand drying devices and all related
fixtures shall be kept clean and in good repair.
   (N)   All garbage and refuse generated indoors shall be disposed of in
durable, easily cleanable containers. Plastic bags shall line all containers.
   (O)   All garbage and refuse stored outdoors shall be stored in an approved
garbage dumpster. Approved garbage dumpsters shall be placed on a concrete or
asphalt surface, and shall be easily accessible to garbage collection crews.
(Ord. 95-1, 2-6-1995)
7-13-13: PHYSICAL FACILITIES:
   (A)   Tattooing shall be performed in a room of not less than one hundred
(100) square feet, and shall be physically separate from toilet rooms and
waiting areas.
   (B)   Floors and floor coverings in all toilet rooms, janitors closets and
tattooing rooms shall be constructed of smooth, durable material such as sealed
concrete, terrazzo, ceramic tile or durable grades of linoleum or plastic, and
shall be maintained in good repair.
   (C)   The walls, wall coverings and ceilings of toilet rooms, and tattooing
rooms shall be light-colored, smooth, nonabsorbent and easily cleanable. All
junctures between walls and floors shall be covered and sealed.
   (D)   Permanently fixed artificial light sources shall be installed to
provide at least twenty (20) foot-candles of light intensity in all toilet
rooms and tattooing rooms.
   (E)   All tattooing establishments shall provide at least one utility sink
or curbed cleaning facility with a floor drain for the cleaning of mops or
similar wet floor cleaning tools and for the disposal of mop water or similar
liquid waste.
   (F)   All rooms shall have sufficient ventilation to keep them free of
excessive heat, steam, condensation, vapors, obnoxious odors, smoke and fumes.
   (G)   An adequate number of lockers or other suitable facilities shall be
provided and used for the orderly storage of employees' clothing and other
belongings.
   (H)   Tattooing establishments shall be maintained free of pest insect and/
or rodent infestations.
   (I)   Tattooing establishments shall not allow the keeping of other live
animals within the tattooing room except for canine accompanying the visually
handicapped. This exclusion does not include the presence of birds in cages or
fish in aquariums in the waiting room. (Ord. 95-1, 2-6-1995)
7-13-14: INSPECTIONS:
During the business hours of the tattooing establishment, the health authority
may conduct periodic inspections for the purpose of determining whether or not
said establishment and the persons performing the art of tattooing therein are
in compliance with all applicable health provisions contained within this
Ordinance and other pertinent ordinances. It shall be unlawful for any person
or operator of a tattooing establishment willfully to prevent or restrain the
health officer from entering any licensed establishment where tattooing is
being performed for the purpose of inspecting said premises, after proper
identification is presented to the operator. (Ord. 95-1, 2-6-1995)
7-13-15: TATTOOING:
No person, other than a person licensed to practice medicine in all its
branches, shall do any tattooing to any person under the age of twenty one (21)
years without the consent of a parent or legal guardian, provided, however,
that such parent or legal guardian are themselves over twenty one (21) years of
age. A sign shall be prominently displayed at the tattoo facility stating that
tattooing of a person under the age of twenty one (21) is contrary to State
law. (Ord. 95-1, 2-6-1995)
7-13-16: NO GUARANTEE OR WARRANTY:
The purpose of this Chapter is to protect the public interest by reducing the
dangers involved in unregulated practice of tattooing. Neither the issuance of
a license, the making of an inspection without finding violations, or any other
act by the health officer or by any other City official shall constitute a
guarantee or warranty that any equipment or any treatment is safe or effective,
or that any tattooing establishment will perform without making errors. (Ord.
95-1, 2-6-1995)
7-13-17: HEARING PREREQUISITE TO REVOCATION OF LICENSE; NOTICE:
No license shall be revoked until after due notice and a hearing shall have
been held before the City Administrator to determine just cause for such
revocation. Notice of such hearing shall be given in writing and served at
least ten (10) days but not more than twenty (20) days prior to the date of the
hearing thereon. The notice shall state the grounds of the complaint against
the holder of such license and shall designate the time and place where such
hearing will be had. Said notice shall be served upon the license holder by
delivering the same personally or by leaving such notice at the place of
business or residence of the license holder in the custody of a person of
suitable age and discretion. In the event the license holder cannot be found,
and the service of such notice cannot be otherwise made in the manner herein
provided, a copy of such notice shall be mailed, registered and postage fully
prepaid, addressed to the license holder at his place of business or residence
at least ten (10) days prior to the date of such hearing. (Ord. 95-1, 2-6-1995)
7-13-18: GROUNDS FOR REVOCATION:
The license of a tattooing establishment may be revoked for any legitimate
reason, including without limitation any one or more of the following grounds:
   (A)   That the holder has been convicted in a court of competent
jurisdiction of a felony. The conviction of a felony shall be the conviction of
any offense which, if committed within this State, would constitute a felony
under the laws thereof.
   (B)   That the holder is addicted to the habitual use of intoxicating
liquors, narcotics or stimulants to such an extent as to incapacitate such
person for the performance of his professional duties for any period of time.
   (C)   That the holder is guilty of fraudulent, false, misleading or
deceptive advertising.
   (D)   That the holder is guilty of wilful negligence in the practice of
tattooing or has been guilty of employing, allowing or permitting any
unlicensed person to perform tattooing in his establishment.
   (E)   That liquor is being sold or consumed within the establishment.
   (F)   That the licensee has been convicted of prostitution, pandering,
pimping or other offense opposed to decency and morality.
   (G)   That the licensee has committed any act involving moral turpitude.
   (H)   That the establishment has abandoned the practice of tattooing or that
the individual licensee has abandoned the same practices. For purposes of this
subsection, "abandonment" shall mean that the activities regulated hereunder,
or any of them, have ceased or otherwise not conducted for a period of sixty
(60) days at the establishment in question, or where an individual licensee has
abandoned the activities regulated hereunder, or any of them, for a like
period.
   (I)   That the licensee, whether an establishment or individual, has
violated any provision of this Ordinance, whether or not an action has been
commenced in Circuit Court.
   (J)   Any licensee, whether an establishment or individual, who has had its
license revoked three (3) times shall be ineligible for any license hereunder
for a period of five (5) years beginning with the effective date of the third
revocation. (Ord. 95-1, 2-6-1995)
7-13-19: TATTOOING ESTABLISHMENTS PRACTICING WHEN PROVISIONS OF CHAPTER BECAME
EFFECTIVE:
Any person, firm or corporation who is actually engaged in the practice of
tattooing at the time of final passage of this Chapter and meets all the
requirements except as to adequacy of facilities, and, upon payment of the
prescribed fee, shall be granted a license. Such person shall have thirty (30)
days from the effective date of this Ordinance from which this Chapter is
derived to bring his facilities into compliance with this Chapter. (Ord. 95-1,
2-6-1995)
7-13-20: FEDERAL, STATE AND LOCAL REGULATION:
Wherever Federal, State or local laws, ordinances, rules or regulations
conflict with the provisions of this Ordinance, then the law, ordinance, rule
or regulation which is most strict shall apply, and it shall not be a defense
to an action under this Chapter, or to a request for suspension or revocation
of the license(s) provided herein, that this Ordinance does not specifically
enumerate the proscribed, prohibited or regulated conduct. (Ord. 95-1, 2-6-
1995)
7-13-21: PENALTY:
In addition to the revocation and suspension of any license, any person
violating any provision of this Ordinance shall be fined not less than twenty
five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each
offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or
on which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 95-1, 2-6-1995)
CHAPTER 14
RADON RESISTANT CONSTRUCTION
SECTION:
7-14-1: Adoption By Reference, Model Standards And Techniques For Control Of
Radon In New Residential Buildings
7-14-2: Zone One Credit (Rep. by Ord. 03-05, 3-3-2003)
7-14-3: Inspection
7-14-4: Enforcement
7-14-5: Testing And Evaluation
7-14-6: Penalties
7-14-7: Conflict Of Ordinance
7-14-1: ADOPTION BY REFERENCE, MODEL STANDARDS AND TECHNIQUES FOR CONTROL OF
RADON IN NEW RESIDENTIAL BUILDINGS:
The mayor and the city council for the city of East Moline are aware that radon
gas remains a deadly threat to our well being, and that radon is second only to
cigarette smoking as the leading cause of lung cancer in our nation, and that
the city of East Moline has been identified to be located in a zone 1-high
radon potential area, and furthermore are aware that the model standards and
techniques are applicable to controlling radon levels in new construction of
one- and two- family dwellings and other new residential buildings three (3)
stories or less in height.
Therefore, the city council of the city of East Moline, Illinois, for the
purpose of prescribing regulations that will help control radon in new
residential buildings and contribute to a healthier indoor air environment,
hereby adopts by passage of this ordinance, certain regulations known as the
"Model Standards And Techniques For Control Of Radon In New Residential
Buildings", as recommended by the United States environmental protection
agency, air and radiation (6604-J), being particularly the March 1994 (EPA 402-
R-94-009) document, specifically sections 9.0, 9.1, 9.1.1.a-b-c, 9.1.2, 9.1.5,
9.1.6*, 9.1.7**, 9.1.8, 9.1.9, 9.1.10, 9.1.11, 9.1.12, 9.1.13, 9.1.14, 9.1.15,
9.1.16, 9.1.17, 9.1.18, 9.1.19, 9.1.20, 9.1.20.1, 9.1.20.2, 9.1.20.3, 9.1.21,
9.1.21.1, 9.1.21.2, 9.1.21.3 and 9.1.21.5 thereof, and any future revisions or
addenda thereto, of which not less than three (3) copies of said regulations
have been and are now filed in the office of the clerk of the city of East
Moline, and the same are hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out
at length herein, and from the date on which this ordinance shall take effect,
the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the limits of the city of
East Moline, Illinois.
* Unfinished basements or cellar occupancies are exempt from the requirements
of both sections 9.1.6 and 9.1.7.
** Delete the sentence "A continuous formed gap (for example, a "tooled edge")
which allows the application of a sealant that will provide a continuous, air-
tight seal shall be created along all joints." from section 9.1.7.
(Ord. 97-44, 11-17-1997)
7-14-2: ZONE ONE CREDIT:
(Rep. by Ord. 03-05, 3-3-2003)
7-14-3: INSPECTION:
The city will require a minimum of three (3) inspections during the
installation of the "standards and techniques", which will be made concurrently
with typical ground work/precover/final building or plumbing inspection
request; and to include: a) "prepour": prior to basement or crawl space pour,
an inspection of the installation of the plastic T- fitting, and the
installation of the polyethylene sheeting over the gas permeable (clean
aggregate or sand) layer, b) "precover": prior to wall covering, an inspection
of the vent pipe installation as it passes vertically through the walls and
into the attic space including the roof penetration and, c) "final inspection":
to verify all applicable work has been completed. The city will identify the
vent piping installation with labels which clearly read "RADON REDUCTION
SYSTEM" and "NO PLUMBING-DO NOT USE" so as to be easily identified for future
reference, and not to be confused with household plumbing system components.
(Ord. 97-44, 11-17-1997)
7-14-4: ENFORCEMENT:
This ordinance shall be enforced by the health inspector or authorized
representative for the city of East Moline (Illinois) health department in
accordance with the "Model Standards And Techniques For Control Of Radon In New
Residential Buildings"; United States environmental protection agency, air and
radiation, March 1994, and any subsequent revisions, copies of which will be on
file in the city clerk's office. (Ord. 97-44, 11-17-1997)
7-14-5: TESTING AND EVALUATION:
The health inspector or authorized representative for the East Moline health
department, within six (6) months after new home occupancy, shall provide
appropriate tests to determine the effectiveness of the radon resistant new
construction methods; and at no expense to the homeowner. The health inspector
shall provide explanation of test results to homeowner, and may make
recommendations to enhance or improve the indoor radon levels. (Ord. 97-44, 11-
17-1997)
7-14-6: PENALTIES:
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this ordinance shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine of not less that fifty
dollars ($50.00) and not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day
which such a violation occurs shall constitute a separate violation. (Ord. 97-
44, 11-17-1997)
7-14-7: CONFLICT OF ORDINANCE:
In any case where a provision of this ordinance is found to be in conflict with
a provision of the East Moline building code(s) current practice, the East
Moline building code(s) will prevail and remain in full force. (Ord. 97-44, 11-
17-1997)
CHAPTER 15
INTERMENTS
Section:
7-15-1: Interment Of Remains
7-15-1: INTERMENT OF REMAINS:
It shall be unlawful to make any interment or bury the dead body of any person
within the city limits, except in a properly established cemetery. (Ord. 17-07,
2-21-2017)
TITLE 8
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
CHAPTER 1
STREETS AND SIDEWALKS
SECTION:
8-1-1: Supervision
8-1-2: Construction
8-1-3: Specifications
8-1-4: Injury To New Pavements
8-1-5: Repairs And Maintenance
8-1-6: Defects
8-1-7: Obstruction
8-1-8: Barricades
8-1-9: Disturbing Barricades
8-1-10: Private Use
8-1-11: Encroachments
8-1-12: Injury
8-1-13: Deposits On Streets
8-1-14: Deposits On Sidewalks
8-1-15: Drains
8-1-16: Poles And Wires
8-1-17: Gas Pumps
8-1-18: Games
8-1-19: Openings
8-1-20: View At Corners
8-1-21: Barbed Wire Fences
8-1-22: Burning Leaves, Rubbish (Rep. by Ord. 91-30, 10-7-1991)
8-1-23: Bicycle Path And Walkway
8-1-24: Discharge Of Water
8-1-1: SUPERVISION:
All public streets, alleys, sidewalks and other public ways in the City shall
be under the supervision of the Director of Maintenance Services. He shall be
charged with the enforcement of all provisions of this Code relating to such
public places (except traffic regulations) and is hereby authorized to enforce
such Code provisions. (M.C. 1962, sec. 13.101; amd. Ord. 88-1, 1-4-1988)
8-1-2: CONSTRUCTION:
It shall be unlawful to construct or lay any pavement on any public street,
sidewalk, alley or other public way or to repair the same without having first
obtained a permit therefor. Applications for such permits shall be made to the
Clerk and shall state the location of the intended pavement or repair, the
extent thereof and the person or firm who is to do the actual construction
work. No such permits shall be issued except in or on the order of the City
Council. (M.C. 1962, sec. 13.102)
8-1-3: SPECIFICATIONS:
All street and sidewalk pavements shall be made in conformity with
specifications laid down or approved from time to time by the Council. (M.C.
1962, sec. 13.104)
8-1-4: INJURY TO NEW PAVEMENTS:
It shall be unlawful to walk upon or drive any vehicle or animal upon or injure
any newly laid street or sidewalk pavement while the same is guarded by a
warning sign or barricade or to knowingly injure any soft newly laid pavement.
(M.C. 1962, sec. 13.105)
8-1-5: REPAIRS AND MAINTENANCE:
   (A)   Kept In Good Repair: All public streets, alleys and sidewalk pavement
shall be kept in good repair, said repair work to be done under the supervision
of the Director of Maintenance Services.
      It shall be the duty of all owners of lots, blocks, tracts or parcels of
land touching the line of a sidewalk in the City to maintain and repair said
sidewalk.
      It shall be the duty of the Director of Maintenance Services to serve or
cause to be served, a notice addressed to the party who last paid the general
taxes on the respective real estate, notifying said person that the sidewalk
abutting the subject real estate is in need of repair and that the necessary
repairs must be made within thirty (30) days of the receipt of the notice. The
cost of said repairs made under voluntary compliance shall be shared between
the property owner and the City under the then existing sidewalk replacement
program as determined by the City Council.
      If the person so served does not make the necessary repairs within the
prescribed time period, the Director of Maintenance Services may proceed to
make the necessary repairs, keeping an account of the expense of the repairs,
and one hundred percent (100%) of such expense shall be collected from the
property owner pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-84-3, or may be
filed as a lien against said property with the Recorder of Deeds of Rock Island
County, Illinois. Any property owner's failure to properly maintain the
sidewalk abutting the owner's real estate shall create a cause of action
against such owner in favor of any party injured as a result of the failure to
maintain the sidewalk.
   (B)   Duties Of Abutting Property Owners:
      1.   The occupant of property abutting a public right of way or the owner
thereof if said property is vacant, or any person acting as the agent of
either, shall have the following duties in relation to said public right of
way:
         (a)   To remove within a reasonable time from the portion of any
public sidewalk abutting said property all snow and ice.
         (b)   To refrain from putting, pushing, blowing or otherwise
depositing any snow removed from a public sidewalk or private property upon any
improved public roadway.
         (c)   To refrain from allowing, causing, permitting or making any
accumulation of sand, gravel, soil, ashes, debris, or other matter to be
washed, blown, carried or deposited by the elements or otherwise from private
property to the public right of way, including, but not limited to, streets,
alleys, sidewalks, catch basins and storm drains, and to remove any such matter
so washed, blown, carried or deposited onto said public right of way within a
reasonable time.
         (d)   To maintain the boulevard in accordance with the ordinances of
the City.
      2.   For purposes of this Section, "reasonable time" shall mean as
follows:
         (a)   Snow Removal: Within twenty four (24) hours after cessation of a
snowfall or, if a snowfall ceases in the nighttime hours, within twenty four
(24) hours after sunrise.
         (b)   Other Material: Within twenty four (24) hours after such matter
has been washed, blown, carried or deposited onto the public right of way or;
if the cause of said washing, blowing, carrying or depositing of such matters
onto public right of way is an ongoing activity such as excavation,
construction or transportation; within two (2) hours after the close of each
workday.
   (C)   Violation: Any person found guilty of violating any of the provisions
of this Section shall be subject to a fine of five dollars ($5.00) for the
first offense, ten dollars ($10.00) for the second offense and twenty five
dollars ($25.00) for the third offense, with said offense being charged by
citation as issued by the Police Department, only after written warning has
been delivered to the property owner or occupant. (Ord. 96-4, 2-5-1996)
8-1-6: DEFECTS:
It shall be the duty of every City officer or employee becoming cognizant of
any defect in any street or alley or sidewalk or any obstruction thereof, to,
report the same to the Director of Maintenance Services as soon as possible.
(Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-1-7: OBSTRUCTION:
It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, create or maintain any
obstruction of any street, alley, sidewalk or other public way, except as may
be specifically authorized by ordinance or by the Director of Maintenance
Services when necessary in an emergency or in connection with any lawful
construction, repair or removal work.
When an abandoned, unattended, wrecked, burned or partially dismantled vehicle
is creating a hazard to vehicular or pedestrian traffic, its immediate removal
from the street, alley, sidewalk or other public way by a towing service may be
authorized by the Police Department. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-1-8: BARRICADES:
Any person laying or repairing any pavement on a street, sidewalk or other
public place or making an excavation in any such place, shall maintain suitable
barricades to prevent injury to any person or vehicle by reason of the work;
such barricades shall be protected by lights at nighttime.
Any defect in any such pavement shall be barricaded to prevent injury; any
person properly maintaining any opening or excavation in any such place shall
guard such opening or excavation while the same remains open by proper
barricades and lights. (M.C. 1962, sec. 13.109)
8-1-9: DISTURBING BARRICADES:
It shall be unlawful to disturb or interfere with any barricade or lights
lawfully placed to protect or mark any new pavement or excavation or opening in
any public street, alley or sidewalk. (M.C. 1962, sec. 13.110)
8-1-10: PRIVATE USE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to use any street, sidewalk or other public
place as space for the display of goods or merchandise for sale or to write or
mark any signs or advertisements on any such pavements. (M.C. 1962, sec.
13.111)
8-1-11: ENCROACHMENTS:
It shall be unlawful to erect or maintain any building or structure which
encroaches upon any public street or property. (M.C. 1962, sec. 13.112)
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to erect or cause to
be erected, to retain or cause to be retained, an "encroachment" (herein
defined), within the limits of the roadway right of way.
ENCROACHMENT: Any building, fence, sign, or any other structure or object of
any kind (with the exception of utilities and public road signs), which is
placed, located or maintained in, on or over any portion of the roadway right
of way.
ROADWAY RIGHT OF WAY: Those areas existing or acquired by dedication or by fee
simple for highway purposes; also, the areas acquired by temporary easement
during the time the easement is in effect. (Ord. 99-17, 5-17-1999)
8-1-12: INJURY:
It shall be unlawful to injure any sidewalk, street or alley pavement. (M.C.
1962, sec. 13.113)
8-1-13: DEPOSITS ON STREETS:
It shall be unlawful to deposit on any street any material which may be harmful
to the pavement thereof, or any waste material or any glass or other articles
which may do injury to persons, animals or property.
Coal or other materials may be deposited in streets preparatory to delivery or
use, provided that such deposit does not reduce the usable width of the roadway
at the point to less than eighteen feet (18'), provided that such material or
coal, other than material to be used in actual building construction, shall not
be permitted to remain on such street for more than three (3) hours.
Any such material or coal shall be guarded by lights if the same remains upon
any street after nighttime. (M.C. 1962, sec. 13.114)
8-1-14: DEPOSITS ON SIDEWALKS:
It shall be unlawful to deposit on any public sidewalk any material which may
be harmful to the pavement thereof, or any waste material, or any glass or
other articles which might cause injury to persons, animals or property.
Merchandise or other articles may be deposited on sidewalks preparatory to
delivery, provided that the usable width thereof is not thereby reduced to less
than four feet (4'); and provided that no such article shall remain on such
walk for more than one- half (1/2) hour. (M.C. 1962, sec. 13.115)
8-1-15: DRAINS:
It shall be unlawful to obstruct any drain in any public street or alley. (M.C.
1962, sec. 13.116)
8-1-16: POLES AND WIRES:
It shall be unlawful to erect any poles or wires or to maintain any poles or
wires over any public street, alley or other public way without having first
secured permission from the Director of Maintenance Services. (Ord. 99-10, 3-
15-1999)
8-1-17: GAS PUMPS:
It shall be unlawful to maintain or erect any gasoline pump or tank in any
public street, alley or sidewalk. (M.C. 1962, sec. 13.118)
8-1-18: GAMES:
It shall be unlawful to play any games upon any street, alley, sidewalk or
other public place where such games cause unnecessary noise or interfere with
traffic or pedestrians. (M.C. 1962, sec. 13.119)
8-1-19: OPENINGS:
It shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any opening or stairway in any
public street or sidewalk or alley without a permit from the City Council. All
such lawfully maintained openings shall be guarded by a suitably strong cover
or a railing to the approval of the Director of Maintenance Services. (M.C.
1962, sec. 13.120; amd. Ord. 88-1, 1-4-1988)
8-1-20: VIEW AT CORNERS:
It shall be unlawful to construct or maintain or permit to remain any fence or
other structure or any bushes or other plants on a corner lot within fifty feet
(50') of the street line which obstructs the view, at a height of more than
five feet (5') above the level of the adjacent street pavement.
Any person violating any provision of this Chapter shall be subject to penalty
as provided by Section
1-4-1 of this Code; and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each
day during or on which a violation occurs or continues or on which any such
obstruction to the view is permitted to remain after notice from the Police
Department, or any other official of the City, to remove the same. (M.C. 1962,
sec. 13.121)
8-1-21: BARBED WIRE FENCES:
It shall be unlawful to maintain or construct any fence composed in whole or in
part of barbed wire, or with any similar material designed to cause injury to
person, or any wire which is charged with electric current, anywhere within
three feet (3') of any public street, sidewalk, alley, park or other public way
or place. (M.C. 1962, sec. 13.122)
8-1-22: BURNING LEAVES, RUBBISH:
(Rep. by Ord. 91-30, 10-7-1991)
8-1-23: BICYCLE PATH AND WALKWAY:
The bicycle path and walkway within the City of East Moline shall be restricted
to pedestrians, including joggers, and those on bicycles, in-line skates, and
those in wheelchairs. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate upon the
bicycle path and walkway any other vehicle, any motorized vehicle, or
skateboard, except for any vehicle approved in writing by the Chief of Police,
or any vehicle authorized by the City for maintenance, security, safety or
emergency purposes, or motorized wheelchairs. (Ord. 92-37, 9-21-1992)
The bicycle path and walkway shall be closed to all persons before the hour of
six o'clock (6:00) A.M., and after the hour of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. Any
person convicted of a violation of said ordinance provision shall be subject to
a fine of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) and not more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 91-37, 12-2-1991)
8-1-24: DISCHARGE OF WATER:
   (A)   Prohibited: The owner or occupant of property abutting a public right
of way, or any other person acting as agent for either, shall not discharge
water originating from sumps, sump pits, sump pumps or other pumps or any
reservoir serving as a drain or receptacle for water, onto a street, alley, or
other public right of way so as to cause a hazardous accumulation of water or
ice upon said right of way.
   (B)   Notification: The Director of Maintenance Services shall give written
notice of violation to the owner or occupant of the property from which the
water is discharged. Said notice shall direct said owner or occupant to abate
the discharge within thirty (30) days. If the discharge of water continues
after thirty (30) days, the violation shall be subject to prosecution by the
City Attorney and to the penalties of this provision.
   (C)   Penalties: Any person who shall violate this provision shall be
punished by a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not to exceed
five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day which such violation occurs shall
constitute a separate violation. (Ord. 98-27, 7-20-1998)
CHAPTER 2
DRIVEWAY APPROACHES AND CITY SIDEWALKS
SECTION:
I. DRIVEWAY APPROACHES
8-2-1: Permit Required
8-2-2: Application To City Engineering (Building Inspection) Department
8-2-3: Contractor's Bond
8-2-4: Fees Required
8-2-5: Traffic Control And Public Safety
8-2-6: Sidewalks
8-2-7: Graded Surfaces
8-2-8: Specifications
8-2-9: Repairs
8-2-10: Supervision
8-2-11: Exemptions
8-2-12: Authority
8-2-13: Penalty
II. SIDEWALKS
8-2-14: Permit Required
8-2-15: Application To City Engineering Department
8-2-16: Contractor's Bond
8-2-17: Fees Required
8-2-18: Traffic Control And Public Safety
8-2-19: Sidewalks
8-2-20: Graded Surfaces
8-2-21: Specifications
8-2-22: Repairs
8-2-23: Supervision
8-2-24: Exemptions
8-2-25: Authority
8-2-26: Penalty
I. DRIVEWAY APPROACHES
8-2-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to construct or build, any driveway for vehicles over,
across, or upon any public right of way, curb, or sidewalk or that enters or
connects with any public street without first having obtained a separate
driveway permit from the Engineering Department (Building Inspections
Department for new building construction). Failure to obtain a permit prior to
commencement of the work shall result in a stop work order until the proper
permit is obtained. (Ord. 95-11, 4-3-1995)
8-2-2: APPLICATION TO CITY ENGINEERING (BUILDING INSPECTION) DEPARTMENT:
Prior to any work commencing, applications for such permit shall be made to the
Engineering Department and shall set forth:
   (A)   The nature or purpose, and exact location of the work to be done.
   (B)   The date of application, time when the work will commence and the
expected duration of the use or occupancy of any public way or public place
described in the application.
   (C)   The names and addresses of the contractor and owner, and the signature
of the applicant.
   (D)   The fee required.
The permit shall constitute an agreement that the applicant will comply with
all the provisions of this Code relating to the work to be done. (Ord. 95-11,
4-3-1995)
8-2-3: CONTRACTOR'S BOND:
No person shall be issued a permit unless a general contractor's license and
Code compliance bond has been executed and delivered to the City, with a
certificate that said bond is presently in full force and effect in the penal
sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) with good and sufficient sureties to
be approved by the Director of Engineering Services and the City. (Ord. 95-11,
4-3-1995)
8-2-4: FEES REQUIRED:
   (A)   The fee required for all such construction permits shall be twenty
five dollars ($25.00) for residential driveways and approaches. The residential
driveway shall be a maximum width of twenty five feet (25') wide at the curb
line. The fee shall be applicable to original construction and any widening or
replacement.
   (B)   The fee required for all such construction permits shall be thirty
five dollars ($35.00) for commercial, business, or residential special use
driveways. Commercial, business, or residential special use driveways shall be
a maximum of thirty five feet (35') wide at the curb line. The fee shall be
applicable to original construction and any widening or replacement.
   (C)   The fee for a permit issued under a stop work order will be twice the
required fee for each permit. All fees and previous permits must be paid in
full before any permits will be issued. (Ord. 95-11, 4-3-1995)
8-2-5: TRAFFIC CONTROL AND PUBLIC SAFETY:
   (A)   Traffic control shall be in accordance with the applicable sections of
the Illinois Department of Transportation Standard for Road and Bridge
Construction, latest edition, and the applicable guidelines contained in the
Illinois Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways,
latest edition.
   (B)   The permit holder shall insure that the work is performed with minimal
inconvenience and safety hazard to the public. The permit holder shall provide,
erect, and maintain all barricades and signs necessary to protect the work and
the public.
   (C)   No street or alley may be closed or partially closed without the
permission of the City Engineer. Once permission is granted, the contractor
must notify the Police, Fire, and Engineering Departments twenty four (24)
hours in advance of commencing the work. The contractor must also notify those
Departments when the work is completed and the street or alley is reopened.
   (D)   Fire hydrants, gutters, and storm inlets adjacent to the work may not
be obstructed without the permission of the Director of Engineering Services.
(Ord. 95-11, 4-3-1995)
8-2-6: SIDEWALKS:
If any sidewalk is blocked by any such work, an alternate route or a temporary
sidewalk shall be constructed or provided which shall be safe for travel and
convenient for users. (Ord. 95-11, 4-3-1995)
8-2-7: GRADED SURFACES:
No driveway shall be so constructed or graded as to leave a step, sharp
depression, or other obstruction in the sidewalk. The grade shall be the same
as that of the adjoining sidewalk, and in any case the work shall meet the
applicable requirements under the American with Disabilities Act, and the
Illinois Department of Transportation Standards. It shall be unlawful to have
the surface finish of any driveway where it crosses the sidewalk constructed of
such materials as to render it slippery and hazardous to pedestrians, or to
have the grade of such portion vary from the grade of the sidewalk. (Ord. 95-
11, 4-3-1995)
8-2-8: SPECIFICATIONS:
   (A)   Driveways over, across, or upon public right of way shall be
constructed in accordance with specifications adopted by the City Council.
Standard specifications for the improvement shall be maintained on file by the
Director of Engineering Services and available to the public.
   (B)   Work or material not conforming to the applicable specifications may
be rejected at any time within four (4) years after completion of the work,
even though inspected and accepted through oversight or otherwise. (Ord. 95-11,
4-3-1995)
8-2-9: REPAIRS:
It shall be the duty of the property owner maintaining a driveway to keep the
same in good repair where it crosses over, across, or upon public right of way,
and also free from obstructions and openings. (Ord. 95-11, 4-3-1995)
8-2-10: SUPERVISION:
The Director of Engineering Services or his designated representative shall
from time to time inspect all driveway approaches being made over, across, or
upon any public right of way, or other public place in the City to see to the
enforcement of the provisions of this Chapter. Notice shall be given to him at
least twenty four (24) hours in advance of any work to be done in order that
inspection may be provided. (Ord. 95-11, 4-3-1995)
8-2-11: EXEMPTIONS:
The provisions of this Code relative to securing permits shall not apply to
officers or employees of the City engaged in doing work for the City, nor to
persons or corporations which are operating under a franchise or grant from the
City if such franchise provides for the making of excavations and tunnels
without securing a permit therefor. This exemption pertains to the
applications, permits, and fees, but not to the supervision, inspection and
standards prescribed by this Article or specifications. (Ord. 95-11, 4-3-1995)
8-2-12: AUTHORITY:
The Director of Engineering Services shall have authority and it shall be his
duty to exercise his judgement in the public interest, in the issuance of
driveway approach permits, with respect to the size, location, specifications
and timing of construction or other qualifications affecting same. (Ord. 95-11,
4-3-1995)
8-2-13: PENALTY:
Any person convicted of a violation of any section of the Ordinance shall be
subject to the provisions of Section
1-4-1 of this Code. (Ord. 95-11, 4-3-1995)
II. SIDEWALKS
8-2-14: PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to construct or build, any driveway for vehicles over,
across, or upon any public right of way curb, or sidewalk or that enters or
connects with any public street without first having obtained a separate
sidewalk permit from the Engineering Department (Building Inspection Department
for a new building construction). Failure to obtain a permit prior to
commencement of the work shall result in as stop work order until the proper
permit is obtained. (Ord. 95-11, 4-3-1995)
8-2-15: APPLICATION TO CITY ENGINEERING DEPARTMENT:
Prior to any work commencing, applications for such permits shall be made to
the Engineering Department and shall set forth:
   (A)   The nature or purpose, and exact location of the work to be done.
   (B)   The date of application, time when the work will commence and the
expected duration of the use or occupancy of any public way or public place
described in the application.
   (C)   The names and addresses of the contractor and owner, and the signature
of the applicant.
   (D)   The fee required.
The permit shall constitute an agreement that the applicant will comply with
all the provisions of this Code relating to the work to be done. (Ord. 95-11,
4-3-1995)
8-2-16: CONTRACTOR'S BOND:
No person shall be issued a permit unless a general contractor's license and
Code compliance bond has been executed to the City with a certificate that said
bond is presently in full force and effect in the penal sum of five thousand
dollars ($5,000.00) with good and sufficient sureties to be approved by the
Director of Engineering Services and the City. (Ord. 95-11, 4-3-1995)
8-2-17: FEES REQUIRED:
   (A)   The fee required for all such construction permits shall be fifteen
dollars ($15.00) for residential sidewalks. The fee shall be applicable to
original construction and any widening or replacement.
   (B)   The fee required for all such construction permits shall be fifteen
dollars ($15.00) for commercial or business use sidewalks. The fee shall be
applicable to original construction and any widening or replacement.
   (C)   The fee for a permit issued under a stop work order will be twice the
required fee for each permit. All fees and previous permits must be paid in
full before any permits will be issued. (Ord. 95-11, 4-3-1995)
8-2-18: TRAFFIC CONTROL AND PUBLIC SAFETY:
   (A)   Traffic control shall be in accordance with the applicable sections of
the Illinois Department of Transportation Standard for Road and Bridge
Construction, latest edition, and the applicable guidelines contained in the
Illinois Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways,
latest edition.
   (B)   The permit holder shall insure that the work is performed with minimal
inconvenience and safety hazard to the public. The permit holder shall provide,
erect, and maintain all barricades and signs necessary to protect the work and
the public.
   (C)   No street or alley may be closed or partially closed without the
permission of the Director of Engineering Services. Once permission is granted,
the contractor must notify the Police, Fire, and Engineering Department twenty
four (24) hours in advance of commencing the work. The contractor must also
notify those Departments when the work is completed and the street or alley is
reopened.
   (D)   Fire hydrants, gutters, and storm inlets adjacent to the work may not
be obstructed without the permission of the Director of Engineering Services.
(Ord. 95-11, 4-3-1995)
8-2-19: SIDEWALKS:
If any sidewalk is blocked by any such work, an alternate route or a temporary
sidewalk shall be constructed or provided which shall be safe for travel and
convenient for users. (Ord. 95-11, 4-3-1995)
8-2-20: GRADED SURFACES:
No sidewalk shall be so constructed or graded as to leave a step, sharp
depression, or other obstruction in the sidewalk. The grade shall be the same
as that of the adjoining sidewalk, and in any case the work shall meet the
applicable requirements under the American with Disabilities Act, and the
Illinois Department of Transportation Standards. It shall be unlawful to have
the surface finish of any driveway where it crosses the sidewalk constructed of
such materials as to render it slippery and hazardous to pedestrians, or to
have the grade of such portion vary from the grade of the sidewalk. (Ord. 95-
11, 4-3-1995)
8-2-21: SPECIFICATIONS:
   (A)   Sidewalks, over, across, or upon public right of way shall be
constructed in accordance with specifications adopted by the City Council.
Standard specifications for the improvement shall be maintained on file by the
Director of Engineering Services and available to the public.
   (B)   Work or material not conforming to the applicable specifications may
be rejected at any time within four (4) years after completion of the work,
even though inspected and accepted through oversight or otherwise. (Ord. 95-11,
4-3-1995)
8-2-22: REPAIRS:
It shall be the duty of the property owner maintaining a driveway to keep the
same in good repair where it crosses over, across, or upon public right of way,
and also free form obstructions and openings. (Ord. 95-11, 4-3-1995)
8-2-23: SUPERVISION:
The Director of Engineering Services or his designated representative shall
from time to time inspect all sidewalks being made over, across, or upon any
public right of way, or public place in the City to see the enforcement of the
provisions of this Chapter. Notice shall be given to him at least twenty four
(24) hours in advance of any work to be done in order that inspections may be
provided. (Ord. 95-11, 4-3-1995)
8-2-24: EXEMPTIONS:
The provisions of this Code relative to securing permits shall not apply to
officers or employees of the City engaged in doing work for the City, nor to
persons or corporations which are operating under a franchise or grant from the
City if such franchise provides for the making of excavations and tunnels
without securing a permit therefor. This exemption pertains only to the
applications, permits, and fees, but not to the supervision, inspection and
standards prescribed by this Article or specifications. (Ord. 95-11, 4-3-1995)
8-2-25: AUTHORITY:
The Director of Engineering Services shall have authority and it shall be his
duty to exercise his judgement in the public interest, in the issuance of
driveway approach permits, with respect to the size, location, specification
and timing of construction or other qualifications affecting same. (Ord. 95-11,
4-3-1995)
8-2-26: PENALTY:
Any person convicted of a violation of any section of this Ordinance shall be
subject to the provisions of Section
1-4-1 of this Code. (Ord. 95-11, 4-3-1995)
CHAPTER 3
EXCAVATIONS
SECTION:
8-3-1: Permit Required
8-3-2: Application To The Plumbing Inspector
8-3-3: Excavator's Bond
8-3-4: Fees Required
8-3-5: Traffic Control And Public Safety
8-3-6: Manner Of Excavating
8-3-7: Sidewalks
8-3-8: Backfilling And Restoring Surfaces
8-3-9: Backfilling By Private Utilities
8-3-10: Specifications
8-3-11: Supervision
8-3-12: Exemptions
8-3-13: Emergency Work
8-3-14: Authority
8-3-15: Penalty
8-3-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to dig, excavate, remove, cut or in any manner tunnel
under or break the surface of any part of any street, alley, curb, sidewalk, or
public right of way, unless a separate excavation permit to do so has been
issued by the Plumbing Inspector or his designated representative, according to
the conditions of this Chapter. Failure to obtain prior to commencement of the
work will result in a stop work order until the proper permit is obtained.
(Ord. 95-13, 4-3-1995)
8-3-2: APPLICATION TO THE PLUMBING INSPECTOR:
   (A)   Prior to any work commencing, an application for such permit shall be
made to the Plumbing Inspector and shall set forth:
      1.   The nature or purpose, size, and exact location of the work to be
done.
      2.   The date of application, time when the work will commence and the
expected duration of the use or occupancy of any public way or public place
described in the application.
      3.   The names and addresses of the contractor and owner, and the
signature of the applicant.
      4.   The fee required.
   (B)   The permit shall constitute an agreement that the applicant will
comply with all the provisions of this Code relating to the work done.
   (C)   The excavation permit shall be void one hundred eighty (180) days
after the date of issue. From the time the public right of way is excavated,
the permit holder shall work with all possible speed and shall have five (5)
working days to complete his responsibilities. The permit shall be available on
site for inspection at any time upon request by the authorized City officials.
   (D)   A separate excavation permit shall be required for each uninterrupted
alteration of the surface or undersurface of any street, avenue, highway,
alley, curb, or sidewalk, provided that when multiple cuts are made at
approximately the same time one permit fee shall apply for each six hundred
foot (600') section of utility main over which such multiple cuts are made.
(Ord. 95-13, 4-3-1995)
8-3-3: EXCAVATOR'S BOND:
No person shall be issued an excavation permit unless an excavator's license
and Code compliance bond has been executed to the City with a certificate that
said bond is presently in full force and effect in the penal sum of five
thousand dollars ($5,000.00) with good and sufficient sureties to be approved
by the Director of Engineering Services and the City. (Ord. 95-13, 4-3-1995)
8-3-4: FEES REQUIRED:
   (A)   The fee required for each permit issued shall be twenty five dollars
($25.00), payable to the City of East Moline, at the time the permit is issued.
No refunds shall be made on excavation permits.
   (B)   The fee for a permit issued under a stop work order will be twice the
fee required for each permit. All fees and previous permits must be paid in
full before any permits will be issued. (Ord. 95-13, 4-3-1995)
8-3-5: TRAFFIC CONTROL AND PUBLIC SAFETY:
   (A)   Traffic control shall be in accordance with the applicable sections of
the Illinois Department of Transportation Standard for Road and Bridge
Construction, latest edition, and the applicable guidelines contained in the
Illinois Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways,
latest edition.
   (B)   The excavation permit holder shall insure that the work is performed
with minimal inconvenience and safety hazard to the public. The permit holder
shall provide, erect, and maintain all barricades and signs necessary to
protect the work and the public.
   (C)   No street or alley may be closed or partially closed without the
permission of the Director of Engineering Services. Once permission is granted,
the contractor must notify the Police, Fire, and Engineering Departments twenty
four (24) hours in advance of commencing the work. The contractor must also
notify those Departments when the work is completed an the street or alley
reopened. Fire hydrants, gutters, and storm inlets adjacent to the work may not
be obstructed without the permission of the Director of Engineering Services.
(Ord. 95-13, 4-3-1995)
8-3-6: MANNER OF EXCAVATING:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful to make any such excavation or tunnel in any way
contrary to or at variance with the terms of the permit therefor. Proper
bracing shall be maintained to prevent the collapse of adjoining ground. In
order to insure proper backfill, the excavation shall not have any portion of
it which is below the surface and which extends beyond the opening at the
surface.
   (B)   No injury shall be done to any pipes, cables, or conduits in the
making of such excavations or tunnels. Notice shall be given to the City
department or officer charged with the care thereof, or inspection of any
utility exposed to damage or visual condition of the existing conduits,
endangered or affected by the making of any such excavation or tunnel. (Ord.
95-13, 4-3-1995)
8-3-7: SIDEWALKS:
If any sidewalk is blocked by any such work, an alternate route or a temporary
sidewalk shall be constructed or provided which shall be safe for travel and
convenient for users. (Ord. 95-13, 4-3-1995)
8-3-8: BACKFILLING AND RESTORING SURFACES:
   (A)   Any person making any excavation or tunnel in or under any public
street, alley, curb, sidewalk, or public place in the City shall restore the
surface thereof, to its original condition if there was no pavement located
there. Backfill shall be properly tamped down, and any bracing in such tunnel
or excavation shall not be left in the ground.
   (B)   Any opening in a paved or improved portion of a street shall be
repaired and the surface relayed by the applicant in compliance with the
provisions of this Code and subject to the supervision of the Director of
Engineering Services. The permit holder shall be responsible for the proper
backfilling of the excavation for a period of two (2) years after the date the
backfill is completed. This responsibility shall include all costs for
reopening the excavation, correcting the problem causing the settlement, and
replacing the pavement patch.
   (C)   Backfill material within two feet (2') of streets, alleys, curbs,
sidewalks, driveways, and other paved surfaces, with the exception of the top
one foot (1') of the excavation, shall be sand meeting the Illinois Department
of Transportation Specification for Road and Bridge Construction, latest
edition, and the Supplemental Specifications and Recurring Special Provisions,
latest edition, gradation FA-6, or equivalent as approved by the Director of
Engineering Services. The backfill material shall be thoroughly compacted in
accordance with the Illinois Department of Transportation Specification for
Road and Bridge Construction, latest edition, and the Supplemental
Specifications and Recurring Special Provisions, latest edition, or by methods
approved by the Director of Engineering Services.
   (D)   Backfill for areas beyond more than two feet (2') from the paved
surfaces shall be earthen material free from broken concrete, asphalt, large
rocks, or other debris. The backfill material shall be thoroughly compacted in
accordance with the Illinois Department of Transportation Specification for
Road and Bridge Construction, latest edition, and the Supplemental
Specifications and Recurring Special Provisions, latest edition, or by methods
approved by the Director of Engineering Services.
   (E)   Surface restoration at paved surfaces shall be the responsibility of
the permit holder. Temporary pavement patching on all pavement excavations
shall be done within two (2) working days after completion of the work in the
excavation. The temporary patches shall conform to the following minimum
standards:
      1.   Streets and alley patches:
Two inches (2") of well compacted, cold-mix asphalt placed on six inches (6")
of well compacted CA-6.
      2.   Driveways and sidewalks:
Two inches (2") of well compacted, cold-mix asphalt.
   (F)   The permit holder is responsible for maintaining the temporary patches
for a period of not more than six (6) months. During this maintenance period,
the permit holder shall make any repairs within two (2) working days after
notification by the City. If the permit holder fails to make the necessary
repairs within the two (2) working day period, the City will make the repairs
and charge the permit holder for all the costs incurred for such repairs.
   (G)   Surface restoration for areas disturbed outside of paved areas by the
construction shall be restored in like condition prior to the excavation. (Ord.
95-13, 4-3-1995)
8-3-9: BACKFILLING BY PRIVATE UTILITIES:
Private utility companies shall be responsible for backfilling, restoration and
safeguarding excavations made by the companies in street rights of way, and
also backfilling and safeguarding excavations made on boulevards or other City
property. Said companies shall be liable for the maintenance of backfilling and
restoration for a period of forty eight (48) months after the date of
acceptance by the City for said excavations, and shall hold the City harmless
for all claims for damages that may result because of the excavations during
said period. Backfilling and restoration shall be done in accordance with
specifications provided by the Director of Engineering Services. The sinking or
deterioration within the aforesaid period of months shall be held to be the
responsibility of the utility company, who shall upon direction of the Director
of Engineering Services re-excavate and properly refill and resurface said
street cut. (Ord. 95-13, 4-3-1995)
8-3-10: SPECIFICATIONS:
Excavations across or upon public right of ways shall be constructed in
accordance with specifications adopted by the City Council. Standard
specifications for the improvement shall be maintained on file by the Director
of Engineering Services and available to the public. (Ord. 95-13, 4-3-1995)
8-3-11: SUPERVISION:
The Director of Engineering Services or his designated representative shall
from time to time inspect all excavations and tunnels being made in or under
any public street, alley, curb, sidewalk, or other public place in the City to
see to the enforcement of the provisions of this Chapter. Notice shall be given
to the Director of Engineering Services or his agent at least twenty four (24)
hours before work of refilling any such excavation or tunnel commences. (Ord.
95-13, 4-3-1995)
8-3-12: EXEMPTIONS:
The provisions of this Code relative to securing permits shall not apply to
officers or employees of City engaged in doing work for the City, nor to
persons or corporations which are operating under a franchise or grant from the
City, if such franchise provides for the making of excavations and tunnels
without securing a permit therefor. This exemption pertains only to the
applications, permits, and fees, but not to the supervision, inspection and
standards prescribed by this Article or specifications. (Ord. 95-13, 4-3-1995)
8-3-13: EMERGENCY WORK:
Excavations shall be allowed at any time for emergency repairs to the public
utilities by the City, its contractor, or private utilities having a valid
franchise with the City by the respective utility company or its contractor
under the following conditions:
   (A)   The repairs shall be of an emergency nature only and shall not
constitute normal maintenance to the utility or extension thereof.
   (B)   Immediate notification must be given to the Police and Fire
Departments for any street or alley closure.
   (C)   Notice shall be given to the Director of Engineering Services at the
first available opportunity during normal City working hours stating the
location of the work, the nature of the emergency, and when said work will be
completed and back to normal conditions.
   (D)   Removal and replacement of pavement and traffic control for the
duration of the closing shall be in accordance with the applicable sections of
the Code of Ordinances. (Ord. 95-13, 4-3-1995)
8-3-14: AUTHORITY:
The Director of Engineering Services shall have authority and it shall be his
duty to exercise his judgement in the public interest, in the issuance of
excavation permits, with respect to the size, location, specifications, and
timing on excavations or other qualifications affecting same. (Ord. 95-13, 4-3-
1995)
8-3-15: PENALTY:
Any person convicted of a violation of any section of this Ordinance shall be
subject to the provisions of Section
1-4-1 of this Code. (Ord. 95-13, 4-3-1995)
CHAPTER 4
RAILROAD REGULATIONS
SECTION:
8-4-1: Train Crossings
8-4-1: TRAIN CROSSINGS:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for a railroad corporation to permit any train,
railroad car or engine to obstruct public travel at a railroad or highway grade
crossing for a period in excess of ten (10) minutes, except where such train,
railroad car or engine cannot be moved by reason of circumstances over which
the railroad corporation has no control.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any railroad employee to wilfully or
intentionally permit any train, railroad car or engine to obstruct public
travel at a railroad or highway grade crossing for a period in excess of ten
(10) minutes, except where such train, railroad car or engine cannot be moved
by reason of circumstances over which the railroad employee has no control.
However, no employee acting under the rules or orders of the railroad
corporation or its supervisory personnel may be prosecuted for such violations.
   (C)   Any railroad corporation violating, or any railroad employee violating
this Section shall be fined not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 73-41, 10-15-1973)
CHAPTER 5
TREES AND SHRUBS
SECTION:
8-5-1: License
8-5-2: Clean-Up
8-5-3: City Property
8-5-4: Unsafe Conditions
8-5-5: Injury
8-5-6: Advertisements And Notices
8-5-7: Excavations
8-5-8: Wires
8-5-9: Penalties
8-5-1: LICENSE:
   (A)   No person engaged in the business of trimming trees shall trim,
remove, feed or treat in any manner any trees standing in any street, alley,
parkway, boulevard or other public or private place in the City without first
obtaining a tree trimmer's license from the City Clerk. The license fee for
such a business or occupation shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) per year. The
license shall commence on the first day of May in each year. Any person being
issued a tree trimmer's license shall first provide a copy of his/her
