insurance, good for the term of one year, but not necessarily to coincide with
the term of the license. Said insurance shall be from a reputable insurance
agent authorized to do business in the State of Illinois and cover public
liability of twenty five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) per person, fifty
thousand dollars ($50,000.00) per accident and twenty thousand dollars
($20,000.00) liability coverage for property damage. In addition thereto, said
applicant shall provide proof of workman's compensation coverage for each
employee. (Ord. 93-37, 6-7-1993)
   (B)   The provisions of this Section shall not apply to:
      1.   The United States of America, the State, County or the City, any
department, bureau or agency of any of the foregoing or any official
representative of any of the foregoing in the pursuit of his official duties.
      2.   Any person who engages in tree trimming as defined above on his own
premises.
      3.   Any public utility, including its authorized employees and agents,
when engaged in tree trimming for the purpose of line clearance and in order to
ensure the continuity of utility service to the public. (Ord. 90-5, 3-5-1990)
8-5-2: CLEAN-UP:
Any person licensed pursuant to this Chapter shall immediately, and at his own
expense, remove all tree trunks, limbs, branches, twigs or brush and properly
dispose of same in accordance with State and local laws. In addition thereto,
the licensee shall remove any stumps, fill in depressions, or remove any other
hazards caused by his/her actions. (Ord. 90-5, 3-5-1990)
8-5-3: CITY PROPERTY:
Any person, including each licensee, shall obtain permission from the Director
of Maintenance Services for each tree to be removed, cut, trimmed, or planted
when such tree is or will be located on City property or such tree is owned by
the City or its departments. (Ord. 90-5, 3-5-1990)
8-5-4: UNSAFE CONDITIONS:
   (A)   Any person who is found operating, or creating a condition which is
dangerous, unsafe, unsanitary or a menace to life, health, or property, or has
engaged in the business of trimming trees without a proper license or permit,
shall be ordered by the Director of Maintenance Services to immediately stop
work and correct the said situation.
   (B)   Whenever it has appeared to the Director of Maintenance Services that
the licensee has created or maintained any condition which is dangerous,
unsafe, unsanitary, or a menace to life, health, or property, or has done
business without proper license or permit, the Director of Maintenance Services
shall direct and mail an order in writing by certified mail to the licensee
directing him/her to correct the defect or omission within twenty (20) days
from the receipt of the notice.
   (C)   No applicant for the license required by Section
8-5-1 of this Chapter who is subject to an order issued under subsection (A) of
this Section shall be entitled to such license until compliance is demonstrated
to the satisfaction of the Director of Maintenance Services. (Ord. 90-5, 3-5-
1990)
8-5-5: INJURY:
It shall be unlawful to injure any tree or shrub planted in any public place.
(Ord. 90-5, 3-5-1990)
8-5-6: ADVERTISEMENTS AND NOTICES:
It shall be unlawful to attach any sign, advertisement, or notice to any tree
or shrub in any street, parkway, or other public place. (Ord. 90-5, 3-5-1990)
8-5-7: EXCAVATIONS:
In making excavations in streets or other public places proper care shall be
taken to avoid injury to the roots of any tree or shrub, whenever possible.
(Ord. 90-5, 3-5-1990)
8-5-8: WIRES:
Any person or company given the right to maintain poles and wires in the
streets, alleys, or other public places in the City shall, in the absence of
provision in the franchise concerning the subject, keep such wires and poles
free from and away from any trees or shrubs far away as may be possible. Said
party shall also keep all such trees and shrubs properly trimmed so that no
injury shall be done to the poles or wires or shrubs and trees by their contact
with each other. (Ord. 90-5, 3-5-1990)
8-5-9: PENALTIES:
Any person(s) violating any part of this Ordinance shall be subject to a fine
of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00) for each occurrence. (Ord. 90-5, 3-5-1990)
CHAPTER 6
PUBLIC BENCHES
SECTION:
8-6-1: Definitions
8-6-2: Location Restrictions
8-6-3: Permit Required
8-6-4: License Period; Permit Fee
8-6-5: Revocation
8-6-6: Construction
8-6-7: Maintenance
8-6-8: Advertising
8-6-9: Supervision
8-6-10: Location Of Benches
8-6-11: Indemnity Agreement
8-6-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of
this Chapter:
BENCH: A seat located upon public property along any public highway for the
accommodation of passersby awaiting transportation.
STREET: Any public thoroughfare, or way including the sidewalk, the parkway and
any public property bordering upon a public way. (M.C. 1962, sec. 27.501)
8-6-2: LOCATION RESTRICTIONS:
It shall be unlawful to install, erect or maintain any bench in any of the
following locations:
   (A)   In any alley.
   (B)   At any place where the distance from the face of the curb to the
property line is less than eight feet (8').
   (C)   At any location more than fifty feet (50') from the nearest
intersecting street; provided, that whenever, in the opinion of the Mayor and
City Council, observance of this requirement would result in inconvenience or
hardship, this requirement may be waived by the Mayor and City Council.
   (D)   On any street or highway except at an established bus stop.
   (E)   At any place or places which the Mayor and City Council may from time
to time specify. (M.C. 1962, sec. 7.502)
8-6-3: PERMIT REQUIRED:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to install, erect or maintain any
bench in the City without first securing a license therefor. A separate permit
must be obtained for each bench, which shall be valid only for a particular
location specified thereon. Each permit shall bear a separate number and not
more than two (2) permits shall be issued for any one location.
   (B)   No bench permit shall be issued except upon written application
showing proposed location of each bench, the advertising, if any, to appear
thereon and such other information as the Mayor and City Council may require.
   (C)   Detailed plans and specifications of each bench must be supplied by
the applicant. No installation will be permitted which will cause damage to the
property of the City.
   (D)   No permit shall be issued if the City Council shall find that the
maintenance of the bench should tend to obstruct the passage along any public
way, or create a hazard or would otherwise be detrimental to the public safety,
welfare or convenience. (M.C. 1962, sec. 27.503)
8-6-4: LICENSE PERIOD; PERMIT FEE:
Each permit shall expire on April 30 next following the date of issuance.
Annual permit fee shall be five dollars ($5.00) for each bench. Application for
renewal must be made prior to expiration date and must be accompanied by the
renewal fee. (M.C. 1962, sec. 27.504)
8-6-5: REVOCATION:
Any permit may be revoked or renewal thereof denied for any violation of any of
the provisions of this Chapter, for any fraud or misrepresentation in the
application, or any other reason, the issuance or revocation of the permit
being in full discretion of the City Council as to the number of permits and
renewal thereof. If any permit is revoked or renewal thereof denied in
accordance with the provisions of this Chapter, the permittee shall remove the
bench from public property within ten (10) days from the date he is so ordered,
the City may remove and store the bench at the permittee's expense.
Any permit issued under this Chapter shall be cancelled and revoked if the
permittee fails to install a bench within sixty (60) days after date of
issuance of the permit. (M.C. 1962, sec. 27.505)
In addition to any penalty imposed hereunder for the violation of any
provisions of this Chapter, the Mayor and City Council may revoke any such
permit. (M.C. 1962, sec. 27.513)
8-6-6: CONSTRUCTION:
No permittee shall locate or maintain any bench at a point less than eighteen
inches (18"), or more than thirty inches (30") from the face of the curb, and
each bench shall be kept parallel with the curb.
No bench shall be more than forty two inches (42") high, nor more than two feet
six inches (2'6") wide, nor more than seven feet (7') long over-all.
Each bench must have displayed thereon in a conspicuous place the name of the
permittee and the permit number. (M.C. 1962, sec. 27.506)
8-6-7: MAINTENANCE:
It shall be the duty of the permittee to maintain each bench at all times in
safe condition at its proper location, and to inspect each bench periodically.
(M.C. 1962, sec. 27.507)
8-6-8: ADVERTISING:
No advertising matter or sign whatever shall be displayed on any bench, except
on the front and rear surfaces of the back rest, and not have more than seventy
five percent (75%) of each such surface used.
No advertisement or sign on any bench shall display the words "Stop", "Look",
"Drive-In", or any other word, phrase, symbol or character calculated to
interfere, mislead or distract traffic. (M.C. 1962, sec. 27.508)
8-6-9: SUPERVISION:
The Building Inspector shall supervise the maintenance and erection of all
benches licensed hereunder. (M.C. 1962, sec. 27.509)
8-6-10: LOCATION OF BENCHES:
The Mayor and City Council shall designate locations where such benches shall
be erected and reserve the right to change, alter or amend designation of said
location as public convenience and necessity may from time to time require.
(M.C. 1962, sec. 27.510)
8-6-11: INDEMNITY AGREEMENT:
No bench permit or permits shall be issued hereunder unless applicant shall
post with the City Clerk a public liability bond as may be approved by the
Mayor and City Council.
Such public liability bond shall provide that the permittee will indemnify and
save harmless the City, its officers, agents and employees from any loss, cost,
damages, expenses or like, which may result or arise out of the granting the
permit or permits on the existence, installation or maintenance of the bench
for which the permit is issued, and that permittee will pay all loss or damage
that may arise out of such existence, installation or maintenance. The said
insurance policy shall be maintained in its original amount by the permittee at
his own expense, at all times during the period for which the permit is in
effect. In the event that two (2) or more permits are issued to one permittee,
one such policy of insurance shall be of such a type, coverage shall be
automatically restored immediately from and after the report of any accident
from which liability shall thereafter occur.
The limit of liability of any such bond shall be in no case less than fifteen
thousand dollars ($15,000.00) for bodily injury or death of one person, and
five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) for property damage. The permissible limits
of the liability for bodily injury or death of more than one person and the
limits of liability for property damage shall depend on the number of bench
permits covered thereby, and shall not be less than the amounts specified in
the following schedule:
 
Number Of Bench Permits Limits Of Public Liability Limits Of Property Damage
   1 to 10           $ 30,000.00                $5,000.00
   11 to 50          40,000.00                  5,000.00
   51 to 100         60,000.00                  5,000.00
   101 or more       100,000.00                 5,000.00
 
(M.C. 1962, sec. 27.511)
CHAPTER 7
CITY PARKS
SECTION:
8-7-1: Administration
8-7-2: Rules And Regulations
8-7-3: Tobacco Free Parks
8-7-1: ADMINISTRATION:
All City parks, lots or lands, heretofore or hereafter devised or bequeathed to
the City or purchased by the City shall be administered by and shall be under
the control of the Park Board which is provided for in Title 2, Chapter 14 of
this Code. (M.C. 1962, sec. 11.701)
8-7-2: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The Park Board shall make and enforce whatever rules and regulations it deems
necessary for the proper use of each of the City's parks. However, the
following regulations shall be in effect for all City parks and any violation
thereof shall be punishable by a fine of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) and
not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00):
No person or persons shall:
   1.   Permit dogs, cats or other animals on the premises, nor allow animals
to enter fenced-in areas, except for special functions, as authorized by the
Director Of Maintenance Services.
   2.   Carry or discharge firearms, fireworks, bows and arrows or slingshots,
unless duly authorized by City officials.
   3.   Cut, mark, break, climb upon, or in any way injure or deface trees,
shrubs, plants, buildings, fences, bridges or other structures or property on
the premises.
   4.   Remove from the premises sod, trees or plants, or other movable
property, or to pick flowers of any kind on any such premises.
   5.   Race with horses, bicycles, automobiles, minibikes, motorcycles, or
other vehicles, boats or animals; or drive or ride on drives on any such
premises at more than fifteen (15) miles per hour, except in Northeast Park
where said speed limit shall be ten (10) miles per hour, or unless otherwise
posted.
   6.   Sell, be in possession, or be under the influence of any intoxicating
beverages, hallucinogenic drugs or cannabis. The Park Board and City Council
may authorize the sale of alcoholic beverages in a park or parks. Consumption
of alcohol in a park must be limited to alcohol purchased from a vendor
licensed to sell alcohol in the park by the City with a valid liquor license
authorizing such sale.
   7.   Lie or sleep on tables or benches on the premises.
   8.   Distribute circulars or advertisements, or post notices, bills or other
paper upon any structures or trees on any such premises, or to advertise by any
other means.
   9.   Take any bird eggs or bird nests, fish in the lagoons, unless permitted
at such times as designated by the Director of Maintenance Services or other
authorities; or kill, or disturb any waterfowl, birds or wildlife.
   10.   Light any fires on the property, other than established fireplaces.
   11.   Drive or park any motorized vehicles other than on a roadway or
parking area.
   12.   Ride a bicycle in any playground area.
   13.   Be on the premises, unless otherwise designated or authorized, and
under proper supervision, between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and
seven o'clock (7:00) A.M., unless as otherwise posted. The enclosed playground
areas shall be opened and closed at the discretion of the Director of
Maintenance Services and any person being found within such closed areas shall
be in violation of this Chapter.
      The bicycle path and walkway shall be closed to all persons before the
hour of six o'clock (6:00) A.M. and after the hour of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M.
   14.   Be permitted to bring into or upon park and recreational properties
refuse of any kind, including undesirable plant life or discarded appliances.
   15.   Enter any area or portion of any area designated as restricted by
signs or notices without the consent of the director of maintenance services.
   16.   Be allowed to display language or conduct deemed disorderly, nor
engage in acts of vandalism.
   17.   Sell or offer to sell to any person, food, refreshments, or be a
vendor of any salable products without the approval by written permit, and by
contractual agreement with the park recreation board or its authorized agents.
   18.   Play or participate in a baseball or softball game, except in those
areas designated as ball diamonds.
   19.   Play radio or recording devices in a loud manner so as to disturb or
annoy other patrons of a city park. (Ord. 78-15, 4-17-1978; Ord. 93-52, 10-18-
1993; Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999; Ord. 05-31, 10-17-2005; Ord. 23-06, 3-20-2023)
8-7-3: TOBACCO FREE PARKS:
   (A)   Tobacco Products Prohibited. No Person shall be permitted to use
tobacco products, including electronic nicotine delivery systems, in any City
park at all times under the jurisdiction of the park board.
   (B)   Locations. Locations of prohibition include but are not limited to:
      1.   Butterworth Park
      2.   Cottage Grove Baseball Diamond
      3.   Cottage Grove Tot Lot
      4.   Empire Park
      5.   Fire Station Tot Lot
      6.   Garfield Tot Lot
      7.   Hereford Park
      8.   Lincoln Tot Lot
      9.   Millennium Park
      10.   Mitchell Park
      11.   Jacobs Northeast Park Sports Complex
      12.   James C. Officer Park
      13.   Radden Park
      14.   Watertown Memorial Park
      15.   WimanPark
   (C)   Posting of Signs. A sign indicating “NO SMOKING” must be placed at
every City park entrance and noticeably placed throughout the City parks. The
park board will deem appropriate areas for all signs in all parks.
   (D)   Exemption. Tobacco products are permitted in parking lots adjacent to
City parks. Tobacco products may be used in City parks as part of a Native
American spiritual or cultural ceremony. Approval from the City of East Moline
administration must be requested and received prior to the ceremony.
   (E)   Enforcement.
      1.   Signage will be posted at strategic locations.
      2.   The community, faculty users and staff will be notified of this
Ordinance.
      3.   Enforcement of
8-7-3 is a shared responsibility of City staff and City park patrons.
      4.   The City will make periodic observations to monitor for compliance.
      5.   Any individual in violation of
8-7-3 will be informed of policy and asked to comply. If the violator refuses
to comply they will be subjected to ejection from the City park.
   (F)   Penalty. Any person violating
8-7-3 shall be subject to a mandatory fine as follows: not less than fifty
dollars ($50.00) plus court costs nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) plus court costs for a first offense; not less than one hundred
dollars ($100.00) plus court costs nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) plus court costs for a second offense; not less than two hundred
dollars ($200.00) plus court costs nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) plus court costs for a third or subsequent offense.
   (G)   Definitions as used in this section:
 
AT ALL TIMES:                        At all hours every day.
                                     All facilities controlled by East Moline
                                     for recreation purposes including but not
CITY PARKS:                          limited to: playgrounds, trails, open
                                     space, plazas, athletic fields, restrooms,
                                     concession areas or bleachers.
                                     Includes all products containing or

                                     other substance intended for human

                                     inhalation of aerosol or vapor from the

                                     limited to: e-cigarettes, e-cigars, e-

                                     cigarettes, cigars, cigarillos, chewing
                                     tobacco, snuff, electronic nicotine
                                     delivery systems and any other forms of

CHAPTER 8

8-8-1: CREATION OF DEPARTMENT:
There is hereby created a water and sewer department of the city, which shall
consist of officers and employees as may be assigned to the water and sewer
department, with the approval of the mayor and city council. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-
1999)
8-8-2: MANAGEMENT:
   (A)   City Administrator: The city administrator oversees and coordinates
activities in the water and sewer departments. The city administrator shall be
held strictly responsible for the efficient and economical operation of the
water and sewer departments, and shall have full control of all employees
within said departments, and with their employment and discharge, with the
consent and approval of the mayor and city council.
   (B)   Director Of Maintenance Services: The director of maintenance services
oversees and coordinates the activities of the water distribution department,
including the reading of meters, and the sewerage collection and drainage
departments.
   (C)   City Finance Director: The city finance director oversees the
management and supervision of the water and sewer billing responsibilities. The
city finance director shall, pursuant to his/her authority under 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/3.1-10-45, appoint various clerks and subordinates to
perform water and sewer billing responsibilities, as the city council may from
time to time authorize, and shall be held responsible, severally, for the
fidelity of all persons so appointed by the City Finance Director.
   (D)   Director Of Engineering Services: The Director of Engineering Services
oversees and coordinates the installation of water, sewer and drainage systems.
He shall keep a correct map of all the water, sewer and drainage systems now or
hereafter laid in said City with a record of their dimensions, location and
connection, hydrants, valves and manholes. It shall be his duty to see to the
enforcement of the laws and ordinances relating to the water, sewer and
drainage systems of the City.
   (E)   Director Of Water Filtration: The Director of Water Filtration
oversees and coordinates the processing of drinking water from the Mississippi
River to the time it is distributed for consumption.
   (F)   Superintendent Of Wastewater Treatment: The Superintendent of
Wastewater Treatment oversees and coordinates the processing of sewage from the
time it reaches the sewer plant until it is processed for return to the river.
   (G)   Certification: The Director of Water Filtration and the Superintendent
of the wastewater treatment plant or their representative shall obtain
certification, as required by the State of Illinois Department of Public
Health, or the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-
1999)
8-8-3: BONDS OF EMPLOYEES:
The City Council shall require of all employees, as they may deem proper, good
and sufficient bond for their faithful performance of duties, the amount
thereof to be fixed and approved by the City Council. The premiums shall be
paid out of the funds of the Water and Sewer Departments, respectively, and
such bonds shall run in the name of the City and shall be filed with the City
Finance Director. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-4: RULES AND REGULATIONS OF THE WATER AND SEWER DEPARTMENTS:
The following rules and regulations shall be considered a part of the contract
with every customer of City water, sanitary sewer and drainage; said customer
or user shall be governed by and subject to the rules and regulations set out
in this Chapter. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-5: PERMIT FOR WATER SERVICE CONNECTIONS:
   (A)   Required: Permit for water service connections must be obtained at the
office of the Plumbing Inspector by the owner or agent of the property to be
served. Such permit shall state the official street address of the premises,
the size of the pipe required and the approximate location where such services
shall enter the premises. No work is to commence until the permit is issued.
   (B)   Water Services: Only the following types of material shall be used in
all water services, from the distribution main to the metering device: type "K"
copper, brass, or ductile iron. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-6: SERVICE CONNECTIONS:
The making of all service connections and the laying of pipes, setting of water
service fixtures in streets, public grounds and in premises to be served by
City water, shall be made by duly licensed plumbers under the supervision of
the Plumbing Inspector of the City. Each plumber must have a current bond on
file with the City and must have a current State of Illinois plumbing license.
This Section does not prohibit City employees from performing necessary
plumbing repairs and connections as referenced above. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-7: SERVICE TAPS:
No service taps shall be made on new mains until the main has been tested for
pressure and bacteria and approved by the City and/or the Illinois
Environmental Protection Agency, Division of Public Water Supply. No service
taps shall be made unless first authorized by the City's Plumbing Inspector and
when so authorized, shall be made as required by the plumbing ordinance in
effect in the City. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-8: NO ALTERATIONS OR ADDITIONS OF SERVICE PIPES WITHOUT PERMIT:
After a service connection has been laid, no plumber or other person shall make
any attachment or connection to it to serve other premises so as to connect the
same with the City water system unless he shall procure a written permit from
the Plumbing Inspector, specifying the particular additions, repairs, or
alterations to be made, and shall perform such work in conformity with such
permit, ordinances of the City and rules and regulations of the City Water and
Sewer Department. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-9: NO SPRINKLER OR FIRE PROTECTION SERVICE UNTIL CONNECTION IS TESTED:
City water will not be turned on to any sprinkler or fire protection service
unless all pipes in connection with such system are left exposed until pressure
tested. The Water and Sewer Department must be notified in order that its
representative shall be present to perform the required bacteria tests. The
proper approved backflow device must be in place, tested and certified. The
device must be no farther than three feet (3') from the outside wall. (Ord. 99-
10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-10: SEPARATE CONNECTIONS:
There shall be separate service pipes laid from the main to each building
wherever there is a water main laid in front, at the rear or at the side of
such building. Such service pipes shall be laid on a straight line at right
angles to the water main and connections made within two (2) lines drawn
parallel to the sides of the building to be served or within three feet (3')
thereof. Where services are laid to premises where there are no water mains
available for direct connection, a small temporary main will be permitted to be
laid as hereinafter provided under Section
8-8-11 of this Chapter. In all cases such building served must have an
independent service shutoff. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-11: TEMPORARY MAINS:
   (A)   Pipe laid temporarily in the streets where there are no water mains,
must be laid in the line where water mains may be laid in the future, and if
under four inches (4") in size the service pipe must be of approved material
from the main to the shutoff, and shall be copper pipe from shutoff to the
premises to be served. Four inch (4") pipe or larger, shall be ductile cast
iron, or approved AWWA plastic (for temporary mains only). The location of the
meter shall be designated by the City's Plumbing Inspector.
   (B)   Temporary mains shall be laid at the expense of the party to be
served.
   (C)   The permit for any temporary main shall provide that the size of such
main shall be designated by the Director Of Engineering Services subject to the
approval of the Council and shall be of a size as to allow other party
connections to be made to such main if requested by intervening property
owners, or to allow any further extension which may be deemed necessary by the
Director Of Engineering Services.
   (D)   If a request is made to the City Finance Director for permission to
connect onto such main, the City Finance Director shall, before granting such
permission, require such person to pay a just and equitable amount to the
person who laid such main under the original permit.
   (E)   If at any future time the City deems it necessary to extend its
regular water service on any street or alley and paralleling such temporary
main, then all consumers being served by such temporary main shall abandon
their service connection with such temporary main. Such connection shall be
made within thirty (30) days after completion of such water service. (Ord. 99-
10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-12: YARD HYDRANTS, SPRINKLING PLUGS AND SILL COCKS:
Yard hydrants, sprinkling plugs, and sill cocks will not be allowed on water
service connections now installed or to be hereafter installed unless such yard
hydrant, sprinkling plug or sill cock is connected in such a manner that the
water consumed through such yard hydrant, sprinkling plug or sill cock shall
first pass through the water meter on such service, and must meet any and all
cross-connection control backflow connection codes. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-13: SERVICE CURB BOX AND STOP:
   (A)   Stop Box And Shutoff: A curb stop box and shutoff for controlling the
supply of water to consumers shall be placed on every service. When connections
are made in streets or avenues, the stop box shall be placed twelve inches
(12") outside the property line and when made in alleys, on the lot line. The
cover of said stop box shall be maintained by the property owner at the same
height as the sidewalk or the surrounding ground. Any variation in the location
for setting of such stop boxes, as herein provided for, shall be made only when
authorized by the Plumbing Inspector. The stop box used shall be of a design
approved by the Plumbing Inspector or Director Of Maintenance Services and must
have an unobstructed opening at least one inch (1") in diameter and fitted with
a substantial cover on which shall be marked the word "Water" in raised
letters. Any curb box which is to be surrounded by anything other than earth,
shall have an approved curb box receptacle installed.
   (B)   Stop Valve: Every service pipe must also have a stop valve placed in
the building within twelve inches (12") of the point where the pipe enters the
building. Said stop must have a full flow ball and/or gate valve, and be kept
in working order at all times, by the property owner, so that the water may be
shut off by the occupant of the premises. There shall also be a full flow ball
and/or gate valve placed on the outlet side of the water meter, not more than
twelve inches (12") from the meter, so that the meter can be taken out or
replaced without draining the pipe system in the building.
   (C)   Curb Box Stop Requirements: All curb box stops on the line of service
must have round ways of the same diameter as the pipe with which they are
placed, and with proper tee head and rods for turning on and off, and of a make
and pattern approved by the City's Plumbing Inspector. Services larger than one
inch (1") shall have a value in compliance with the Plumbing Ordinance. Any and
all curb box stops should be of the "ori-seal" design.
   (D)   Outside Meter Vault And Shutoff: Whenever a meter cannot be set on the
premises without danger of freezing, difficulty of reading, or for any other
cause as determined by the Water and Sewer Department, the Director of
Maintenance Services may demand the installation of an outside meter vault and
shutoff, type to be designated by the City's Plumbing Inspector.
   (E)   Conformance: Owners of premises having water services which do not
have separate curb boxes and stops for each building and or address, or which
otherwise do not conform to the requirements in this Ordinance at the time of
its passage shall be required to put in such curb box stops or make such other
changes as are necessary to conform to these requirements when so instructed by
the Plumbing Inspector.
   (F)   Control: The outside shutoff shall be under the sole control of the
City Water and Sewer Department and no person except an employee or person
specially authorized by the City Water and Sewer Department shall open the
cover of such box, or turn on or off water. Provided, however, that licensed
and bonded plumbers may turn on or off water for testing plumbing or making
repairs, but whenever so used the shutoff must be left closed if found closed,
and open if found open by the plumber who uses it.
   (G)   Locations; Maintenance: The stop box on every service must be kept
flush with the surrounding ground or sidewalk surface, and must be visible from
the sidewalk. The valves, curb box and shutoff must be kept in good condition
and ready for use at all times by the property owner. Should the property owner
neglect to maintain such valves, curb box stop and shutoff in proper condition,
and if the curb box stop is found to be out of repair at any time, the City
Water Department shall have the right to clean or repair the same when needed
upon giving notice, and charge the cost thereof to the owner, and if payment is
refused may turn off the water in the service until the same is paid. The City
will not be responsible for any damage due to the breaking of a service or curb
box stop, done while setting, or repairing a water meter.
   (H)   Responsibility In Turning On Water: In turning on water, the City of
East Moline or the City Water And Sewer Department shall not be responsible for
any damage that may occur by reason of open or improper connections, or for any
other causes. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-14: NO CONNECTION BETWEEN SERVICES:
When there are two (2) or more services on the premises, the piping from each
service must be kept separate, and no connection shall be made from one to the
other. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-15: DEPTH OF SERVICE PIPE:
Service pipes must be laid at least four and one-half feet (41/2') below the
surface of the ground. When pipes are laid in streets or grounds subject to
fixed grades, where the surface of the ground is higher than the established
grades, they shall be so laid that they will be at least four and one-half feet
(41/2') below the established grade, except in sandy soil formation in which
case the Plumbing Inspector may require pipes to be laid to a depth of at least
five feet (5') below the established grade. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-16: MAINTENANCE OF SERVICE PIPES:
All service pipes and appurtenances from the water main to the premises,
including the corporation cocks at the mains shall be installed and maintained
at the expense of the property owners, and any leaks or other defects in the
same shall be promptly repaired by the property owners, or if not promptly
repaired the water shall be turned off until such repairs have been made, and
the expense thereof shall be charged against such owner, and must be paid
before water shall be turned on again. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-17: EMERGENCY WATER LEAKS:
In the event of any leak or other defect occurring which endangers the public
health or safety, the City Plumbing Inspector shall give the property owner
twenty four (24) hour notice to repair said defect, and in the event repair is
not made within said twenty four (24) hours, then the City may hire a licensed
plumber to make said repair, which cost shall be assessed against the owner.
(Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-18: FAILURE OF SUPPLY:
The City shall not be held responsible for any damages resulting from the
failure of the water supply. The City reserves the right to prohibit and
control water usage when in the judgment of the City it shall be necessary to
do so. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-19: ABANDONED OR UNUSED SERVICE PIPES:
All water and sewer laterals that may become useless because of installation of
larger or other new services, or because water or sewer will be no longer used
through them, must be permanently disconnected at the respective mains at the
expense of the owner of the premises, and so reported to the City's Plumbing
Inspector and Maintenance Services Department.
If a service pipe or connection, which is not being used, is found to be
leaking, the City's Maintenance Services Department may with proper notice,
repair or turn off the same, and charge the expense thereof to the owner of
property for which the repair was made. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-20: RIGHT TO SHUT OFF WATER:
The City may, when necessary, without notice, shut the water off in its mains
for the purpose of making repairs, extensions, or for other purposes. No claims
shall be made against the City by reason of the breakage of any service pipe or
service connection or from any other damage that may result from shutting off
water. The City Water and Sewer Department shall also have the right to shut
off water services for the nonpayment of bills by the giving of due notice of
at least ten (10) days.
If at any future time the City deems it necessary to extend its regular water
service on any street or alley and paralleling a temporary main, then all
consumers being served by such temporary main shall abandon their service
connection with the temporary main. The connection shall be made within thirty
(30) days after completion of such water service. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-21: APPLICATION FOR WATER AND/OR SEWER SERVICE METER:
   (A)   Location Within City Limits: All properties connected to City
utilities must be within the City limits. If not, prior to application the
property must be annexed to the City, or if not contiguous, a preannexation
agreement must be signed. Properties within the corporate boundaries of another
municipality are exempted from the requirements of this subsection.
   (B)   Form; Record: Application for water and/or sewer, and for the
installation of the water meter shall be made at the Finance Department office
upon blanks furnished by said office. The Finance Department office shall at
once make a record of such application in a file kept for that purpose. Every
application for water and/or sewer shall state that the same is taken subject
to all rules and regulations then in force or that may thereafter be adopted
for the government of the Water and Sewer Department.
   (C)   Owner To Sign All Applications; Deposit: All applications for water
and sewer service shall be signed by the owner and/or tenant of the premises,
and shall contain an agreement to pay all bills. Such application when accepted
by the Water Department shall constitute a contract between the applicants and
the City. All applications for use of water by a tenant, shall in addition to
the signature of the owner, be accompanied by a cash deposit in an amount equal
to two (2) minimum bills, rounded up to the next five dollar ($5.00) increment,
for a single dwelling and one hundred dollars ($100.00) for a business
establishment. Such deposit shall be returned to the applicant, less final
amount owed for water and sewer. The final bill is to be computed with the next
regularly scheduled billing. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-22: NO SERVICE AT NEW LOCATION UNTIL PAYMENT OF DELINQUENT RENTALS:
No persons, either owners or tenants, who in changing their residence from one
location to another served by the Water and Sewer Department, shall be given
water and sewer service until any and all delinquent accounts, which are
charged against them at their former place of residence, shall have been paid
in full. No water at a new location shall be turned on and if water has been
turned on, it shall be turned off until settlement of such delinquent water and
sewer rental at the former location is made. Also, no water at the new location
shall be turned on and if water has been turned on, it shall be turned off, if
there is a delinquency at the new location, until settlement of such delinquent
account has been made. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-23: RATES AND CHARGES:
The rates and charges for the use and services of the waterworks, sewerage and
drainage system of the city of East Moline are hereby established. Such rates
and charges shall be made and collected against each lot, parcel of land, or
premises which may have any active water and/or sewer connections with the
waterworks and sewage systems of the city of East Moline or which may actively
use water and discharge sewage or industrial waste either directly or
indirectly into said system or any part thereof.
The rates for all water used, subject to minimum service charges, hereinafter
stated shall be as follows: (Ord. 03-12, 4-21-2003)

   (K)   Drainage Fund: All funds collected from the storm sewer rates and
surcharges shall be deposited into the drainage fund of this system. The
drainage fund shall be considered a separate operation fund with sewerage
revenue being transferred to the drainage fund on an as needed basis. (Ord. 03-

   (L)   Billing:
      1.   Billing for water usage, sewerage and drainage shall be prepared and
sent out by the city of East Moline, and said bills shall be payable fifteen
(15) days from postal date. Bills for residential water, sewerage and drainage
shall be prepared for a two (2) month period. The bills shall be payable at the
finance department.
      2.   A billing charge will be added to each water bill in the amount of
three dollars fifteen cents ($3.15). A billing charge will be added to each
sewer bill in the amount of three dollars fifteen cents ($3.15). (Ord. 04-27,
7-19-2004, eff. 7-31-2004)
   (M)   Liability: The owner of any lot, parcel of land, or premises having
active water and/or sewer connections with the waterworks and sewerage system
of the city, the occupant of such premises, and the user of such services shall
be jointly and severally liable to pay for such services to such lot, parcel of
land, or premises, and all services are furnished to the premises by the city
of East Moline only upon the condition that owner, occupant, and user shall be
jointly and severally liable therefor to the city of East Moline. (Ord. 03-12,
4-21-2003)
   (N)   Commencement Of Rates: (Rep. by Ord. 07-09, 9-4-2007)
   (O)   Connection Fees: Whenever any person, firm or corporation desire to
connect their premises with a water main and/or sanitary sewer owned by the
city of East Moline, and said premises have not been charged, nor has the owner
of said premises paid for the construction of the water main and/or sewer main,
said owner shall, in addition to the other applicable fees required by the
ordinances of said city, pay to the city a connection fee in the amount
assessed for each connection. Said fee or fees are to be paid before
application is made for a plumbing permit or permits to make the connection. If
the owner of the premises has at their own expense installed the water main
and/or sanitary sewer in the vicinity of the property to be served by said
connection, no connection fee shall be charged; however, the plumbing permit(s)
shall be required.
   (P)   Special Charges: The city council reserves the right to make special
charges for services supplied to properties which may not be covered by the
above rates or which, in the judgment of the council, should be charged special
rates due to the extent of the use of water or sewage service so supplied.
(Ord. 03-12, 4-21-2003)

8-8-24: REVENUE:
All revenues derived from the operation of the waterworks and sewerage system
of the city shall promptly be deposited and held in the waterworks and sewerage
system fund established by an ordinance entitled:
   AN ORDINANCE COMBINING THE EXISTING WATERWORKS SYSTEM AND THE EXISTING
SEWERAGE SYSTEM OF THE CITY OF EAST MOLINE, ROCK ISLAND COUNTY, ILLINOIS;
PROVIDING FOR THE ISSUANCE OF WATERWORKS AND SEWERAGE SYSTEM REFUNDING AND
IMPROVEMENT REVENUE BONDS OF SAID CITY IN THE AGGREGATE PRINCIPAL AMOUNT OF
FIVE MILLION, THREE HUNDRED FIFTEEN THOUSAND DOLLARS ($5,315,000); PRESCRIBING
THE FORM AND INCIDENTS OF SAID BONDS; PROVIDING FOR THE REFUNDING OF CERTAIN
OUTSTANDING BOND ISSUES OF SAID CITY; PROVIDING FOR THE COLLECTION OF REVENUES
FROM SAID COMBINED WATERWORKS AND SEWERAGE SYSTEM SUFFICIENT FOR THE PURPOSE OF
PAYING THE COST OF THE OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE COST OF THE OPERATION AND
MAINTENANCE THEREOF; PROVIDING AN ADEQUATE DEPRECIATION FUND THEREFOR, AND
PROVIDING FOR THE PAYMENT OF SAID BONDS, BOTH AS TO PRINCIPAL AND INTEREST; AND
FURTHER PROVIDING FOR THE SEGREGATION AND DISTRIBUTION OF SAID REVENUES
passed on September 7, 1965, and shall be credited, held, and disbursed in
accordance with the provisions of said ordinance.
   (A)   Records And Accounting: The city finance director shall install and
maintain a proper system of accounts and records, separate and apart from all
other accounts and records showing the amount of revenues received from the
waterworks and sewerage system and the application of all such revenues and all
financial transactions in connection therewith.
      Such accounts shall be kept and an annual audit thereof shall be made in
accordance with the provisions of the aforesaid ordinance passed on September
7, 1965, which authorized the above mentioned waterworks and sewerage system
refunding and improvement bonds.
      All revenues derived from the operation of the waterworks and sewerage
system shall be kept in a bank account separate and distinct from all other
funds or bank accounts of the city, as provided by the aforesaid ordinance.
   (B)   Auditing: The waterworks and sewerage system fund shall be audited
after the close of each fiscal year by an independent firm of certified public
accountants. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-25: DISCONTINUED USE OF WATER:
Owners or consumers desiring to discontinue the use of water shall give a
minimum twenty four (24) hour notice thereof to the water and sewer department
at the city hall office who shall cause the water to be turned off and the
meter removed. Water and sewer rents or charges for services shall be made
until such notice is given. When water and sewer service is discontinued all
water and sewer rentals for such service that is currently outstanding shall
become due and payable. The final billing is due and payable after issuance of
the bill. "Minimum bill" charges, or actual usage, will be due if the meter is
not removed.
Owners or consumers desiring to have periodic water disconnection and
reconnection shall be subject to a single thirty five dollar ($35.00) fee for
the disconnection and reconnection of the water service. This charge will be
incurred at time of disconnect. (Ord. 13-19, 9-3-2013)
8-8-26: COLLECTING ZONES, PAYMENT DATES AND PENALTIES:
Failure to receive a bill will not protect the owner or consumer from the
assessment of a penalty.
Notice must be given by the owner or authorized agent if it is desired that
bills be forwarded to any other address than the premises supplied.
The city of East Moline water and sewer department shall have full power and
authority to require the payment in advance for the use of water furnished to
any building, place or premises. In case prompt payment for the water and/or
sewer shall not be made the city finance director may authorize the water to
such premises be turned off and shall not be compelled again to supply said
premises with water until said arrears, together with the costs and expense of
turning said water off and on, shall be fully paid. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-27: NOTICE OF DELINQUENCY:
   (A)   If the charges for the use and services of the waterworks, and
sewerage and drainage system are not paid within seventeen (17) days after the
rendition of the bill, such charges shall be deemed and are hereby declared to
be delinquent. Delinquent charges shall thereafter constitute liens upon the
real estate to which the water and sewerage services shall have been furnished.
The city finance director or city attorney may file after the expiration of
such seventeen (17) days, a notice of such lien in the office of the recorder
of deeds of Rock Island County, Illinois. This notice shall consist of a sworn
statement of the city finance director setting out:
      1.   A description of such real estate sufficient for the identification
thereof;
      2.   The amount of money due for the use and services of the waterworks
and sewerage system; and costs of filing and releasing of liens;
      3.   The date when such amount became delinquent. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
   (B)   The director of maintenance services shall turn off the water, after
notification of the City Finance Director, of any premises if the charges for
the use and services of the waterworks and sewage and drainage system are not
paid within forty (40) days after rendition of the bill therefor.
A charge of ten dollars ($ 10.00) will be made upon the issuance or delivery of
a warning notice (red tag) for the disconnection of water service.
A charge of thirty-five dollars ($35.00) will be made for turning off the water
whenever water is shut off for nonpayment of water and/or sewer service. If a
water and/or sewer customer requests to have water turned on same day or after
normal business hours the charge will ninety dollars ($90.00).
Water will not be turned on again until the above mentioned charges have been
paid.
   (C)   An individual, 18 years or older, must be present during the time that
the City is turning on the water/sewer service to the premises. (Ord. 13-18, 9-
3-2013; amd. Ord. 18-34, 12-17-2018; Ord. 21-09, 8-2-2021; Ord. 21-16, 12-6-
2021)
8-8-28: ADJUSTMENT OF WATER CHARGES:
In case of a dispute over the amount of a bill or over the accuracy of a meter,
the water distribution department shall, at the request of the consumer, test
the meter after the required deposit has been made by the customer. The
following rates shall apply: under two inches (2"), twenty five dollars
($25.00); two inches (2") and over, fifty dollars ($50.00), plus any additional
costs. The customer is encouraged to witness the meter testing, but if the
individual chooses not to attend, the validity of the test results are final.
If it is found upon such test that the meter registers a greater amount of
water than has actually passed through said meter (allowing 2 percent for
accuracy) the bill will be adjusted to conform with the correct amount passing
through said meter, and the deposit shall be returned. If, however, the meter
registers correctly the amount of water passing through it or is slow by two
percent (2%) or more the owner shall be required to forfeit the deposit for the
test. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-29: LEAKAGE:
No billing adjustment shall be made due to leakage after the water has passed
through and has been registered by the meter. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-30: WATER METERS:
   (A)   All water furnished consumers shall be metered. One meter per customer
under two inches (2") shall be furnished and installed by the city water
distribution department, but owners must provide a suitable location and proper
opening in piping system per the plumbing code. All proper valves and fittings
necessary to comply with the requirements and to provide connection to meter,
except a coupling or flange at each end of the meter, shall be provided by the
owner of premises to be served. Meters shall be placed on service pipe not to
exceed two feet (2') from the wall where such pipe enters the premises. There
shall be a suitable place provided for the meter so as to keep it dry and
clean, and readily accessible at all times to the meter reader and inspectors
of the water distribution department.
   (B)   In case two (2) or more meters are desired for measuring water to
different tenants in the same building from one service connection, they shall
be so placed that neither one of them shall measure water which has passed
through the other one. Each metered service connection shall be separately
valved.
   (C)   All water meters two inches (2") and larger shall be furnished by the
city. The customer will be responsible for the installation of the meter, as
well as any cost incurred for said installation.
   (D)   All such systems, two inches (2") or larger, shall be installed by the
customer with a bypass with a valve connection at each end of the bypass to
permit the repair, testing or replacement of a meter. All bypass valves shall
be sealed.
   (E)   Size of meters for any buildings, industry or apartments shall be
approved by the plumbing inspector at the time of application for water
service. The size of meters so specified shall be subject to change as the
demand or other conditions may develop. The city’s plumbing inspector reserves
the right to require an increase in the size of meter.
   (F)   No meters shall be installed in pits.
   (G)   The owner and/or contractor of a new building shall be responsible for
the installation of the remote wire from the water meter location to the remote
reading device location when a meter is relocated or a second meter is
installed. There shall be a suitable place provided so the remote is readily
accessible at all times to the meter reader and inspectors of the city. The
wire used in such installations shall be 22/3 AWG solid conductor outdoor
communication cable with three (3) wires being black, green, and red in color.
Installation of the wire and location of the remote reading device shall be
completed prior to precover inspection of the plumbing inspection. (Ord. 99-10,
3-15-1999; amd. Ord. 00-27, 8-21-2000; Ord. 20-15, 8-3-2020)
8-8-31: OWNERS TO PROTECT METERS:
   (A)   The owner or occupant of premises where a meter is installed shall be
held responsible for its care and protection from freezing or hot water and
from other damage or interference from any person or persons. In case of any
damage to the meter, or in case of its stoppage or malfunction he shall give
immediate notice to the water and sewer office. In all cases where meters are
broken or damaged by negligence of owners, occupants, or their agents, except
for ordinary wear and tear, the necessary repairs shall be paid for by such
owner or occupant, and in case payment thereof is neglected or refused, the
water service shall be turned off and shall not be turned on until full payment
has been made, together with a turn off and a turn on fee of thirty five
dollars ($35.00). Damaged meters may be repaired by the water distribution
department without first giving notice to the owner or occupant of premises
served by such meter.
   (B)   No one shall in any way interfere with the proper registration of a
water meter, and no one except an authorized employee of the water distribution
department shall break a seal of a meter; provided, however, that the city's
plumbing inspector may grant written permits to licensed plumbers in case of
emergency to break such seal for drainage pipes or stopping water leaks. (Ord.
99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-32: DISCONTINUED USE OF METER:
Whenever an owner or occupant of premises wishes to or is required to
discontinue a water service either temporarily or permanently, notice shall be
given at least twenty four (24) hours in advance of the next business day to
the water and sewer office for removal of the meter. The owner of the premises
shall provide free access and shall be held responsible for that meter until
such meter has been removed, and if the meter is inaccessible, covered or lost,
the owner shall be required to pay for the same at the actual value of the
replacement meter. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-33: REPAIRING METERS:
The Water Distribution Department shall not be denied the right to enter any
premises supplied by City water to exchange any meter, for repairs or other
cause, as may be deemed necessary by the Department. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-34: UNLAWFUL TO OBSTRUCT:
No person shall in any manner obstruct the access of any curb box stop, water
meter, remote reading device, dial or valve connected with any water service,
by means of any lumber, brick building material, fuel, or any other article,
thing or hindrance, particularly the obstruction of meters that will interfere
with the ready access to meters at any and all times. Neglecting to comply with
this provision, the consumer at once becomes liable and the water will be
turned off, after notice has been given, until said obstruction shall be
removed. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-35: WATER FOR CONSTRUCTION AND SPECIAL PURPOSES:
The consumer is to notify the City's Plumbing Inspector of location of usage.
To determine water usage, the City's Plumbing Inspector will determine whether
to install a meter or charge a flat rate. Unmetered water usage will not be
allowed for any reason, without approval of the City's Plumbing Inspector.
Persons violating this Section may be subject to possible criminal prosecution
and/or fines. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-36: DAMAGE TO CITY UTILITIES OR APPURTENANCES:
Any person, persons, company, contractor or corporation who may be working in
any street of the City of East Moline who in any way damages the City utilities
or appurtenances thereto, shall be responsible to the City of East Moline for
any and all such damages and they shall bear all expenses of such replacement
or repair made necessary thereby, and they shall also be responsible for damage
to surrounding properties, on account of said damages to City utilities or
appurtenances. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-37: FIRE HYDRANTS:
All fire hydrants installed in the City of East Moline, for the purpose of
extinguishing fires in said City are hereby declared to be public hydrants and
no person or persons other than members of the Fire Department of said City of
East Moline, for the uses and purposes of said Department, and those
specifically authorized by the Water Distribution Department, shall open any of
the hydrants or attempt to draw water from the same or in any manner interfere
with or damage any of said fire hydrants. No person shall in any manner
obstruct the access to or the view of fire hydrants. No fire hydrant may be
painted, unless authorization is granted in writing by the Director of
Maintenance Services. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-38: PLUMBING INSPECTOR TO REPORT:
It shall be the duty of the Plumbing Inspector to report, in writing, to the
Finance Department and Water Distribution Department, all premises inspected by
him where City water is used or about to be used, within forty eight (48) hours
after such inspection. Such report shall contain the name of the owner, address
of the property, and the name of the plumber or plumbers performing the work,
and any necessary data required as to the location of the tap-on main, stop
box, or curb box. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-39: INSPECTION AND INSPECTORS:
Inspectors, meter readers, or any other employee of the Water Distribution
Department, whose duty it may be to enter upon private premises to make
inspections and examination of water meters, pipes, fixtures, or appurtenances,
thereto, for any reason whatsoever, in connection with the City water supply,
will be provided with a badge or other credentials to identify him, her or
them, as authorized agents and representatives of the Water Distribution
Department.
Any officer, inspector, meter reader or authorized agent, or employee of the
Water Distribution Department shall upon presentation of his or her badge or
other credentials provided for in the preceding paragraph, have free access at
any and all reasonable hours to any premises, supplied by City utilities, for
the purpose of making any inspection thereof. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-40: WATER DISTRIBUTION DEPARTMENT MAY INSPECT PREMISES:
In case any authorized agent or employee of said Water Distribution Department
shall be refused admittance to any premises, or after being admitted is
hindered or prevented in making such examination, the Water Distribution
Department may cause the water to be turned off from said premises, after
giving twenty four (24) hours' notice to the owner or occupant of said
premises.
No unauthorized person shall have, wear or exhibit any badge or credential of
the Department. It shall be the duty of each and every officer, agent or
employee of said Department, upon resignation or dismissal to surrender and
deliver to the Director of Maintenance Services all badges, credentials and
keys of the Water Distribution Department. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-41: OTHER DEPARTMENTS REQUIRED TO AID:
It shall be the duty of all City employees and officials to give aid to the
Water Distribution Department in the enforcement of this Ordinance and to this
end they shall report all violations thereof which come to their knowledge, to
the office of the City Finance Director. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-42: NO CONNECTION BETWEEN CITY AND OTHER SUPPLY:
No person, company or corporation shall be permitted to cause a connection to
be made or allow one to exist with City water supply for commercial, domestic,
sanitary, fire protection, or boiler feed purposes, or for any other purpose
whatsoever, where water foreign to the City water supply is used for a second
source of supply. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-43: REGULATION OF CROSS-CONNECTIONS:
   (A)   Definitions: For the purpose of this Chapter the following definitions
shall apply:
    BACKFLOW: Water of questionable quality, wastes or other contaminants
entering a public water supply system due to a reversal of flow. "Back
siphonage" is one type of "backflow".
   CROSS-CONNECTION: A connection or arrangement of piping or appurtenance in
which a backflow could occur.
   SAFE AIR GAP: The minimum distance of a water inlet or opening above the
maximum high-water level or overflow rim in a fixture, device or container to
which public water is furnished which shall be at least two (2) times the
inside diameter of the water inlet pipe; but shall not be less than one inch
(1") and need not be more than twelve inches (12").
   SECONDARY WATER SUPPLY: A water supply system maintained in addition to a
public water supply, including, but not limited to, water systems from ground
or surface sources or water from a public water supply which in any way has
been treated, processed or exposed to any possible contaminant or stored in
other than an approved storage facility.
   SUBMERGED INLET: A water pipe or extension thereto from a public water
supply terminating in a tank, vessel, fixture or appliance which may contain
water of questionable quality, waste or other contaminant and which is
unprotected against backflow.
   WATER UTILITY: The City Water Department.
   (B)   Compliance With Existing Laws: A connection with a public water supply
system shall comply with the existing laws and rules, the Illinois State
Plumbing Code, and the provisions of this Code.
   (C)   Cross-Connections Prohibited: Cross-connections of the public water
supply system and any other water supply system or source including, but not
limited to, the following are prohibited:
      1.   Between a public water supply system and a secondary water supply.
      2.   By submerged inlet.
      3.   Between a lawn sprinkling system and the public water supply system.
      4.   Between a public water supply and piping which may contain sanitary
waste or a chemical contaminant.
      5.   Between a public water supply system and piping immersed in a tank
or vessel which may contain a contaminant.
   (D)   Local Cross-Connection Control Program: The City shall develop a
comprehensive control program for the elimination and prevention of all cross-
connections, and removal of all existing cross-connections and prevention of
all future cross- connections.
   (E)   Corrections And Protective Devices: Any user of the water supply
system shall obtain written approval from the plumbing inspector of any
proposed corrective action or protective device before using or installing it.
The total time allowed for completion of the necessary corrections shall be
contingent upon the degree of hazard involved and include the time required to
obtain and install equipment. If the cross connection has not been removed
within the time as hereinafter specified, the city shall physically separate
the water supply system from the on site piping system in such manner that the
two (2) systems cannot be connected by any unauthorized person.
   (F)   Piping Identification: When a secondary water source is used in
addition to the public water supply, the public water supply and secondary
water piping shall be identified by distinguishing colors or tags and so
maintained that each pipe may be traced readily in its entirety, it will be
necessary to protect the water supply system at the service connection in a
manner acceptable to the plumbing inspector.
   (G)   Private Water Storage Tanks: A private water storage tank supplied
from the water supply system shall be deemed a secondary water supply unless it
is designed and approved for potable water usage.
   (H)   Elimination Of Existing Cross Connections: By August 1, 1994, all
existing cross connections to the water supply systems shall be eliminated. The
expenses of such elimination shall be that of the owner of the property on
which such cross connection exists.
   (I)   Inspection: The water department or plumbing inspector shall have the
authority to inspect any premises to determine the presence of an existing
cross connection and to order the elimination of such cross connection.
   (J)   Discontinuance Of Water Service: The water department is hereby
authorized to discontinue water service after a reasonable notice to any person
owning any property where a cross connection in violation of this code exists.
The water department may take such other precautionary measures as necessary to
eliminate any danger of the contamination of the water supply system. Water
service to such property shall not be restored until such cross connection has
been eliminated.
   (K)   Penalty: The city may issue a monetary penalty for noncompliance in
accordance with the provisions of this code of the city of East Moline. Any
person convicted of a violation of this ordinance section shall be fined in a
sum not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than five hundred dollars
($500.00), in addition to being subject to a petition to the circuit court of
Rock Island County for an order of compliance. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-44: REPEAL INVALIDITY OF PART:
Any ordinance or parts of ordinances in conflict with the provisions of this
ordinance are hereby repealed insofar as such conflict exists. If any section
or provision of this ordinance shall be held invalid, the remaining sections or
provisions of this ordinance shall be construed as though the invalid provision
or section had not been contained herein and shall remain in full force and
effect. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-45: EFFECTIVE DATE:
This ordinance shall be in effect immediately upon its passage and publication
as provided by law. (Ord. 99-10, 3-15-1999)
8-8-46: WATER REVIEW COMMITTEE:
There is hereby created the water review committee, of the city of East Moline.
This committee shall be made up of three (3) members, who shall be the city
administrator, the director of maintenance services, and the director of water
and wastewater facilities.
The water review committee shall act as the appeal board for those water and
sewer customers of the city, who have been unable to resolve a challenge to
their water bill, with the director of finance. The committee shall be convened
by the director of finance for a hearing with the water customer, upon at least
ten (10) days' written notice. All hearings of the committee shall be open to
the public. The director of finance shall prepare a report on the business of
the committee, and present the report to the city council on a quarterly basis.
The water review committee shall have authority to adjust a water bill up to an
amount of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) of an unpaid or
disputed water bill. Any adjustment shall be made by a majority vote of the
members of the committee. Any portion of the water bill that remains unpaid
after conclusion of the hearing before the water review committee, shall be
treated in the normal course of enforcement, by shutoff notice, lien, or
collection in court, as determined by the director of finance. (Ord. 10-27, 8-
16-2010)
CHAPTER 9
WASTEWATER REGULATIONS 1
SECTION:
8-9-1: General Provisions
8-9-2: General Sewer Use Requirements
8-9-3: Pretreatment Of Wastewater

8-9-5: Wastewater Discharge Permit Issuance Process
8-9-6: Reporting Requirements
8-9-7: Compliance Monitoring
8-9-8: Publication Of Users In Significant Noncompliance
8-9-9: Administrative Enforcement Remedies
8-9-10: Judicial Enforcement Remedies
8-9-11: Supplemental Enforcement Action
8-9-12: Affirmative Defenses To Discharge Violations
8-9-13: Miscellaneous Provisions
8-9-14: Use Of Public Sewers Required
8-9-15: Private Sewage Disposal
 
Notes
1 1. See also chapter 8 of this title.
8-9-1: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
   (A)   Purpose And Policy: This ordinance sets forth uniform requirements for
users of the publicly owned treatment works for the city of East Moline and
enables the city of East Moline to comply with all applicable state and federal
laws, including the clean water act (33 United States Code section 1251 et
seq.) and the general pretreatment regulations (40 code of federal regulations
part 403). The objectives of this ordinance are:
      1.   To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the publicly owned
treatment works that will interfere with its operation;
      2.   To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the publicly owned
treatment works that will pass through the publicly owned treatment works,
inadequately treated, into receiving waters, or otherwise be incompatible with
the publicly owned treatment works;
      3.   To protect both publicly owned treatment works personnel who may be
affected by wastewater and sludge in the course of their employment and the
general public;
      4.   To promote reuse and recycling of industrial wastewater and sludge
from the publicly owned treatment works;
      5.   To provide for fees for the equitable distribution of the cost of
operation, maintenance, and improvement of the publicly owned treatment works;
and
      6.   To enable the city of East Moline to comply with its national
pollutant discharge elimination system permit conditions, sludge use and
disposal requirements, and any other federal or state laws to which the
publicly owned treatment works is subject.
This ordinance shall apply to all users of the publicly owned treatment works.
This ordinance authorizes the issuance of wastewater discharge permits;
provides for monitoring, compliance, and enforcement activities; establishes
administrative review procedures; requires user reporting; and provides for the
setting of fees for the equitable distribution of costs resulting from the
program established herein.
   (B)   Administration: Except as otherwise provided herein, the
superintendent shall administer, implement, and enforce the provisions of this
ordinance. Any powers granted to or duties imposed upon the superintendent may
be delegated by the superintendent to other city of East Moline personnel.
   (C)   Abbreviations: The following abbreviations, when used in this
ordinance, shall have the designated meanings:
BMP:   Best management practice
BMR:   Baseline monitoring report
BOD:   Biochemical oxygen demand
CFR:   Code of federal regulations
CIU:   Categorical industrial user
COD:   Chemical oxygen demand
EPA:   U.S. environmental protection agency
FOG:   Fats, oils, and grease
gpd:   Gallons per day
IU:    Industrial user
mg/l:  Milligrams per liter
NPDES: National pollutant discharge elimination system
NSCIU: Nonsignificant categorical industrial user
POTW:  Publicly owned treatment works
RCRA:  Resource conservation and recovery act
SIC:   Standard industrial classification
SIU:   Significant industrial user
SNC:   Significant noncompliance
TSS:   Total suspended solids
TTO:   Total toxic organics
USC:   United States Code
 
   (D)   Definitions: Unless a provision explicitly states otherwise, the
following terms and phrases, as used in this ordinance, shall have the meanings
hereinafter designated:
   ACT OR THE ACT: The federal water pollution control act, also known as the
clean water act, as amended, 33 USC section 1251 et seq.
   APPROVAL AUTHORITY: USEPA, regional administrator, region 5, 230 S. Dearborn
Street, Chicago, IL 60604.
   AUTHORIZED OR DULY AUTHORIZED REPRESENTATIVE OF THE USER:
      1.   If the user is a corporation:
         (a)   The president, secretary, treasurer, or a vice president of the
corporation in charge of a principal business function, or any other person who
performs similar policy or decision making functions for the corporation; or
         (b)   The manager of one or more manufacturing, production, or
operation facilities employing more than two hundred fifty (250) persons or
having gross annual sales or expenditures exceeding twenty five million dollars
($25,000,000.00) (in second quarter 1980 dollars), if authority to sign
documents has been assigned or delegated to the manager in accordance with
corporate procedures.
      2.   If the user is a partnership or sole proprietorship: a general
partner or proprietor, respectively.
      3.   If the user is a federal, state, or local governmental facility: a
director or highest official appointed or designated to oversee the operation
and performance of the activities of the government facility, or their
designee.
      4.   The individuals described in subsections 1 through 3 of this
definition, may designate a duly authorized representative if the authorization
is in writing, the authorization specifies the individual or position
responsible for the overall operation of the facility from which the discharge
originates or having overall responsibility for environmental matters for the
company, and the written authorization is submitted to the city of East Moline.
   BATCH PROCESS: A treatment or manufacturing process in which a tank or
reactor is filled, the wastewater (or solution) is held or a chemical solution
is prepared, and the tank is emptied, resulting in a discrete discharge to the
sanitary sewer. The tank may then be refilled and the process repeated.
   BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES OR BMPs: Schedules of activities, prohibitions of
practices, maintenance procedures, and other management practices to implement
the prohibitions listed in subsections
8-9-2(A)1 and (A)2 of this chapter (40 CFR 403.5 (a)(1) and (b)). BMPs include
treatment requirements, operating procedures, and practices to control plant
site runoff, spillage or leaks, sludge or waste disposal, or drainage from raw
materials storage.
   BIOCHEMICAL OXYGEN DEMAND OR BOD: The quantity of oxygen utilized in the
biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedures
for five (5) days at twenty degrees centigrade (20°C), usually expressed as a
concentration (e.g., milligrams per liter).
   CATEGORICAL INDUSTRIAL USER (CIU): An industrial user which is subject to a
categorical standard promulgated by the USEPA.
   CATEGORICAL PRETREATMENT STANDARD OR CATEGORICAL STANDARD: Any regulation
containing pollutant discharge limits promulgated by EPA in accordance with
sections 307(b) and (c) of the act (33 USC section 1317) which apply to a
specific category of users and which appear in 40 CFR chapter I, subchapter N,
parts 405-471.
   CHAIN OF CUSTODY: A legal record (which may be a series of records) of each
person who had possession of an environmental sample, from the person who
collected the sample to the person who analyzed the sample in the laboratory
and to the person who witnessed the disposal of the sample.
   CITY: The city of East Moline or the city council of East Moline.
   CONFINED SPACE: A space which, by design, has limited openings for entry and
exit, unfavorable natural ventilation which could contain or produce dangerous
air contaminants (or create an atmosphere of oxygen deprivation), and which is
not intended for continuous employee occupation. A permit may be required under
OSHA to enter a confined space.
   CONTROL AUTHORITY: The city of East Moline.
   CONVENTIONAL POLLUTANT: A pollutant which has been designated as
conventional under section 304(a)(4) of the act. These pollutants include: BOD,
TSS, pH, fecal coliform, and oil and grease.
   DAILY MAXIMUM: The arithmetic average of all effluent samples for a
pollutant collected during a calendar day.
   DAILY MAXIMUM LIMIT: The maximum allowable discharge limit of a pollutant
during a calendar day. Where daily maximum limits are expressed in units of
mass, the daily discharge is the total mass discharged over the course of the
day. Where daily maximum limits are expressed in terms of a concentration, the
daily discharge is the arithmetic average measurement of the pollutant
concentration derived from all measurements taken that day.
   ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY OR EPA: The U.S. environmental protection
agency or, where appropriate, the regional water management division director,
or other duly authorized official of said agency.
   EXISTING SOURCE: Any source of discharge that is not a "new source".
   GRAB SAMPLE: A sample which is taken from a waste stream without regard to
the flow in the waste stream and over a period of time not to exceed fifteen
(15) minutes.
   HAZARDOUS WASTE (40 CFR 261): Unless excluded by the domestic sewage
exemption and not a solid waste, a solid waste is a hazardous waste if it meets
one of two (2) criteria: 1) it has one of the following four (4)
characteristics: ignitability, corrosivity, reactivity, or toxicity (according
to the toxicity characteristic leaching procedure), or 2) it must be a listed
hazardous waste in 40 CFR 261.31-261.33.
   INDIRECT DISCHARGE OR DISCHARGE: The introduction of pollutants into the
POTW from any nondomestic source.
   INDUSTRIAL USER: An industrial user is any nondomestic source which
introduces pollutants into a publicly owned treatment works (POTW).
   INSTANTANEOUS MAXIMUM ALLOWABLE DISCHARGE LIMIT: The maximum concentration
of a pollutant allowed to be discharged at any time, determined from the
analysis of any discrete or composited sample collected, independent of the
industrial flow rate and the duration of the sampling event.
   INTERFERENCE: A discharge, which alone or in conjunction with a discharge or
discharges from other sources, inhibits or disrupts the POTW, its treatment
processes or operations or its sludge processes, use or disposal; and
therefore, is a cause of a violation of the city of East Moline's NPDES permit
or of the prevention of sewage sludge use or disposal in compliance with any of
the following statutory/regulatory provisions or permits issued thereunder, or
any more stringent state or local regulations: section 405 of the act; the
solid waste disposal act, including title II commonly referred to as the
resource conservation and recovery act (RCRA); any state regulations contained
in any state sludge management plan prepared pursuant to subtitle D of the
solid waste disposal act; the clean air act; the toxic substances control act;
and the marine protection, research, and sanctuaries act.
   LOCAL LIMITS (40 CFR 403.3(c)): Effluent discharge limits applicable to
industrial users of the city of East Moline, developed by the city of East
Moline in accordance with 40 CFR 403.5(c).
   MAY: Is permissive.
   MEDICAL WASTE: Isolation wastes, infectious agents, human blood and blood
products, pathological wastes, sharps, body parts, contaminated bedding,
surgical wastes, potentially contaminated laboratory wastes, and dialysis
wastes.
   MONTHLY AVERAGE: The sum of all "daily discharges" measured during a
calendar month divided by the number of "daily discharges" measured during the
month.
   MONTHLY AVERAGE LIMIT: The highest allowable average of "daily discharges"
over a calendar month, calculated as the sum of all "daily discharges" measured
during a calendar month divided by the number of "daily discharges" measured
during that month.
   NEW SOURCE:
      1.   Any building, structure, facility, or installation from which there
is (or may be) a discharge of pollutants, the construction of which commenced
after the publication of proposed pretreatment standards under section 307(c)
